IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The inability to clinically treat cancer metastasis is responsible for the majority of patient deaths from solid tumors, including breast cancer. Cell migration is a pivotal step in the metastatic dissemination of cancerous cells from a primary tumor to distant organs in the body. We herein employ a multidisciplinary approach, which integrates state-of-the-art bioengineering and imaging tools, quantitative analysis and in vivo models, to offer a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms driving breast cancer cell migration in physically-confined spaces and identify novel therapeutic targets to reduce breast cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most of the over 40,000 patients diagnosed with pancreatic cancer each year in this country will die from metastatic disease. Irreversible electroporation (IRE) is a non-thermal ablation technique that is currently being used clinically to treat locally advanced tumors. The goal of this research is to understand effects of IRE on the immune system and to augment these effects using immunotherapy agents to eradicate distant micrometastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Completion of this work will provide a detailed mechanistic understanding of how SAMHD1 non-catalytically directs CtIP function in DSB repair to maintain genome integrity and govern breast cancer treatment resistance and new insights into how SAMHD1 dysregulation leads to genomic instability and development of disease, including cancer, autoimmune disease, and viral infection. In addition, this work is expected to elucidate the significance of the SIRT1 acetylome in directing SAMHD1 in DSB repair, providing new insights into the upstream signaling events governing SAMHD1 function in DSB repair and how loss of Sirt1 results in an in vivo tumor permissive phenotype. Finally, this work will establish proof of concept for the use of VLPs with Vpx in targeting SAMHD1 as a novel therapeutic approach for sensitizing resistant breast cancer to DSB-inducing agents that may significantly improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 60 million rural residents of the United States have a lower rate of new cases of cancer per year compared to urban residents but have a higher rate of cancer deaths per year, partly due to the greater difficulty in accessing high-quality cancer treatment in rural areas. As rural patients are less likely to receive care in urban cancer centers with cancer specialists who treat very large numbers of cancer patients, an effective strategy used by the University of Kentucky Markey Cancer Center has been to share their expertise and resources with smaller community hospitals across Kentucky to help improve their quality of care. We propose to study the Kentucky model in order to identify and characterize its core functions (i.e., what made it effective in improving quality of care in community hospitals), adapt it to a new rural setting, and determine its value to the hospitals and impact on cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Pancreatic cancer is a leading cause of cancer mortality with few effective therapies. This project will develop a novel immunotherapy that we show has pronounced therapeutic activity in preclinical animal models. We will uncover the mechanistic basis for the observed antitumor effects and create a novel immune therapy designed to change the standard of care for pancreatic cancer patient treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deaths from esophageal adenocarcinoma continue to rise, yet factors driving this trend remain poorly understood. We hope to demonstrate that the inter-relationship between gastro-esophageal reflux bile acid composition, Notch signaling activity, and esophageal bacterial composition is key to driving esophageal neoplasia. This knowledge can in turn be translated to future efforts to modify these factors to prevent esophageal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor heterogeneity is a well-known property of treatment resistant, recurrent, and metastatic breast cancer. The proposed research project is relevant to public health because it will provide a genetically tractable Cancer rainbow mouse model for inducing and visualizing tumor heterogeneity in an immune intact system. The proposed studies will credential the use of a novel Crainbow mouse model that more accurately recapitulates the heterogeneity found in treatment resistant HER2+ breast cancer patients. Our proposal will significantly improve upon the translational utility of mouse models for preclinical trials and at the same time provide a reliable tool for reconstructing the molecular and cellular interactome controlling tumor heterogeneity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite several ground-breaking advances in the treatment of lung cancer, the overall outlook remains dismal, necessitating the urgent development of preventive therapies. We have observed that use of the anti-diabetic drug metformin is associated with improved lung cancer outcomes selectively in patients who are overweight and obese and have linked this association to metformin-induced immunological changes in both humans and mice. With a clinical trial and mouse experiments, we propose to study if the anti-cancer immune effect of metformin occurs in obese subjects who have a high risk for developing lung cancer occurs so that the drug may be used for cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Chemotherapy is the standard of care for triple-negative breast cancer, however up to 25% of patients who receive this treatment will suffer metastatic recurrence within five years. The extracellular matrix is a major component of the tumor microenvironment, which provides structure and support to our tissues, which is known to drive invasion and metastasis. The goal of this project is to investigate how the extracellular matrix contributes to chemoresistance and chemotherapy-induced metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Chemoresistant prostate cancer (PCa) is lethal with no cure. This R01 project will develop a novel class of EED inhibitors that interrupt EED-EZH2 interaction and block noncanonical EZH2 survival signaling in chemoresistant PCa cells. We anticipate to identify several patentable, highly potent and efficacious EED inhibitors with optimized pharmacological profiles and drug-like properties, which can be promptly moved to the next stages of drug development. This project is original, innovative and has high impact on both translational research and patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Basal-like breast cancer has the worst prognosis of all breast cancer types. One of the hurdles to identifying effective targeted therapies is the uncertainty about how the disease arises in the first place. By examining cancer-prone tissues before tumor onset, we hope to identify the path(s) that cells take en route to becoming a basal-like cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is the most aggressive and deadly form of brain cancer whose poor clinical outcome stems from its diffuse invasion throughout the brain and drug resistance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The numbers of breast cancer survivors are increasing and their symptom burden after treatment is significant. Despite a growing evidence base of symptom management and risk reduction strategies, use of these activities in primary care practice remains suboptimal. This study engages critical stakeholders in identifying and prioritizing evidence based activities to enhance breast cancer survivorship care and has potential to impact implementation strategies used throughout the U.S. for long-term care for patients with a history of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) is a highly aggressive disease that has limited treatment options. This proposal focuses on determining if a protein called YES1 may underlie the malignancy associated with TNBC and the molecular pathways it uses to cause poor patient outcomes. This work will also provide a proof-of- concept in model systems testing the possibility of inhibiting YES1 with drugs that may ultimately lead to a more effective approach for treating TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Approximately 42%of American adults are obese, and this condition is strongly related to the development of colorectal cancer. Innovative lifestyle strategies to treat obesity and reduce colorectal cancer risk are critically needed. The proposed research will demonstrate that time-restricted eating, a type of intermittent fasting, is an effective therapy to help obese individuals reduce and control their body weight and prevent the development of colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medically underserved patients have the highest burden of multiple chronic conditions and are at increased risk for poor outcomes during and after cancer treatment. As medically underserved complex cancer patients may lack healthcare knowledge and access to supportive care, their health outcomes and care transitions might be improved by enhancing communication and collaboration between their oncologists and primary care providers (PCPs). This study tests and evaluates a novel shared care model for complex cancer survivors called OPTIMISE that shifts the timing of thinking about survivorship to point of diagnosis and seeks to develop a clinical infrastructure to support continuity of care from cancer diagnosis through post-treatment survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Significance Recent landmark studies from the Children’s Oncology Group (COG) highlight adherence to home-based oral chemotherapy as an enduring problem in pediatric cancer care. Yet, little is known about why some families have difficulty adhering to their child’s home-based oral chemotherapy while others do not. Through the novel examination of how behavioral parenting skills shape adherence at the episode and daily levels the proposed program of research has potential to lead to a paradigm shift in pediatric cancer adherence risk prediction and interventions, moving away from blunt demographic-based risk prediction and identifying behavioral parenting skills that are easily amenable to screening, modifiable, and may be more precise predictors of non-adherence risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative EBV-associated cancers represent an important unmet medical need. New therapeutic strategies are required to improve patient outcomes. We have developed small molecules inhibitors to EBNA1 to treat EBV latent infection driving EBV-associated cancers. We now propose to better understand how tumor cells respond to these inhibitors and enhance their efficacy by rational combinatorial therapies and structure-based chemical modifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer mortality disparities remains an important public health and clinical challenge. Understanding breast cancer recurrence is a critical target in reducing disparities, but a lack of population-based data limit inferences. The proposed study will advance our understanding of multi-level drivers of demographic disparities in recurrence and breast cancer-specific mortality, and facilitate prioritization of intervention targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The biological mechanisms that drive genetic susceptibility to ovarian cancer are not well understood. This grant will use ultra-sensitive sequencing to characterize with high resolution TP53 mutations in fallopian tube during normal aging and in women with susceptibility to ovarian cancer to determine whether elevated risk of ovarian cancer is associated with increased somatic TP53 clonal evolution. This research will increase our understanding of ovarian carcinogenesis and enable to develop better strategies for ovarian cancer prevention and prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastatic disease accounts for >90% of cancer-related deaths worldwide, yet this phase of tumor progression is the least biologically understood. To address this challenge, we will integrate newly developed protein phenotyping technology, sophisticated computational biologic analyses, and an understudied neoplastic hybrid cell that represents the largest tumor population in peripheral blood. Our proposed study will explore the biology underlying the lifecycle of a disseminated neoplastic hybrid cells providing new insights into metastatic disease effectors, identification of pre-metastatic tumor states, and evaluation of a stage II colorectal cancer patient cohort in need of new approaches for treatment stratification to impact their survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE There is currently no acceptable screening method for ovarian cancer, and most cases are detected when the disease is widespread and likely to be deadly. We will develop a two-step blood-based biomarker followed by a minimally-invasive fallopian tube imaging and sampling technique, as an effective method to detect ovarian cancer at an early time when the disease is most curable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the promise of smoking cessation interventions in people living with HIV (PLWH), intervention potential is limited by a lack of understanding about how to best implement evidence-based cessation strategies in this population. Tobacco treatment with first-line pharmacotherapy, delivered remotely in a proactive, opt-out fashion presents an opportunity for PLWH to receive robust, evidence-based tobacco treatment even if they are not currently motivated to quit smoking. By optimizing the delivery of effective tobacco treatments for PLWH, we hope to increase the number of people receiving tobacco treatment, increase tobacco cessation rates, and reduce the risk of morbidity and mortality from smoking-related causes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study addresses how a chaperone molecule called GRP94 controls cancer and determines the best strategy to target GRP94 for cancer immunotherapy. Significant discoveries have been made regarding the roles of GRP94 in controlling the pathway of transforming growth factor beta (TGFb). Several therapeutic leads have emerged in blocking the GRP94-TGFb pathway; further in-depth study of GRP94 will advance novel therapies for cancer.

PHR: Chronic low back pain is a major contributor to disability in the United States. Lumbar radiofrequency ablation (LRFA) is a non-surgical procedure to treat chronic low back pain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE MDM2 and its numerous isoforms are key regulators of the expression and function of the p53 gene, a critical tumor suppressor that prevents inappropriate cell growth and proliferation. The proposed research will study the molecular connection between DNA damage, MDM2 isoform switching, p53, and cancer. Unraveling this pathway could lead to the discovery of novel therapeutic intervention points and thus be a crucial stepping-stone for cancer drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is prevalent in humans and has been implicated in the malignant brain tumor glioblastoma (GBM) and other cancers. We have developed a novel murine model of CMV in GBM and identified for the first time potential molecular and cellular mechanisms by which CMV can accelerate tumor growth and alter responses to therapy. Therefore, in this project we will use this model alongside human GBM samples from patients with known CMV status to further understand the biology of CMV in GBM and assess new approaches to improve GBM treatment with the goal of rapid translation to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies are relevant to public health because they have the potential to identify women at high risk of breast cancer using ethnic-specific models. Thus, this advance is expected to have a high impact to the health and well being of women because women at high risk may choose to alter the breast cancer screening frequency for earlier detection or to participate in risk reduction strategies, such as lifestyle modification. Both approaches will reduce breast cancer mortality. This is relevant to the part of NIH's mission which focuses on the prevention of disease by supporting research in the prevention and early detection of human diseases.

PHR: To address “PQ9: What methods can be developed to effectively study small or rare populations relevant to cancer research” we will develop organoids of rare neuroendocrine tumors pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas (PPGL). Currently there are no markers of clinical behavior and malignant PPGLs can only be recognized after metastases develop, for which there are few treatment options. PPGL organoids will enable investigation of tumor markers of outcome and drug screen to identify potential new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is the causal agent of Kaposi sarcoma, a common cancer in immunocompromised people (such as HIV/AIDS and transplant patients) and two lymphoid malignancies. We have designed a study to uncover the role of key KSHV glycoproteins in oral and systemic transmission of KSHV ex vivo and in vivo. We expect to generate critical data that will inform future design of an effective prophylactic KSHV vaccine candidate to prevent KSHV infection and its associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite enormous recent progress in treatment and supportive therapies for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), it accounts for the highest percentage of leukemic deaths, and less than a third of patients will become long-term survivors. We recently discovered that specific AML-associated mutations in two genes, isocitrate dehydrogenase-1 and -2 (IDH1/2), block DNA repair pathways and lead to sensitivity to drugs which block these same pathways. Here, we seek to develop highly effective combinations against AMLs with IDH1/2 mutations, as well as mutations in other AML-related genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The overarching goal of this study is to identify effective metabolic based diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to improve the overall survival of patients with Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). We propose to investigate the positron emission tomography (PET) tracer, 18F-BnTP as a novel metabolic diagnostic and to develop metabolic based therapeutic strategies targeting oxidative mitochondrial metabolism in therapy resistant KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors. This work represents a new approach to overcoming therapy resistance in KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors – one in which the tumor’s metabolic and bioenergetic dependencies are profiled and then selectively targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: We propose to investigate novel mechanisms of action of the SIRT7 enzyme in regulating chromatin – the structure in which the human genome is packaged – and how these mechanisms are linked to mammalian aging and cancer biology. Defects in chromatin regulation can contribute to numerous aging-associated pathologies, including cancer, metabolic and neurodegenerative disease. This proposal will provide new insights into how chromatin mechanisms regulate important cellular functions, and has the potential to identify new targets for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extant work has only minimally considered the potential role of historical structural racism in shaping trajectories of neighborhood built, social, and toxicant conditions (the neighborhood exposome), nor has it considered how these historical conditions impact child mental health outcomes. The proposed study will be the first to evaluate historical patterns of structural racism in shaping the current and dynamic neighborhood exposome, and ultimately associations with child internalizing and externalizing behaviors, advancing both our understanding of the role of historical structural racism and neighborhood context in human development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain arteriovenous malformations are abnormal connections between arteries and veins that result in a tangled network of blood vessels that are prone to rupture. Although they are the leading cause of stroke in children and young adults, the only available treatments are high-risk surgical approaches. We recently identified the genetic cause of the majority of brain arteriovenous malformations, and the goal of our project is to use our novel animal models of this disease to better understand bAVM pathogenesis and to use this information to develop drugs that can be used to treat it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to build an innovative, first-in-clinic, easy-to-use, oxygen scanner for repeated monitoring of tumor oxygen levels in cancer patients. The scanner will be built using the advanced in vivo electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) technology developed at Dartmouth College and in partnership with ViewRay®, a pioneer in the development of MRI image-guided linear accelerator for radiation therapy. The new oxygen scanner can provide potentially important and previously unavailable information on tumor oxygen status, which is important for accurate prognosis and development of effective treatment strategies for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) responds poorly to immunotherapy and the mechanisms of this resistance are unknown. We hypothesized that cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) mediate this intratumoral immunosuppression in a HIF2-dependent fashion and provide evidence that HIF2 inhibition improves survival in mouse models of PDAC by potentially improving immune responses. In this grant, we explore the mechanisms of HIF2-dependent immune modulation by CAFs and perform preclinical studies to repurpose an FDA-approved HIF2 inhibitor to improve the response of pancreatic cancer to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive cancer subtype with limited treatment options. We have made the surprising discovery that the antioxidant glutathione (GSH) functions extracellularly, not intracellularly, to support TNBC growth. Our research will challenge the paradigm of antioxidant function in cancer by describing a novel mechanism of GSH function as a circulating source of amino acids and has the potential to reveal a completely new set of therapeutic targets for TNBC intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the elucidation of new mechanisms (i.e., chronobiology) will increase the understanding of the negative consequences of common drugs on brain and behavior. This mechanistic neuroscience cannot be done in humans. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of NCI/NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing cancer-related comorbidities, which in turn, improves health and quality of life.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with cancer may use cannabis to manage symptoms, such as pain, and potentially reduce opioid use. Cannabis’ status as a Schedule 1 substance has made it difficult to study the role of cannabis use on pain and opioid use among cancer patients. This study will generate new knowledge to inform clinical practice and guidelines related to cannabis use in cancer pain and symptom management.

PHR: Project Narrative: Poly(ADP)-ribose polymerase inhibitors (PARPi) exemplify a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of homology-repair deficient tumors. The proposed research is relevant to public health as elucidation of the cellular DNA repair mechanisms that respond to PARPi treatment will enable novel approaches to combat clinical issues of resistance and relapse. PHR: Project narrative In consultation with end users, we will develop a first-in-class, inexpensive, rapid, and reliable point-of-care nucleic acid diagnostic to enable accessible and rapid testing for congenital syphilis. To enable development of modern diagnostics for maternal syphilis, we will evaluate detectability of syphilis pathogen DNA and syphilis associated microbiome changes in maternal vaginal swabs. The proposed project will make a significant impact on congenital syphilis prevention because our team has in-depth expertise, validated diagnostic assay and device technologies, public health nexus with sexual health care, industry partnerships for commercialization, and the commitment to make healthcare universally accessible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing evidence showing that AKR1C3 and AR/ARv7 play important roles in promoting prostate cancer progression and resistance. We have developed a number of novel small molecules that function as dual inhibitors of AR/ARv7 and AKR1C3. This application is aimed to determine the efficacy, mechanisms of action, and safety of these small molecules and to develop as novel agents to treat advanced prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Unscheduled whole-genome doubling events give rise to genetically unstable polyploid cells that can promote disease. The aims of this proposal are designed to identify unique the genetic adaptations acquired by polyploid cells that enable their sustained proliferation and survival. Successful completion of these aims will provide significant insight into the genesis and evolution of whole genome-doubled cells in vivo, as well as reveal innovative therapeutic avenues to selectively kill pathological polyploid cells while sparing the normal cells that comprise human tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) dysregulation in individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) are based solely on peripheral cortisol, and results are inconsistent and incomplete because we have not been able to study a marker of brain cortisol – forming a significant gap in the existing literature. Translating preclinical findings in the brain to human AUD is a critical next step in understanding HPA dysfunction in this population. This proposal will derive critical foundational information about HPA axis dysregulation in AUD at baseline by fully characterizing the availability of 11β-HSD1, a cortisol-regenerating enzyme, in the brain and peripheral cortisol levels and determine relationships to drinking behavior in people with AUD vs. healthy controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Jumonji histone demethylases are enzymes that drive cancer’s uncontrolled growth and allow cancer cells to adapt to therapeutic toxic stress, surviving it. Here we propose to define how a key Jumonji enzyme in lung cancer gets activated when DNA is damaged with radiation therapy and to find ways to block the activity of this enzyme in order to sensitize non-small cell lung cancers to radiation, overcoming radiation resistance. Our goal is to make lung tumors exquisitely responsive to radiation therapy locally, without any damage to normal tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to validate potential targets for chemoradiation sensitization in patients with cervical cancer undergoing chemoradiation for cure. This will be accomplished by testing previously identified potential targets in cervical cancer cell lines and organoid models and by computationally validating mutations that expand during CRT in patients undergoing treatment. This proposal uses a novel, non-invasive swab-based biopsy method to collect serial data without harm or discomfort to patients, which is the first approach in cervical cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Men of African ancestry have a higher incidence and mortality from prostate cancer (PCa) than men of European ancestry. There is currently an urgency to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying these race-related differences and to harness them for identifying novel therapeutic targets. The high mortality of advanced PCa is attributed to therapy resistance, thus there is also an urgent clinical need to develop innovative approaches to circumvent this resistance. The proposed study will uncover the molecular basis for specific race-related differences in PCa immunobiology, which could provide key insights into immune determinants contributing to PCa mortality disparities. The study will also establish the glycolytic enzyme Enolase as a potential therapeutic and theranostic target for advanced PCa, which could lead to innovative clinical strategies to reduce overall PCa mortality disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the US, approximately 1 in every 2-3 individuals will develop cancer, a disease of uncontrolled cellular proliferation that can be fatal. The TP53 gene is the most commonly mutated gene in human cancer, reflecting the fact that p53 plays an essential role as a tumor suppressor. This research aims to elucidate the mechanisms by which p53 acts to suppress cancer, with the ultimate goal of improving early detection and treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The primary focus of my work has been to understand the mechanisms by which cancers subvert normal developmental and stem cell signals to grow, spread and evade therapy. Over the last decade our work has ranged from discovery of new signals involved in cancer growth and progression to preclinical work that has formed the basis of clinical trials testing new agents for drug-resistant leukemias – leading to the recent approval of Glasdegib to treat aggressive leukemia – and pancreatic cancer. In the coming years, we will continue to strive to make important contributions that will have a meaningful impact on the many lives that deeply depend on the discoveries we make as a community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The only effective means of breast cancer prevention in women with inherited BRCA mutations is prophylactic mastectomy, which, while effective, raises issues relating to quality of life and other psychological and physical consequences. The overarching objective of this application is to develop strategies to detect and eliminate pre-malignant cells in breast tissues from high-risk women. To accomplish this goal, we have used state-of- the-art single-cell technologies to detect and isolate subpopulations of breast cells that accumulate in BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutation carriers and propose studies to determine how these subpopulations contribute to tumor development and what causes their accumulation in order to develop strategies to interfere with cancer development in high-risk women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Death from chemoresistant germ cell tumors (GCTs) account for the greatest number of life years lost of any non-childhood malignancy, and the origins and evolution to chemoresistance in this disease are incompletely characterized. We have developed data identifying reciprocal loss of heterozygosity (RLOH) as a disease- defining genomic defect in GCTs, presence of apoptotic priming underlying the more typical chemosensitivity, and accumulation of RLOH as GCTs evolve towards chemoresistance. Through the use of several novel molecular techniques applied directly to patient specimens, this proposal will enable this program to develop a more complete understanding of the factors driving oncogenesis and evolution to chemoresistance in this rare cancer, with the plan to translate targets revealed through this study to therapeutic development in this area of unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Rectal cancer represents a growing problem, because it is increasingly diagnosed in people in the prime of life; however, research into new treatments has been hampered because current models of rectal cancer poorly represent patient tumors. Our goal is to develop rectal cancer organoids (tumoroids) as models for rectal cancer research and to establish whether the tumoroids allow for prediction of individual patients' responses to the components of standard treatment, including chemotherapy or radiotherapy. The ultimate result will be expansion of patient-specific research tools, accelerated discovery of new treatment options for rectal cancer patients, and eventually better treatment decisions for individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colorectal cancer is the 2nd leading cause of cancer death in the United States. A lifestyle consistent with the American Cancer Society (ACS) Nutrition and Physical Activity Guidelines is associated with approximately 40% lower risk of death in people with colorectal cancer, but few colorectal cancer survivors follow the guidelines. This study will use an innovative framework to identify an intervention to improve physical activity, diet, and body size among colorectal cancer survivors that can be remotely delivered and broadly accessible.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent advances, lung cancer five-year survival rates remain dismal. One barrier to progress is the identification of new treatment strategies for specific genotype-defined subsets of lung cancer. In this work, we characterize the mechanism of a little-studied new cancer oncogene, RIT1, and test two new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of RIT1-mutant lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. A current challenge in cancer research is understanding tumor heterogeneity, a major cause of resistance to chemotherapy drugs as well as metastasis development. APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B have been identified as two of the major drivers of tumor heterogeneity by promoting the deamination of cytosine to uracil on DNA and inducing genomic mutations. The goal of this proposal is to uncover the molecular mechanisms that govern APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B regulation in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project narrative Our proposed research is to evaluate the effectiveness of using an existing implementation strategy infrastructure at academic centers in delivering best-practice communication interventions to increase HPV vaccination rates in rural primary care clinics. The project is relevant to public health because it aims to increase HPV vaccination rates and reduce cancer inequities in rural populations by addressing the context- specific communication needs of both rural providers and parents, especially those parents who are vaccine hesitant. The proposed research is relevant to the NCI because it aims to improve implementation of effective interventions that are responsive to behavioral and sociocultural factors in cancer prevention among rural populations, an understudied area in cancer prevention research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative When developing new cancer treatments, many scientists use animal models in which human tumors are implanted into research animals (i.e. patient-derived xenografts or PDXs). Despite the popularity of these models, we lack understanding of how we bias our results based on the methods we use to make new PDXs (e.g. implanting tumor pieces under the skin of immunocompromised mice as opposed to implanting into the site of origin). To improve the efficiency of pre-clinical research, this proposal will provide a clear answer to this question in head and neck cancer by methodically studying the site of implant, the age of the tumor, and the influence of an immune system on the tumor biology, evolution, and treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The resistance to current AR targeted therapies is one of the biggest challenges when treating advanced prostate cancer and largely hinders the clinical outcome of patients with this deadly disease. This study aims to determine the molecular role of a new potential tumor suppressor in prostate cancer, SYNCRIP, in suppressing APOBEC- mediating mutagenesis and resistance to AR targeted therapies. Elucidating the role of this protein and the molecular mechanism of the resistance may identify new actionable targets and establish a pathway for the development of therapeutic approaches to overcome the resistance and ultimately benefit patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanoma is an aggressive cancer with an increasing incidence. Metastatic melanoma to the liver is frequent and associated with poor prognosis and resistance to novel therapies, such as immunotherapies. The current study will use novel models, methodologies and a large cohort of patient biopsies to elucidate the molecular underpinnings of the development of liver metastasis and how these lesions confer resistance to immunotherapies. This will inform rationale design of novel therapeutic avenues for patients with metastatic melanoma to the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAR-T cell therapy drafts a patient's immune system (cytotoxic T cells) to target and kill tumors and its combination of pin-point specificity and broad efficacy has translated into exciting clinical data and revolutionary treatment for certain blood cancers. The major impediment to widespread use of CAR-T therapy remains its cost, which approaches $500K, a slow manufacturing process and huge regulatory hurdles for facilities that manufacture CAR-T cells. We will develop biomaterial approaches to CAR-T cell therapy, including improved methods to reprogram cells, to release cells quickly to tumors, and even to generate the CAR-T cells entirely within a patient's own body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  PARP inhibitor resistance is a growing clinical problem, and alternative therapeutic strategies are needed. Hyperactivation of Wnt/beta-catenin signaling drives PARP inhibitor resistance and immune evasion. Thus, we hypothesize that combining a Wnt inhibitor with a checkpoint blockade (e.g., anti-PD-1) could overcome PARPi resistance and activate an anti-tumor immune response. In our unique PARP inhibitor- resistant models, we propose to examine the anti-tumor effect of a first-in-class Wnt/ beta-catenin inhibitor in a syngeneic and humanized mouse models.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE No U.S. cohort to date has evaluated associations with per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) with measures of health consequence of reduced immune function including common childhood infections and some allergies, despite the use of decreased antibody response following vaccine as a critical endpoint for the regulation of PFAS. We propose to combine pediatric birth cohorts with available prenatal PFAS serum concentrations from across the Environmental Influences on Child Health Outcomes cohort, to evaluate associations with childhood infections (bronchiolitis, croup, pneumonia and bronchitis, ear infections) and allergies (allergy symptoms, and atopic dermatitis) at infancy and early childhood for individual PFAS and mixtures. Additional analyses will include effect modification by biological and sociodemographic factors to evaluate the cumulative impact of environmental stressors, as well as study of dietary and sociodemographic determinants of low-level PFAS exposure to develop guidance for reducing exposure among pregnant women in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on genetic and epigenetic factors that underlie the etiology of Ph-like acute lymphoblastic leukemia where there exists a cancer health disparity within the Hispanic/Latino population regarding incidence, prevalence, and mortality. Further understanding of these factors lays the groundwork for predictive diagnostics and personalized preventative medicine. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission to foster discoveries pertaining to the causes, diagnosis, and prevention human diseases and improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance narrative Approximately 19% of the US population resides in rural areas; for over three decades, this population has experienced increasingly inferior health outcomes when compared with their urban counterparts. The underlying cause(s) of the widening rural/urban gap in cancer outcomes is hypothesized to be multifactorial, and this study will provide a comprehensive multi-level evaluation of rural/urban mortality disparities. Findings will provide the critical evidence needed to inform policy, as well as to inform intervention development to address the systemic disparities in mortality experienced by rural patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly half of patients with pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PanNET) present with liver metastases at diagnosis, which correlates with poor prognosis, and the immunosuppressive microenvironment of PanNET limits the efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) for metastatic PanNET patients, with a less than 10% objective response rate. Emerging evidence suggests that increased vascular leakage and poor vascular perfusion resulting from vascular destabilization impair immune cell infiltration into tumors, thus facilitating tumor immune evasion and consequent tumor progression. In this work, we propose to study role of angiopoietin-2/Tie2 signaling, which regulates vascular destabilization and dysfunction, in liver metastatic progression and in ICI therapy resistance of metastatic PanNET as well as the potential of Tie signaling molecules as sensitive cancer biomarkers for PanNET patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This renewal application seeks support for the infrastructure maintenance of the Multiethnic Cohort (MEC) Study, established in 1993-1996, to continue a well-integrated program of research testing innovative hypotheses aimed at ensuring that racial/ethnic disparities are investigated and progress in disease prevention applies to major US racial/ethnic minorities. By including 215,251 men and women mostly of 5 racial/ethnic populations (African Americans, Japanese Americans, Latinos, Native Hawaiians and Whites), the MEC is the most racially and ethnically diverse cancer cohort, and its value for etiologic research on chronic diseases is widely recognized. Leadership of the MEC entails a highly interactive, team-science approach; investigators have amply demonstrated willingness to share data and samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance African Americans continue to have poor outcomes after a cancer diagnosis and few African American cohorts exist to support studies of the determinants of cancer prognosis and progression, survival, quality of life and post-treatment outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our inability to explain why some patients do not respond to immunotherapy, combined with our inability to predict the responders, poses a serious challenge to advancing cancer care and research. Currently, biopsies serve as the most informative way to assess the immunological activity within a cancerous area, but we are spatially and temporally limited in the number of biopsies we can obtain from patients, especially in cases of brain cancer. We propose here a novel strategy merging artificial intelligence and mechanistic modeling to reveal the spatial and temporal tumor-immune landscape within patients by connecting a unique resource of image-localized biopsies and clinical imaging for cohorts treated with standard and immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High throughput sequencing of the rearranged T cell receptor genes (HTS) is an approach that profiles T cells in the tissue and has enhanced the ability to diagnose and manage patients with cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL). However, the formalin used to preserve skin biopsy specimens damages DNA and affects readings in a way that could lead to errors in patient diagnosis and care. We seek to identify new fixatives and tissue handling procedures that enable multiple different analyses to be accurately carried out on small skin biopsies obtained in CTCL clinical trials, including HTS readings, histologic studies and measures of gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance to Public Health SIGNIFICANCE:  Cancer incidence and mortaility trends show therapeutic progress against multiple liquid and solid tumors, but some solid tumor types such as liver cancer remain exceptions [Siegel 2020], which motivates a deeper understanding of solid tumors.  We hypothesize a causal biophysical link between two aspects of solid tumors that are widely considered unrelated, namely (1) stiffness of the tissue which is a major risk factor for liver cancer – as it is for other maliganancies such as breast cancer, and (2) genetic changes – that are a hallmark of cancer and that are increasingly being targeted in therapy but are also most abundant in solid tumors.  We propose a mechano-genetics process in which genetic changes are caused by tissue stiffness including compression in mitosis, and to test our hypothesis and clarify aspects of mechanism, we will develop and apply a novel approach with gene editing that allows us to see genetic changes in real-time, in single cells under physical duress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Myxobacteria are an incredible resource for discovery of bacterial natural products and have provided candidate therapeutics with antibacterial, antifungal, cytotoxic, antiviral, and immunosuppressive activities. However, established synthetic biology tools for investigation of myxobacteria pale in comparison with techniques available for routine use with other prolific producers of biologically active metabolites such as Streptomyces. The proposed research will develop and utilize novel synthetic biology tools to ensure continued natural products discovery from this unique and underexplored resource.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-standing history and contribution to the Human Genome Program through clone generation (RP11 BAC libraries), high throughput mapping, array technology development, and distribution of these resources worldwide, provides a track record documenting expertise of the Genomics Shared Resource (GSR), which is an integral part of the Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center (Roswell Park) Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG) program (P30CA016056, PI Dr. Candace Johnson). As the Director of the GSR with over 19 years of relevant experience, Dr. Prashant Singh’s efforts are dedicated to support the mission of the GSR, which is to provide state-of-the-art instrumentation and expertise that enables CCSG members to acquire and analyze genomic data sets across basic, translational, clinical and population studies. Dr. Singh’s intellectual and practical contributions are invaluable to NCI-funded projects of the CCSG program members. Funding Dr. Singh as an NCI Core-based Scientist will ensure the stability and continued growth of a vital resource to Roswell Park’s CCSG programs and allow him to dedicate his time for novel technology development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tyrosine kinase driven Non-small-cell lung cancers (NSCLC) develop resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Waiting for resistance, reverse engineering its molecular origins, and then responding to that resistance with new drugs is a slow, costly, and ultimately losing battle. This grant will propel the model driven forward engineering design of “dual-switch selection drives” in NSCLC that re-program tumor cells to work with existing therapies to combat drug resistance—regardless of molecular origin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Using deconvolution approaches, we identified two tumor-intrinsic subtypes of PDAC (basal and classical) that are robust, replicable, prognostic and predictive of treatment response. We have also found two stroma subtypes associated with outcome and show tumor-stroma interactions in patients associated with outcome, recapitulated in tumor-CAF models. We will use a combination of cancer biology, computational approaches to determine tumor-stroma interactions and how they predict treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Michigan Center for Translational Cancer Proteogenomics (UM-CTCP) will perform advanced proteogenomics analyses a part of the Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium (CPTAC) initiative. Working in collaboration with other members of the CPTAC, UM-CTCP will apply its advanced computational infrastructure for comprehensive and global characterization of genomics, transcriptomics, and proteomics data, collected from several cohorts of human tumors using NCI-provided biospecimens. UM- CTCP will conduct integrative analyses of data across these different data types with a goal to identify potentially cancer-related molecular alterations and to elucidate how distinct changes at the protein level are related to abnormalities in cancer genomes. A second priority of UM-CTCP is to assist with the selection of cancer-specific protein candidates for subsequent functional studies and validation using targeted assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a critical underrepresentation of cancers from American Indian patients in national cancer genome databases. Additionally, American Indians have the poorest cancer survival rates of all ethnicities in the United States. The goal of this proposal is to engage with American Indian communities and individuals in order to increase their understanding and participation in precision medicine, molecular characterization of tumors and cancer research with the long-term goal of reducing their cancer burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Massachusetts, Boston (UMass Boston) and Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center (DF/HCC) Partnership is committed to further developing a shared rigorous and collaborative transdisciplinary cancer and disparities-related research program that is primed for “Bridging the Divides: Innovations to Address Gaps in Cancer Disparities Research, Education, Outreach and Infrastructure.” Sophisticated research projects are proposed across several areas of basic biomedical and population sciences that will employ evidence and methods to converge upon and impact cancer and cancer health disparities at multiple levels of analysis. These projects, together with state-of-the-art Outreach and Research Education Cores and creative Research Design and Analysis Core and Genomics Cores, will serve to build research capacity and infrastructure at UMass Boston, expand the cancer disparities platform and community outreach programs at DF/HCC; and make, at an elevated level, significant advances to the science of cancer control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/LAY SUMMARY Chronic kidney disease is a common diagnosis in the general community but also represents a concern in patients who undergo radical or partial nephrectomy for renal cancer. This research program will develop and employ deep learning algorithms to study macrostructural features of non-cancerous kidney tissue. The goals are to establish automated imaging biomarkers as tools that can aid clinicians in predicting the future development of chronic kidney disease and understanding their microstructural histology determinants (nephron hypertrophy and nephrosclerosis).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL COMPONENT The Stanford Brain Metastasis Consortium has unified brain and cancer experts in the singular goal of improving our understanding and treatment of brain metastases, a currently increasing yet underserved subset of cancer patients. To accomplish the above goal, we have developed highly innovative and complementary Projects to understand and disrupt the cancer-neuro-immune axis supporting brain metastases, and created Research Cores to make human specimens and cutting-edge technologies readily accessible to participating scientists. We expect to identify and target key mediators of brain metastasis, with therapeutic benefit for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Metastatic breast cancer and relapse following therapy are dependent on (1) development of intrinsic resistance to targeted and endocrine therapies, and (2) resistance to recognition and destruction of cancer cells by the immune system. The Stanford Breast Metastasis Center (SBMC) is focused on (1) quantifying the timing of metastatic dissemination in breast cancer (2) functionally delineating the contribution of cellular and microenvironmental crosstalk on metastatic proclivity, and (3) characterizing the mechanisms of responses by metastatic cells to therapies. To achieve these goals, we harness an integrated systems biology, functional genomic and evolutionary dynamic approach applied to longitudinal breast cancer tissue cohorts and patient- derived organoid models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall Section  This proposal focuses on elucidating the genomic and microenvironmental determinants, and temporal dynamics underlying efficacy of radiation-based combination therapies. We will use an innovative molecular characterization trial testing radiation plus antibody-drug conjugate in bladder cancer and radiation plus immunotherapy in head and neck cancer to characterize the mechanistic drivers underlying these next generation RT-based therapies. Our studies will help build a foundation to optimize multimodal, radiation- based definitive treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Children’s Oncology Group (COG) is the world’s largest organization devoted exclusively to childhood and adolescent cancer research with more than 9,000 members at over 220 leading children’s hospitals, universities, and cancer centers across the U.S., Canada and other countries. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients experience dramatic quadriceps strength loss after total knee replacement, which contributes to persistent weakness and reduced long-term function after surgery. Neuromuscular electrical stimulation reduces quadriceps weakness and improves patient function after knee replacement, but it is drastically underused in rehabilitation practice. This randomized trial will examine the effectiveness and feasibility of a comprehensive strategy for implementing neuromuscular electrical stimulation after knee replacement in two large healthcare organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal investigates whether enhancement in insulin action by six months of either high-intensity aerobic and resistance exercise training improves various measures of brain functions and brain-muscle connections, potentially explaining the improvement of cognition in people with insulin resistance. Insulin resistance is a condition in diabetes, obesity, and aging where insulin action is low and is associated with significantly higher prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias. These studies based on high-technology brain imaging and functional measurements in combination with cognitive function are anticipated to reveal novel insights on how exercise training prevents dementia in people with insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The human reference pangenome, which represents a collection of genome sequences in a single data structure, has the potential to transform human genetics applications. Here we will develop a web-based pangenome browser and a suite of command line tools to enable integrating existing pangenomes with other data sources including large biobanks for complex traits analysis and other applications. All software will be made widely available to accelerate the use of pangenomes by the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Title: Artificial Intelligence for effective communication to promote vaping cessation on social media The proposed study will identify key features of e-cigarette-related social media (Twitter/X, Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube) posts associated with high user engagement (such as the number of likes) by leveraging cutting- edge artificial intelligence, including but not limited to natural language processing techniques and deep learning models, along with advanced statistical modeling techniques. Furthermore, we will conduct cross-sectional anonymous online surveys and semi-structured interview studies to verify the key features contributing to high user engagement and, more importantly, identify features targeting specific populations. The identified key features will be valuable for designing multimedia messages (text, image, and video) that effectively promote vaping cessation, especially among youth, young adults, and other disadvantaged groups.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal placental development in pregnant individuals with obesity and diabetes contributes to miscarriage, preeclampsia, and stillbirth that are all major public health concerns. This study will determine how glucose and glutamine signaling in mitochondria regulate placental development. Defining how nutrient availability affects placental health will inform novel strategies for improving outcomes in pregnancies complicated by obesity and diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Two major risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease are elevated brain Fe levels and low socioeconomic status (SES) communities experiencing uncontrollable, poverty-associated stressors. Air pollution, and associated Fe contamination, are higher in low SES communities, subjecting these populations to two major risk factors for cognitive decline. The current grant proposes to evaluate the effects of inhaled Fe, at different concentrations and in stress vs. resilience-inducing contexts, to advance our mechanistic understanding of how co-occurring environmental stressors, with shared biological consequences, can converge to enhance or mitigate risk for memory loss and Alzheimer’s Disease.

PHR: Project Narrative: The copper oxygenases and oxidases play key roles in natural product biosynthesis1, 2, neurotransmitter3, 4, and neuropeptide hormone regulation5, 6, iron metabolism7, 8, and biological energy transduction.9-11 Experimentally elucidating their actual mechanisms and how Nature controls their reactivities is both of fundamental importance and has downstream applications in controlling neurological disorders12-15, understanding melanogenesis in human diseases and agricultural applications16-18, the design of new biocatalysts19, 20, and second sphere control into homogenous21, 22 and heterogenous catalysts23-25, and in the development of new biofuel cells26, 27, including wearable devices.28

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite there being ~294,000 individuals with SCI nationwide and ~17,810 new cases each year, we still lack an effective therapeutic that can significantly restore functions that are lost. This study addresses the urgent need to develop SCI therapeutics by further exploring and optimizing a promising and new potential treatment strategy called optogenetic spinal stimulation. By adjusting the number of stimulation sessions, combining stimulation with an axon growth-enhancing peptide, and assessing the resulting circuitry changes, we will be critical-steps closer to a treatment for spinal injuries of varying magnitudes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The ARTEMIS project will establish an advisory panel to engage individuals who have lived experience with polysubstance drug use and reside in rural communities, a markedly under resourced and high-risk focal population. The team will utilize and leverage patient insights to help identify and address barriers to treatment as well as gaps in systems of service delivery to improve access and engagement. This panel will serve as a resource to support providers and researchers in integrating patient perspectives with the treatment and study of substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to assess the role of cost-associated barriers to new and future novel AD/ADRD therapeutics in Hispanic or Latino people. To do this, we will engage both a cohort of Latino adults created as part of the team’s ongoing work on diversity in clinical trials and an existing group of Latino patients with AD/ADRD and their caregivers. Our work in the first (planning) phase of the project will include semi-structured interviews and a population-based survey to understand knowledge of and barriers to new novel AD therapeutics. The second stage of our work will analyze existing Medicare claims and Encounter data to understand actual use patterns. We will then use the team’s well-established dynamic microsimulation to estimate the downstream impacts of use on cognitive and physical health, costs, and quality of life of older Hispanic or Latino adults with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance The proposed experiments will determine the neural mechanisms of gait and cognitive-motor interactions in individuals with subjective cognitive decline. Gait speed slows in this population before cognitive declines appear; therefore, a greater understanding of how neural control of walking differs in subjective cognitive decline relative to typical aging will lead to new interventions and early biomarkers for impending declines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Intratelencephalic (IT) neurons are thought to underlie human cognition and show specific disruption in neurodevelopmental disorders; however, little is known about the genetics and axon projection patterns of different IT neuron subtypes and their alterations in disease. This proposal seeks to utilize novel genetic mouse lines, axon tracing techniques, and cutting-edge transcriptomic profiling to understand the changes in gene expression and axon projections of two specific IT neuron subtypes after perinatal hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), a common brain injury in term babies that results in neurodevelopmental symptoms. These experiments will help us understand the detailed pathology of HIE in the brain and generate candidate targets for future cell-specific therapies to precisely ameliorate the developmental symptoms of HIE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant for public health as it evaluates the mechanisms underlying opioid use dis- order treatment benefit while also testing a novel pharmacological treatment for insomnia, a common comor- bidity among individuals receiving addiction treatment. The goal of this project is to take critical initial steps to uncover the neurofunctional mechanisms engaged by the orexin system in the brain that regulates sleep, re- ward and stress responses. Project findings will advance the development of novel therapeutics in the ongoing overdose crisis for individuals seeking recovery from opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Environmental heat and socioeconomic stressors are expected to exacerbate health inequities in persons with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementia (AD/ADRD). By uncovering the link between environmental heat, socioeconomic disparities, and stroke outcomes, we aim to provide actionable insights that can guide public health policies. Targeting new stroke prevention strategies in heat vulnerable neighborhoods is a more efficient public health approach to improve resilience of vulnerable communities and reduce health inequities in the AD/ADRD population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study aligns closely with several strategies under Goal 2 of the National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s Disease. It addresses issues on the role of healthcare financing and policies on health outcomes, utilization and disparities which are the highest-priority areas for NIH. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Horizontal gene transfer through mobile genetic elements drives the adaptive evolution of bacterial pathogens and contributes significantly to the spread of pathogenic properties throughout bacterial communities. We recently discovered an integrative and conjugative element (a type of mobile element that is transferred from cell to cell via conjugation) on the genome of the oral pathogen Streptococcus mutans. In this project, we will investigate fundamental aspects of the element’s biology and its influence on S. mutans pathogenesis, including the signals that govern this transfer, interactions with other mobile genetic elements and bacterial defense systems, and elemental mechanisms that may ultimately harm the host bacterial cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Inherited mutations in mitochondrial genes cause multiple devastating neuromuscular diseases that have no FDA-approved therapies. Here, we are investigating whether correcting a common biochemical consequence of mitochondrial diseases, known as “NADH-reductive stress”, using our novel enzyme tool named LOXCAT, has therapeutic benefits. Our proposal will pave the way for novel therapies for various incurable mitochondrial diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVES Our goal is to investigate socioeconomic, clinical, imaging, and biological aspects, such as genetic, epigenetic, and transcriptomic/proteomic features that influence the lower survival rate of Oral cavity Squamous Cell Carcinoma (OSCC) patients of African ancestry (AA) compared to those of European ancestry (EA). We will identify the unique characteristics of AA-OSCC and functionally examine the potential therapeutic targets and pathways that are activated in AA-OSCC. Our research will enhance the understanding of the causes of disparities, identify biomarkers that can detect the high-risk group, predict treatment response and survival, and propose novel treatment strategies for AA-OSCC, which could lead to better outcomes and reduced disparities in this neglected population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Muscular dystrophy is a debilitating genetic disorder characterized by progressive loss of muscle function. There is currently no cure and the only effective therapy to delay functional loss is glucocorticoid steroid therapy. The proposed project will investigate a novel mechanism of ribosome specialization as a contributor to the pathogenesis of muscular dystrophy with the aim of developing additional therapies for the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For curatively treated hormone receptor positive breast cancer, taking 5-10 years of a daily oral endocrine therapy such as tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor cuts the risk of breast cancer recurrence nearly in half, yet nearly half of women taking endocrine therapy to prevent breast cancer recurrence do not meet minimum thresholds for adherence, often due to symptoms. We propose to test whether oncology teams can improve long-term oral oncologic medication adherence through better symptom monitoring and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective structural and policy solutions are needed to reduce and eliminate disparities, and these must address the historical, cultural, political and institutional influences that restrict access to resources and quality health for minoritized communities. Community-led health structural interventions (CHESIs) are essential in addressing complex structural drivers of health disparities, however research in this area is often negatively impacted by limited resources, and fraught, superficial relationships with academic partners. To tackle these problems, the SHHare Community Project: The Shared Hub for Health Action Research and Equity in Community-led Interventions at NYU Langone Health (NYULH) will use a community-based participatory research approach to support and ensure the independence of assigned CHESIs by establishing robust, complementary units that ensure CHESIs can successfully implement broader structural change that shift paradigms about community-led solutions to ensure measurable gains in health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Syphilis is an important cause of stillbirth, neonatal death, and preterm delivery, but there is currently no molecular diagnostic test for congenital syphilis in routine clinical use. We aim to optimize clinical use of a molecular PCR test for detection of T. pallidum DNA in the context of comprehensive assessment of maternal stage, treatment history and neonatal evaluation. We have assembled an outstanding team with complementary expertise and access to a population with high prevalence of maternal and congenital syphilis to accomplish the aims of the study and advance the field of syphilis diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative Candida albicans is a fungus that causes oropharyngeal candidiasis (thrush) in some people but is tolerated without symptoms in the mouth and gut in most healthy individuals. Salivary Histatin 5 (Hst 5) is an abundant zinc-binding antifungal peptide that effectively kills C. albicans without zinc but produces of C. albicans survivor cells with a commensal phenotype when complexed with zinc. We will examine how zinc-Hst 5 complex induced changes to C. albicans (survivor cells) alter their susceptibility to antifungal drugs, interactions with interspecies mucosal binding partners, and dampen inflammatory signaling in the oral mucosa to understand how Zn-Hst 5 modulates fungal commensalism with the goal of tuning the activity of Hst 5 by therapeutic changes in salivary zinc levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This R50 award will support the research specialist Dr. Richard Bennett to lead research teams and perform key experiments to accomplish the aims of the Dr. Licht’s three NCI-funded R01 awards: R01CA266078 (Histone fold Mutations in Cancer Pathogenesis), multi-PI R01CA256193 (Characterization and targeting of the epigenetic state underlying uveal melanoma liver metastasis) and multi-PI R01CA262483 (Defining and targeting epigenetic plasticity-driven drug resistance and immune escape in melanoma). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because severe lung disease (LD) is an emerging, potentially life-threatening complication of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (SJIA) that frequently progresses to hypoxic respiratory failure. The proposed clinical/observational study represents a needed longitudinal assessment to address key barriers to research in SJIA-LD, including accurate definitions of cases and clinical disease progression, surrogate biomarkers of disease, and lack of LD-specific patient-reported outcomes (PROs). The project is relevant to NIH’s mission to apply knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability through developing urgently needed tools that are essential to accelerate future clinical research, including interventional studies, in SJIA-LD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is amongst the most lethal forms of cancer because it can escape the immune system. Results from a series of human clinical trials where we used interleukin 12 immunogene therapy alone or combined with immune checkpoint inhibitors to improve anticancer immunity now prompt us to explore how to improve Interleukin 12 gene therapy by altering the timing of immune checkpoint inhibitors or by blocking a different mechanism of GBM immune escape that relates to a novel long noncoding RNA. By figuring out which of these two approaches is more effective, additional clinical trials for GBM can be designed, informed by this grant proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative COVID-19 pandemic has killed more than 6.9 million people and caused the worst healthcare crisis of this century. While over 765 million have recovered from COVID-19, the large portion of the population experiences persistent symptoms four weeks after their acute illness; this phenomenon is called post COVID-19, which is a long-term outcome associated with decreased lung function and major morbidity. A significant portion of patients who have suffered from COVID-19 are at risk for developing pulmonary fibrosis but there is no mechanism available to predict post COVID-19 pulmonary fibrosis at early stages. Therefore, the goal of this project is to develop and validate methods to predict patients at most risk for development of post COVID-19 pulmonary fibrosis with novel explainable deep learning algorithms on combined imaging and electronic health record (EHR) data from multiple centers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ScreenPlus is a comprehensive, fluid, pilot newborn screening program that will screen at least 100,000 consented infants for specific disorders in order to determine disease incidence in a diverse population while defining the analytic and clinical validity of multi-tiered, multiplexed screening assays. Longitudinal clinical data will be collected from infants identified through the program in order to provide evidence about the potential benefit of NBS on outcome, while also documenting the natural history of pre-symptomatic disease. Finally, the ethical, legal, and social issues associated with expanded newborn screening will be explored.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Enrollment in Medicare Advantage, the managed care alternative to Traditional Medicare, covers nearly half of Medicare beneficiaries and disproportionately enrolls minorities and low-income beneficiaries. Managed care could improve the care of patients with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) through care coordination and supplemental benefits, though regulators have raised concerns about inappropriate denials of care relative to Traditional Medicare. This project considers whether Medicare Advantage impacts potentially preventable hospitalizations, discharges without home or facility based care, transitions across sites of care, racial, ethnic, and income disparities in care, and intergenerational transfers of time and money among Medicare beneficiaries with ADRD and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA UNIV OF HEALTH SCIS
PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposed research is germane to public health because it is expected to employ health system relevant outcome measures to assess the impact of the decision by Medicare to cover a guideline-concordant non-pharmacologic treatment for chronic low back pain. The project is relevant to the mission of the National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health because it will evaluate a complementary and integrative healthcare intervention for management of Medicare patients with chronic low back pain, a population that tends to be comorbid, difficult to manage, and at risk for adverse effects of pharmacologic interventions. This project is expected to foster interdisciplinary collaborations and partnerships as it produces new evidence for the non-pharmacologic management of chronic low back pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We will study how individually mild mutations, acting within regulatory genomic sequences, act to influence the risk and progression of common genetic diseases. Here, we propose to define potential regulatory sequences in neurons that are preferentially affected in Parkinson disease (PD), evaluating how the use of different subsets of regulatory sequences are altered by age and disease-causing, experimental treatments. We will use this information to study (computationally and experimentally) the identity, DNA sequence, and biological necessity of gene control regions, as well as the impact of mutations that may disrupt them in disease – illuminating how they contribute to the molecular mechanisms underlying PD risk and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Heart failure is a leading cause of death worldwide. Pathological cardiac remodeling in response to hypertension induces the activation of Rps6kb1 in cardiomyocytes, of which precise roles and mechanisms-of- action are elusive. Experiments laid out here will focus on two novel post-translational modifications of Rps6kb1 in pressure overload-induced cardiomyopathy and heart failure, which may provide new insights for our understanding of hypertensive heart disease and shed light on novel therapeutic approaches.
