IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health behavior interventions introduced into social networks have the potential to efficiently improve population health by benefitting not just intervention recipients, but also those influenced by intervention recipients. However, the complex dynamics of social networks make it hard to predict the types of networks and network interventions where this approach will be most impactful, particularly for adults in midlife whose social networks are understudied. The current project will use simulation analyses based on real-world data from a workplace social network to identify the intervention strategies and network characteristics that yield the most positive, equitable, and cost-effective impact on health behavior outcomes for midlife adults.

PHR: This study is about understanding how environmental stress plays a role in the risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD), caused by excessive alcohol consumption, is a cause of rising liver- related mortality in the United States, yet we lack even one approved therapy. We propose an innovative platform to explore fundamental aspects of ALD pathogenies, the contribution of gut endotoxins, and understand how a genetic risk factor influences disease development and progression. These studies will provide new insights to inform development of effective diagnostics and treatments that can improve the lives of both patients and those at risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Biomarkers can provide us with powerful tools for the prediction, diagnosis, prognosis, and ultimately prevention, of age-related diseases. Until now we have lacked good model systems to understand the mechanisms behind so-called “biological clocks”, which have become very popular biomarkers of aging. Using the fruit fly as a powerful experimental system, we develop a new kind of biological clock based on measures of metabolites— the molecular building blocks found in all species—and use this novel clock to better understand aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE  This longitudinal study aims to determine the temporal relationship between concussion and persistent psychological problems in adolescent concussion and further examine if changes in pubertal hormones and/or MRI abnormalities detected in midline brain regions within the first week of injury or three months later mediate this relationship.  Such findings have the potential to move a step toward the identification of objective targets for future research in personalized intervention strategies, designed to modulate hormone-dependent mechanisms of brain plasticity in a sensitive period, and therefore more likely to be effective in reducing the psychiatric morbidity of concussed adolescents later in life.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The physiological and molecular mechanisms of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)-induced vascular senescence leading to vascular dysfunction remain to be elucidated. Transgenic mouse models enable the detection and selective ablation of cells expressing p16, a known marker of cellular senescence. These models will be exposed to Intermittent Hypoxia and Sleep Fragmentation to investigate aorta and coronary artery function, epigenetic age acceleration and molecular alterations induced by OSA in cardiovascular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Newly identified findings that disabling cardiac fibroblast by p38 deficiency corrects the dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) phenotype in mice expressing a sarcomeric variant demonstrates fibroblasts play an unequivocal role in early-stage DCM pathogenesis. In the DCM setting cardiac fibroblasts adaptively responded to the sarcomeric variant by proliferating but failed to undergo canonical activated state transitions, which resulted in myocardial anisotropy and stiffness albeit without conventional fibrosis. Understanding the underlying determinants of adaptive cardiac fibroblast responses, what mechanical property of the heart the fibroblast response is trying to correct, and whether therapies for inherited DCM will need to target fibroblast-dependent processes is vital to overcoming current limitations with standard-of-care and first-in-class muscle cell-specific interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite tremendous progress in improving the quality of orthopaedic trauma research over the past decades, poor outcomes remain unacceptably common in this patient population. The adaptive platform trial design has emerged as a highly efficient alternative to the conventional randomized clinical trial design, allowing multiple interventions to be simultaneously compared with sample sizes adapted to yield clinically actionable inferences. We propose an 18-month planning period to support the pre-trial simulations, document development, and trial structure to initiate a comparative effectiveness adaptive platform trial aimed at improving patient-important outcomes of patients 65 years or older with a lower extremity fracture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses critical fiscal and administrative barriers to substantially strengthen the infrastructure and impact of the SENSE Network, an international, collaborative scientific group that is a nexus for scientific interaction and interdisciplinary collaborations in sensory aging, a field connecting sensory health and gerontology, including the influence of sensory health on Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). The data, research and dissemination infrastructure created as part of this project will foster diversity, increase the pace of innovation and discovery, facilitate the development of interventions, and catalyze translation of innovative research to clinical care and policy. By accelerating and potentiating the impact of siloed researchers, data sets, and projects, the SENSE Network is poised to take a leading role in the field of sensory aging research, advancing science of aging through in-depth interdisciplinary partnerships and collaborations to positively impact the health of older adults in the U.S. and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative On average, rural Americans die younger and spend more of their lives in poor health than their urban peers – disparities that have been growing for the past 40 years. However, rural places are not all the same, and while some rural areas face significant challenges related to living long and healthy lives, others are thriving and may offer lessons that can improve health and longevity in struggling rural communities. The Interdisciplinary Network on Rural Population Health and Aging (INRPHA) brings together scholars from multiple disciplines, institutions, and topical interests to advance knowledge on the complex factors affecting the health and wellbeing of rural working-age and older adults through various activities, including: regular meetings, workshops, and working groups; pilot grants to stimulate new research; mentoring of junior scholars; and dissemination of findings to academic, policy, and public audiences through presentations, academic publications, public research briefs, and more.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed mixed-methods study will investigate the growing crisis of injection-related wounds and skin and soft tissue infections among people who inject drugs (PWID) in the Appalachian foothills of North Carolina. Knowledge gained from this study will help identify xylazine prevalence in the Illicit drug supply and characterize the etiology and unique features of novel and severe wounds and other IWSSTIs by Drug, Set, and Setting (DSS) risk factors. Because the sharp growth in both xylazine exposure and IWSSTIs among PWID comprise an emerging health crisis, these data are time sensitive, and the proposed study is poised to make a timely and effective contribution to public health response.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While almost 40% of children in the US are exposed to harmful environmental tobacco smoke, which is associated with poorer pediatric mental health outcomes, rising poly-use of combustible cigarettes, electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) and combustible cannabis products among reproductive-aged adults could be intensifying environmental harms posed to pediatric mental health. Despite evolving risks, minimal data exists on the combined impact of these environmental smoke and vapor exposures across child development. To inform interventions and policies safeguarding children, this study will describe how cumulative exposure to emissions from combustible tobacco, ENDS, and combustible cannabis products from the prenatal period to adolescence shapes mental health trajectories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed studies will examine the role of the innate immune system in the development and/or exacerbation of salt-sensitive hypertension. The studies will specifically address the role of myeloid cyclooxygenase-2/PGE2 in mediation of alterations of effector T cells, in mediation of altered responses to a high salt diet. The studies will determine alterations in sodium handling by the kidney and investigate potential mechanisms by which macrophage and/or dendritic cells mediate alterations in T cell responses to a high salt diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our ultimate goal is to develop a practical (translational), theranostic platform for managing prostate cancer. We will leverage our expertise with prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) and in the development of multi-functional dendrimers for imaging and therapy. A key innovation is the addition of magnetic resonance imaging, a clinically ubiquitous modality, using chemical exchange saturation transfer (CEST) – avoiding potential toxicity due to gadolinium administration – for pharmacokinetic analysis of our agents and therapeutic monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This proposed study is aligned with the Human Resources and Service Administration’s Ending the HIV Epidemic proposal to reduce HIV incidence by 75% in 5 years and 90% in 10 years. The objective of this study is to adapt a previously developed mHealth platform to improve the successful use of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV among Black adolescents and young adults living in both rural and urban areas within the Alabama by strengthening social support from trusted adults. Success of this mHealth platform also has the potential to build support systems that further empower adolescents and young adults with HIV prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Latina adolescents report high rates of inactivity and are at especially high lifetime risk for diabetes, obesity, and other lifestyle-related conditions. The proposed study seeks to adapt an existing physical activity intervention for Latina girls, Chicas Fuertes, and test its effectiveness and implementation potential as an external referral program for Federally Qualified Health Centers. It will build a foundation for broad implementation, using existing clinical systems and widespread technologies to shift health behaviors across the life course and promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) are the most lethal type of DNA damage, since unrepaired DSBs lead to genomic instability and tumorigenesis. We have identified NUDT16 protein as a novel regulator of the DNA repair pathways. The proposed studies will elucidate the coordination of different DNA repair pathways and uncover key components in these pathways that we can explore to improve cancer therapy and overcome therapeutic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, there are no effective therapies to promote kidney repair following acute kidney injury. Consequently, many patients develop chronic kidney disease and other long-term risks including cardiovascular events and reduced quality of life. By investigating the mechanistic basis and therapeutic potential of endothelial hypoxia-induced glycolysis/MCT4 axis in post-ischemic kidney repair, our studies will stimulate new areas for experimental therapeutics in AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Effective response to the overdose crisis requires rigorously conducted scientific investigations, with a specific focus on criminal legal system, to identify interventions, strategies and approaches that are efficient, feasible, scalable, and sustainable. Phase I of the Justice Community Overdose Innovation Network (JCOIN) created under the NIDA HEAL initiative funded a series of investigations targeting key stages of the substance use treatment continuum as people with substance use disorders interact with the criminal legal system. Together with the new research hubs that will be identified during JCOIN Phase II, these studies will generate a large amount of rich data from the most vulnerable populations in the U.S. opening opportunities for analyses beyond the primary study aims to maximize the impact of investment into scientific research – one of the primary foci of the Methodology and Advanced Analytics Resource Center (MAARC).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: DIVERSITY SUPPLEMENT PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual minority young adults are at elevated risk for alcohol use and alcohol misuse. High quantity and frequent alcohol use and alcohol misuse are robustly associated with increased oxidative stress, and these alcohol- biology associations are strong predictors of various physical and psychological health conditions and substantially contribute to mortality. The proposed work for this supplement seeks to evaluate the adverse health consequences of alcohol use and alcohol misuse on oxidative stress among sexual minority young adults across sociodemographic subgroups who are known to vary in elevated risk for alcohol use and alcohol misuse but are under-represented in biological studies of health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The impetus for the ComPASS Program is the increasing recognition that advancing health equity is a complex challenge that extends beyond the reach of traditional healthcare settings, organizations, or research agendas. This NIH-wide program was created to foster efforts to address structural causes and pathways of differential health outcomes, with the goal of reducing health disparities across diseases and conditions among populations that experience them. The proposed SEACHANGE Hub would participate as one of five hubs in a program that also includes 25 Community-led, Health Equity Structural Intervention (CHESI) projects throughout the U.S. and one Coordinating Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL PPG  Addiction remains one of the world’s greatest public health problems, yet its pathophysiology remains incompletely understood and available treatments for addictions to various drugs of abuse are inadequately effective for most people. This new Program Project Grant, focused on mechanisms of transcriptional and chromatin regulation on a cell type-specific basis, will contribute to a better understanding of the neurobiological basis of addiction, which we believe is necessary for the eventual development of definitive treatments and cures for substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: OVERVIEW: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite a strong evidence base for diabetes prevention and care, significant gaps remain in equitably translating these research findings into real life policy and practice; the overall burdens and costs continue to grow rapidly, with the minorities and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups in the Southeastern U.S. disproportionately affected. To address these gaps, we propose the Georgia Center for Diabetes Translation Research (GCDTR) with the vision of promoting equity through high-quality translation research and a culture of evidence based decision-making across academic, health system, community, and local government partners in Georgia, Florida, and Tennessee. GCDTR will serve as a platform to increase investigator capacity, share expertise, and generate and disseminate knowledge to influence practice and policy to improve diabetes outcomes and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health In this proposal, we will test a new technology, called HRT, that will allow for substantial reduction in the amount of therapy needed to safely and effectively treat cardiomyopathy. We will also test whether HRT works particularly well in the hearts of mice with Friedreich’s ataxia (FA). This technology will allow us to create a safer gene therapy for FA patients and potentially eliminate heart deterioration and improve lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of older adults involved in the criminal legal system (“justice-involved older adults”) has risen dramatically in recent decades, resulting in a growing population of older adults with profound, often co- occurring social and medical vulnerabilities and high rates of health disparities. We launched the ARCH (Aging Research in Criminal Justice Health) Network in 2019 a nationwide, multi-disciplinary community of emerging and established researchers, to catalyze research and interventions designed to improve health and social outcomes in the growing population of criminal justice-involved older adults. This proposal will further develop and sustain The ARCH Network to support emerging and established investigators to advance the conduct and dissemination of research on the health and social drivers of criminal legal system involvement and its consequences on health in later life and to accelerate the translation of this research into practice and policy that can care for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is the leading cause of death in an increasingly aged population in the United States. Personalized medicine based on patient-specific, disease-state relevant dynamic information holds great promise in revolutionizing the standard of care for cancer. Using acute myeloid leukemia as a proof-of-concept, the goal of this research is to develop and apply state-transition based mathematical modeling to predict individual therapy response and to design adaptive therapeutic approaches to ultimately advance personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Parent Grant: R01MD016465– Video-based Intervention to Reduce Treatment and Outcome Disparities in Adults Living with Stroke or Transient Ischemic Attack (VIRTUAL) Principal Investigator: Anjail Z. Sharrief, MD, MPH Type of Administrative Supplement: Diversity Level of Supplement Requested: Investigator Proposed Period of Support: February 1, 2024-January 31, 2026 A. PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research supplement will improve our understanding of barriers and facilitators to the use of telemedicine among a group of racially, ethnically, economically, and geographically diverse population of stroke survivors. In addition, it will improve our understanding of the relationship between digital health literacy and a variety of process, clinical, and patient reported outcomes. This information will lay the foundation for further research and development of interventions aimed at increasing the utilization of telehealth services in stroke survivors which may improve stroke disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Bacteria contain proteins that pump out antibiotics. During antibiotic treatment, nearly one-third of bacteria involved in infections increase the number of pumps to gain antibiotic resistance. We aim to understand how these pumps work by looking at them directly in the bacteria using state-of-the-art cryo-electron microscopy. If we can understand how they assemble and what they look like, we hope to help design new drugs to block the pumps and prevent antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Stressful life events contribute to the onset of cardiovascular disease, which is the leading cause of death in the United States. This project investigates whether the activity of neurons residing within discrete portions of the nervous system promotes resiliency or susceptibility to stress. Completion of the research may guide the development of novel therapeutics that relieve stress and alleviate cardiovascular disease.

PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Defect in trophoblast lineage development results in early pregnancy loss or leads to pregnancies that are associated with pre-term birth, intrauterine growth restriction and preeclampsia, which cause serious adverse effects on maternal and infant health. PHR: PMCSR serves as the backbone for diverse research initiatives, highlighted by the utilization of over 200 laboratories engaged in basic, clinical, and translational research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Suffering from both the sensory and affective components of chronic pain continues to be a major burden on quality of life and economies in the US and around the world. Pain and depression are often comorbid, and the lateral habenula is a brain region that has recently been implicated in both. While most studies have focused on the inputs to the lateral habenula, here we propose to investigate which brain region(s) receive output from the lateral habenula to modulate sensory and affective behavioral responses in models of chronic pain and depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current syphilis detection methods, especially serological ones, are typically laboratory-based, require a secondary confirmatory assay to reach adequate sensitivity and specificity, and are characterized by challenges that prevent clinicians from obtaining immediate and definitive test results for effective treatment decisions before the patient leaves the clinic. Our multiplexed MagChipTM genital ulcer disease assay and MagChipRTM analyzer will provide one of the first commercially available POC NAAT solutions that will enable untrained users in CLIA-waived settings to discriminate syphilitic ulcers from ulcers caused by other ulcerative diseases. In addition, NAATs currently lack sensitivity outside of primary genital lesions – our robust MagChip chemistry is compatible with multiple sample types, which we will leverage in an innovative clinical study, pooling multiple sample types from the same patient to enhance the sensitivity of our MagChip T. pallidum assay for diagnosing secondary, latent, and congenital syphilis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This RC2 consortium will develop a consensus view of intestinal repair and regeneration across diverse injury models in both mouse and human systems, identifying common and unique regenerative programs that are active in different injury contexts. We will functionally interrogate regenerative programs and identify molecular mediators and drugs that can induce a regenerative state. This work will lead to a deep understanding of gut repair and lay the foundation for new fields of research and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regular aerobic exercise is associated with a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease and Alzehimer's disease and its related dementias, due in part to improving vascular health in the peripheral circulation and the brain. Although regular aerobic exercise has been shown to improve vascular health in middle-age/older men it has not consistently improved vascular health in postmenopausal women. The proposed studies will test whether age and sex differences in the underlying biology of vascular aging and molecular transducers with acute and chronic aerobic exercise mediates exercise response variation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is a systematic analysis of how the burden of heart failure varies within the United States and how public health and clinical interventions are likely to impact future disease trends in each U.S. state. The project will build on the data and computational infrastructure of the Global Burden of Disease Study to: a) estimate the burden of heart failure for each U.S. county and for each U.S. state forecast that burden to 2060 with stratification by age, sex, ejection factor, race/ethnicity, rurality/urbanicity b) assess the strength of evidence for modifiable risk factors for heart failure and their role in causing current burden, and c) develop new heart failure policy simulations that allow each state to examine the local impact of interventions that can prevent or reduce the burden of heart failure for their population. The results of this project will provide new evidence on the impact of interventions tailored to each U.S. state, allowing policymakers to improve their selection of policies that can reduce geographic health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most measures of U.S. adult health and longevity lag well behind those of other wealthy countries, particularly for U.S. women, middle-aged adults, racial and ethnic minorities, and areas in the South and Midwest. Explaining this growing U.S. disadvantage necessitates large-scale, coordinated research and data development activities across disciplines. This Network will bring together scientists across disciplines to collectively investigate the U.S. crisis, provide training for Network scientists, and disseminate resources and research to inform decision- makers and improve the health and longevity of the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schistosomiasis is a neglected tropical parasitic disease with ongoing efforts to achieve elimination as a public health problem through a strategy of mass drug administration. Yet how to efficiently identify focal geographic areas of Schistosoma endemicity and hot spots of high prevalence to inform targeted mass drug administration is limited. The proposed research aims to determine whether more geographically precise mapping with newer rapid urine antigen diagnostics in a sample pooling approach for targeted mass drug administration can improve schistosomiasis control efforts and be cost-effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because elucidation of the molecular basis of neogenin and matriptase-2 in the regulation of hepcidin expression is ultimately expected to increase understanding of the pathogenesis of iron overload disorders and iron-restricted anemia in humans. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help understand and treat disorders of iron metabolism including hemochromatosis and anemia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Most individuals with Fragile X syndrome (FXS) and people with autism experience troublesome hypersensitivity to touch, which leads to avoidance responses, but how this affects social interactions is not known. This project investigates social touch in a mouse model of FXS and in the maternal immune activation mouse model of sporadic autism using an innovative behavioral assay. We hope to identify the circuit changes that lead to avoidance to unwanted social touch, and plan to conduct preclinical studies to test whether certain drugs that act on circuits can ameliorate these deficits in autism mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rotator cuff tendinopathy is a common problem. Resistance exercise is a known effective treatment, but not everyone benefits and little is known about the tendon healing response with exercise. In this project, we will track changes in the tendon, outcomes and associated factors to develop a patient-specific exercise approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Engineered T cells are emerging as promising anti-cancer therapeutic agents, but still show limited efficacy against solid tumors, as they rapidly become ‘exhausted’ due to chronic stimulation by tumor cells. Here we engineer a synthetic signaling feedback circuit that tempers excessive stimulation to boost anti-tumor T cell function. If successful, this synthetic circuit could form the basis for new therapies against solid tumors.

PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias are common, devastating and incurable disorders. The protein alpha-  synuclein  commonly  aggregates  in  these  diseases.  Here,  in  patient  stem- cell  models  and  brain  tissue,  we   thoroughly  investigate  the  mechanisms  through  which  this  protein  aggregates  with  a  view  to  developing  new  understanding and therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following epilepsy surgery, roughly half of patients will continue to have seizures, and 70-90% will remain on anti-seizure medications. Using data recorded from the brains of epilepsy patients, we propose to develop and validate computerized tools to accurately and objectively identify epileptic brain regions. This will improve surgical decision making, make epilepsy surgery available to more patients, and ultimately improve the lives of patients with the most severe types of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This study characterizes the tissue response and safety limits of electrical micro-stimulation in multiple non- neuronal brain cells over time. Electrical stimulation is being used to probe brain activity and also treat a wide- range of diseases (e.g. Parkinson’s disease). A state-of-the-art imaging approach is proposed to guide the use of stimulation to induce changes in brain activity, including progenitor proliferation and differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related declines in vascular function contribute to increased risk of cardiovascular diseases. This project will provide new insight into the mechanisms (reasons) by which a mitochondria-targeted antioxidant (MitoQ) may improve vascular endothelial function in older adults by determining the effects of changes in factors circulating in blood on endothelial cell function. Overall, this project will elucidate the beneficial effects of MitoQ supplementation on vascular function, which has implications for reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease with advancing age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Current studies suggest that mitochondrial lipids play a key role in neonatal ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury through regulation of programmed cell death. The proposed research aims to investigate the role of cardiolipin, a mitochondrial phospholipid, following I/R injury using advanced cyclic ion mobility mass spectrometry in addition to several transgenic mouse-lines. These experiments aim to build a better understanding of neonatal I/R injury, uncover novel molecular mechanisms, and reveal potential therapeutic targets within mitochondrial lipids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Clostridioides difficile is a spore-forming bacterium that infects 500,000 people annually in the U.S., leading to severe diarrhea and possible death. My goal is to understand the role of the nutrient-sensing protein CodY in preventing sporulation of C. difficile. Since C. difficile spores are the only means of transmission for this pathogen, understanding how spores form is essential for limiting transmission and infection by C. difficile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Beta-adrenergic stimulation is a key regulator of myofilament diastolic performance in the context of an increase in hemodynamic demand. This proposal focuses on hypertrophic cardiomyopathy mutations that are known to exhibit diastolic dysfunction and impaired responses to the phosphorylation event of Serine 23/24 in cTnI that occurs during beta-adrenergic stimulation. We propose in-silico–in-vitro experimental coupling in order to investigate structural, dynamics, and functional changes induced by phosphorylation and mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is an expansion of the aorta caused by the breakdown of structural proteins within the vessel wall. There are only surgical options for treating large AAAs that are at the highest risk of rupture, and currently no treatments for small AAA, which will become a high risk if ignored. The proposed research will investigate how a localized delivery system of stem cell secretions can stimulate restoration of structural proteins to pave the way for a new, non-invasive treatment of small AAAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Inflammation induced by the bacteria Streptococcus pyogenes is responsible for rapid disease progression, including necrotizing fasciitis and toxic shock syndrome, resulting in morbidity and mortality during invasive infections. My research will investigate host-pathogen interactions to understand how host inflammatory cell death increases S. pyogenes virulence at a genetic level. Understanding mechanisms that drive inflammation will help identify critical targets to correct protective immunity and stall disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In humans, mutations in a number of core ribosome components lead to ribosomopathies, including Diamond- Blackfan anemia (DBA), which is characterized by fatal bone marrow failure. In all of these cases, the mechanism(s) that would account for cell type specific changes in hematopoietic cells underlying these diseases remain poorly understood. Here, we propose to employ novel technologies to pinpoint how alterations in accurate control of translation causes bone marrow failure in these diseases and identify small molecules that activate translational control as a new targeted therapy for DBA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will establish A Longitudinal Study of Egyptian Healthy Aging (“AL-SEHA”) modeled after the US HRS and its sister surveys. Egypt with its large and diverse aging population will add new insights to the international network of harmonized aging studies by representing a population at the intersection of Mediterranean, Arab and African influences, a strongly SES-graded cognitive decline, a large gender divide for elder women, and looming challenges for older citizens due to global warming. AL-SEHA will collect from 20,000 individuals in Egypt aged 50 years and older a baseline and a first follow-up wave including a cognitive assessment, community module, geocoded and environmental data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to ameliorate dementia burden through identifying modifiable environmental risk factors. The project will utilize neurological examination and clinical diagnosis from the National Alzheimer’s Coordinating Center (NACC) Study and repository plasma samples from the National Centralized Repository for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (NCRAD), to determine the metal concentrations, and examine associations of these metals with dementia risk and longitudinal changes in related outcomes. In addition, the concepts learned through this grant and the career development pursued by the investigator, will be readily applicable to his future research focusing on the intersection of environmental epidemiology and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will develop new methods for studying the integration and function of hNPCs transplanted into the mouse brain, thereby providing critical mechanistic insights that will advance the field of stem cell transplantation as a therapy. Mice are one of the major mammalian model organisms for research on stem cell transplant therapy and many organizational principles of cell types and circuits are conserved across evolution, making them critical to understanding neurodegenerative and neurological disorders like Alzheimer’s Disease, Parkinson’s and stroke. This proposal will establish new experimental paradigms to investigate the cell and systems biology of stem-cell transplantation therapies and their functions, thus providing critical clues into why some stem cell strategies are successful and others are not.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A thorough understanding of PPC visual representation characteristics and their interactions with distraction in visual working memory (VWM) can help us better understand the various constraints and limitations of visual processing in VWM and general task performance. It can additionally help us formulate better treatment and rehabilitation plans to facilitate the recovery of PPC functions after lesion. Greater knowledge of PPC function can also provide guidance to the removal of possible PPC tissues due to epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Circulating Biomarker Core within the University of Wisconsin – Madison NCI-designated Carbone Cancer Center, led by Facility Manager Dr. Jennifer Schehr, provides centralized liquid biopsy method development, clinical trial sample processing, and assay preparation for regulatory approval for routine clinical use. Dr. Schehr leads the core’s innovative technological problem-solving with her extensive collaborative network leveraging her PhD in immunology, 2 years of FDA-approved assay development, and 9 years of custom liquid biopsy sample processing technology development, supporting 12 active clinical trials, 10 in development and 28 research projects involving 40 investigators, 22 NCI-designated cancer centers, and 10 other institutions. The services of the core aim to accelerate the process from discovery of promising new biomarkers to extensive evaluation for regulatory approval to provide more advanced predictive and pharmacodynamic biomarkers of resistance to clinicians and increase the efficiency of precision medicine approaches for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Accumulation of pro-inflammatory macrophages in the vessel wall is a hallmark observed in atherosclerosis, an effect that is markedly accelerated in diabetes. Our preliminary studies indicate that a novel macrophage-enriched long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) termed MERRICAL may act to control lesion formation within the vessel wall by regulating macrophage accumulation and pro-inflammatory signaling pathways. The proposed studies will provide a detailed understanding underlying the function of this lncRNA, its interactors, and how to leverage therapeutic manipulation of this lncRNA and its interactors with the goal of developing novel lncRNA-based therapies for the treatment of the accelerated atherosclerotic disease in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection that causes significant human disease throughout the world. New diagnostics that accurately detect the syphilis agent, early in disease, would greatly improve patient outcomes by accelerating access to potentially life-saving treatment. We have discovered that the bacterium that causes syphilis sheds unique pieces of its’ cell-wall into its environment as it grows. In this proposal we will develop a diagnostic tool that specifically detects these unusual, released cell wall fragments, and critically assess its performance in human syphilis patient samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The project will elucidate the structure of RDoC threat and reward domains across symptom, behavior, and brain units of analysis using data-driven analytics in a sample of 500 participants examined at two points. Moreover, the study will examine the extent to which various types of poverty-related adversities predict threat versus reward processes in a large, representative sample of young adults followed since birth and recruited from families living in poverty. The supplement will enable the aims of the study to be complete despite COVID challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By unraveling the molecular mechanism through which DNA replication fork protection determines oncogene- induced senescence and oncogenic transformation, this study will provide new insight into how disruption of replisome activity is linked to oncogene-induced replication stress and fork instability. Fundamental knowledge on the signal transduction pathways essential for this fail-safe tumor suppressive barrier will help develop a strategy that exploits the replication vulnerability of cancer cells as a new therapy and augment the effort to identify potential biomarkers relevant to DNA replication stress in cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative hERG1 is a voltage gated potassium channel that regulates cardiac function. We identified a subdomain of the hERG1 potassium channel, hERG1NP, that is targeted to the nuclei of immature cardiac cells. From the nucleus, the hERG1NP alters gene expression as well as hERG1 channel gating and expression. The approaches that we implement in this grant will define the mechanisms that regulate hERG1NP function and its impact on potassium channel activity and cell function, which will improve the accuracy of predicting the pathogenicity of hERG1NP variants and may inform future drug design targeting this channel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: In rare genetic heart disease, early identification of at-risk individuals is important so that disease may be prevented or treated in the patient, but these diseases are often underdiagnosed. In this study, we will use innovative artificial intelligence approaches on heart images and medical record data to identify patients who may have evidence of an undiagnosed rare genetic heart disease, with a focus on hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis. The results of this study could help create algorithms to identify undiagnosed diseases in patients and help guide them towards treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is to continue the ongoing Monitoring the Future (MTF) Panel study, which has surveyed new nationally representative samples of high school seniors every year since 1976 to track patterns and consequences of substance use and HIV/AIDS risk and protective behaviors. This application covers five new longitudinal data collections in 2023 through 2027 from national samples of adults ages 19 through 65 (approximately 120,000 people total). This application – the MTF Panel – is part of the integrated MTF study; a companion R01 application (the MTF Main) requests funding to continue (a) to collect annual nationally representative cross-sectional data from secondary school students, and (b) to analyze all cross-sectional and longitudinal data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to test whether a novel behavioral activation/problem solving based counseling intervention results in higher rates of smoking cessation than standard behavioral counseling among HIV+ smokers in Botswana. It will also assess whether changes in hypothesized mediators (depressive symptoms, use of substitute reinforcers and avoidance of complementary reinforcers of smoking behavior and problem solving skill) are the mechanisms behind successful quitting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Characterizing the genetic basis of plasma lipids has spurred many key paradigms for preventing coronary heart disease – biological insights, risk prediction, and medicines. Whole genome sequencing now offers the prospect of identifying all the potential genetic factors influencing lipids. The goal of this proposal is to surmount several methodological, analytical, and computational challenges to improve risk prediction and tailor preventive care as well as find new genes, which can be therapeutically targeted to efficiently reduce the risk for coronary heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposed research is to investigate the role of exosomes in cancer cell adhesion and migration, and extracellular matrix assembly, which are key events in cancer metastasis and tumor microenvironment maintenance. We will use a novel in vitro assay developed in the laboratory and state-of-the-art imaging techniques to determine the impact of exosome secretion from cancer cells as well as fibroblasts. This project is relevant to public health because it will lead to a greater understanding of the role of exosome secretion in tumor aggressiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with Chronic Pancreatitis (CP) and/or Recurrent Acute Pancreatitis (RAP) with Diabetes Mellitus (DM), referred to as CP-DM, have not been studied in prospective intervention trials to test efficacy and safety of anti- hyperglycemic medications. We will conduct a randomized, parallel group, dose escalation Pioglitazone versus Empagliflozin clinical trial in CP-DM (the PEP-DM) Trial lasting 24 weeks. The PEP-DM trial will serve as a precedent for a larger study of anti-hyperglycemic intervention to be conducted in CP-DM by the NIH funded consortium for chronic pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus and pancreatic cancer (CPDPC).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Advancing age is well-known risk factor for infection, sepsis, and multiple organ dysfunction following trauma and major surgical intervention. Impaired gut barrier function is the driving force for infection and systemic inflammatory response in many critical conditions. However, our current understanding of the mechanisms underlying the increased vulnerability to gut barrier dysfunction during aging remains poor and, as a result, effective therapies to preserve intestinal barrier integrity in older patients are limited. Studies proposed here will uncover novel mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of gut barrier dysfunction in elderly patients and will also establish a fundamental basis for developing new effective therapeutics to improve gut barrier integrity by targeting intestinal epithelial mitochondria via circHIPK3 and HuR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The use and abuse of prescription opioids in females of reproductive age has dramatically increased over the past two decades. One consequence of this escalated use has been an upsurge in the number of babies born with opioids in their bloodstream, many of whom develop neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. The goals of the current set of studies are to address this public health issue using a preclinical model of oxycodone self-administration in female rats which will allow us to investigate neurodevelopmental modifications and adult outcomes associated with maternal opioid intake.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The administration of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) targeted therapies to cancer patients invariably leads to the development of drug resistance, mainly caused by a mesenchymal-epithelial transition (MET) amplification. This innovative research project addresses this issue by rigorously developing smart transformable EGFR/MET-targeting peptide nanoparticles for treatment of cancers with acquired resistance to EGFR-targeted therapies due to MET amplification. The successful completion of this project will not only lead to the creation of new classes of safe and effective targeted nanotherapeutics against cancers but also open avenues for the advancement of functional nanomaterials in biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Salmonella is an important human pathogen and estimated by the CDC to cause more foodborne diseases than any other pathogen. Over one million estimated cases of Salmonella foodborne illnesses occur in the United States every year, with an economic burden of approximately $3.7 billion dollars per year. We will develop a method for measuring the molecular states of individual Salmonella cells during infection to devise new treatment strategies against Salmonella infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acamprosate and naltrexone are important medications used in the treatment of alcohol use disorder (AUD) but many AUD patients fail to respond to therapy with these drugs. We have used “Multiple Omics” (i.e., genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics) to identify biomarkers for acamprosate treatment response which we will now pursue to define underlying biological mechanisms. We will also study stem-cell (iPSC)- generated brain organoids derived from AUD patients treated with these drugs that will be exposed to acamprosate and naltrexone to identify additional biomarkers and pathways to help us understand mechanisms responsible for variation in response to these important AUD drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation-resistant prostate cancer (RR-PCa) is highly unpredictable which frequently results in cancer recurrence in many patients. This project aims to 1) establish the underlying mechanism(s) of mitochondrial biogenesis that contribute to RR-PCa cell survival and metabolism and 2) determine if targeting inherent mitochondria and radiation-acquired mitochondria, can overcome RR-PCa. The successful completion of this project will establish a new and significant therapeutic platform for making radiation therapy more effective.

PHR: Project Narrative Gynecological cancers with genetic alterations (e g. BRCA1/2 mutation, CCNE1 amplification, ARID1A mutation), provide opportunities for synthetic lethality approaches to cancer therapy. We have established a large library of gynecological cancer patient-derived xenograft and organoid models and now plan to expand to include rare tumor types. We plan to test new therapies that exploit genetic alterations with the ultimate goal of moving new therapies into the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ostechondritis dissecans (OCD) is a developmental orthopaedic disease affecting children and young adults. It is characterized by formation of osteochondral flaps or fragments within joints which cause pain and disability and predispose to early onset osteoarthritis. In the current proposal, our objective is to establish how alterations in the vascular supply to the epiphyseal growth cartilage, along with biomechanical trauma, contribute to the development, progression, and healing of OCD lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: We are tackling a deadly heart condition called pulmonary hypertension (PH), where the risk of death is seven times higher than normal. Our focus is on its most severe form, Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH), which usually gives patients only three years to live. Diagnosing PAH quickly and accurately is crucial because treatments are most effective only at earlier stages of the disease, and using its treatments on similar conditions can be harmful. However, current tests are expensive, complicated, invasive, and can take up to 4 years to provide the first diagnosis. By integrating mathematical modeling, advanced MRI imaging, and physics (fluid dynamics), this application goal is to develop a new, quick, noninvasive one-scan solution, the '4D Right-Heart virtual catheter’, to transform how we diagnose and monitor this life-threatening condition, offering faster diagnosis, better outcomes and making care more timely accessible to these suffering patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance Use Disorder (SUD) affects 46.3 million Americans and their communities and Sexual and Gender Minorities (SGMs) face higher rates of SUD than other groups due to complex factors like stigma and discrimination. Our innovative project aims to engage SGM patients to work with researchers to improve SUD treatment services and research. This work will provide valuable insights for healthcare practitioners, policymakers, and SGM community advocates, leading to tailored, patient-centered care for this underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is the second leading cause of blindness worldwide and the leading cause among African Americans. Effective lowering of intraocular pressure is neuroprotective and preserves vision. The goals of the present proposal are to develop novel technologies to objectively assess and monitor the tissue that regulates intraocular pressure, with age, in different disease subtypes, and in response to different therapies; this work is the first step in a continuum of research leading to early and accurate diagnosis of, and effective personalized therapy for, glaucoma.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Pharmacotherapy for childhood nephrotic syndrome is effective albeit highly complex. In this proposed study, we will carry out a systematic evaluation of factors that influence the ability of socially disadvantaged patients and families to choose the right treatment for them, and then create tools to support them in decision making centered around their needs. We anticipate that the findings will contribute to the understanding of influences on medication selection in this complex childhood kidney disease and produce the first tools to support shared decision making to improve care quality and reduce health disparities in childhood nephrotic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nucleotide metabolism is effectively targeted by anti-cancer agents, but their use is limited by toxicity to non- transformed cells, especially anti-cancer immune cells. Here, we strive to gain a more complete understanding of nucleotide metabolism—from sensing mechanisms to the response to nucleotide depletion—to enable sophisticated anti-cancer strategies that target cancer cells while sparing normal and immune cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will address a critical gap in our knowledge regarding factors that influence the risk that a child will be born with cleft lip/palate and, equally importantly, how severe that presentation will be. The latter is the major determinant of the number of craniofacial surgeries that the child will endure. Specifically, the project will investigate the impact of maternal dietary vitamin A levels and its interaction with specific cleft genes as well as how early developmental events in the embryo influence severity of the presentation of cleft lip/palate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Familial dysautonomia (FD) is a rare neuropathy caused by a splicing mutation in ELP1 gene that leads to variable tissue-specific skipping of exon 20. This mutation reduces the amount of ELP1 protein which is critical for the development and maintenance of specific neurons. The goal of this proposal is to identify the cell-type- specific gene network disruption caused by ELP1 loss and use spatial transcriptomics as well as patient-derived neuronal models to characterize the molecular mechanisms underlying specific neuronal degeneration in FD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Hearing loss is a major health problem that significantly affects the life quality of affected individuals. Many forms of hearing loss are genetic in origin and affect hair cells, the mechanosensors that convert sound induced vibrations into electrical signals. We propose here to show how the critical mechanosensitive structure of the hair cell is assembled, and how specific genes control that assembly; this information may eventually help guide therapeutic approaches leading to hearing restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The work proposed here, a multidisciplinary effort encompassing organic synthesis, oligonucleotide delivery, RNA targeted screening and antibacterial studies, describes the development of sequence-specific cell permeable binders of rRNA as antibacterial therapeutics. The success of the proposed work would be a significant addition to currently available ribosome-specific approaches in broad spectrum antibacterial antibiotic development, in particular for targeting gram negative pathogens such as carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE). We propose using a small rRNA target sequences to design conjugates that can be employed to inhibit bacterial growth, opening possibilities for developing sequence-specific RNA targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Understanding the molecular links that control the intricate relationship between Neisseria gonorrhoeae and the cells of the innate immune system, in this case - the macrophages, is critical for novel therapy design against this highly antibiotic-resistant pathogen. The knowledge gained will provide important insight into how Neisseria manipulates the host receptors and actin polymerization machinery to invade and form a replicative niche and ultimately will aid in the design of more effective therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol abuse and consumption are major causes of chronic liver disease and is a major health problem in the United States without successful treatment. Alcohol consumption induces hepatic mitochondrial morphological and metabolic changes as adaptive responses to attenuate alcohol toxicity, but mitochondria become maladaptive during the chronic course of alcohol consumption. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms of how alcohol-induced mitochondrial dynamic morphological changes on mitochondrial function and mitochondria- mediated innate immune response in the pathogenesis of alcohol-associated liver disease and cancer will help to develop novel therapeutic strategies to treat alcohol-associated liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Our project addresses the high prevalence of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) in the U.S. Hispanic population, with a particular focus on the impact of low language acculturation and hearing loss. We aim to investigate how language acculturation may factors interact and affect cognitive decline among Hispanic adults, leveraging data from the HCHS/SOL study. Our findings will inform public health strategies and interventions to mitigate cognitive decline risks in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease is the 7th leading cause of death in the United States and the most common cause of dementia; however, there are still no clinically-approved treatments that cure or reverse this disease. Aberrant tau protein causes neuronal dysfunction and neurodegeneration seen in Alzheimer’s disease and multiple other dementias but the mechanism in which it does so is not completely understood. This project aims to deepen our understanding of the mechanisms of tau-induced neurodegeneration, which is key to developing new therapeutic strategies to target dementias like Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer-related fatigue affects the majority of patients with blood cancer and can persist long into survivorship, thereby preventing people from returning to work, family roles, and hobbies, and reducing quality of life. This study will evaluate the ability of a 12-week time-restricted eating program (10-hour eating window during the day, fasting 14 hours at night) to reduce persistent fatigue, as well as shed light on relationships between a person’s internal body clock, sugar metabolism, and fatigue. If effective, time-restricted eating would be a safe, low-cost, widely accessible treatment that could revolutionize management fatigue among blood cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Comprehensive bioinformatic analysis and multi-omics data integration is an essential part of a wide variety of cancer-related studies such as biomarker discovery for cancer immunotherapy or the role of epigenetics in cancer-specific regulation. This application is aimed to support the development of state of the art bioinformatics analysis pipelines through my role as principal data scientist and bioinformatics manager of The Experimental and Computational Genomics Core in the Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center. The support of the R50 award will enable broader access of comprehensive bioinformatic expertise provided by the Experimental and Computational Genomics Core for diverse cancer-related studies by members of the Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center, the Bloomberg~Kimmel Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy, and the Convergence Institute at Johns Hopkins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart failure caused by dilated cardiomyopathy remains irreversible, with a mortality of up to 50% within five years, despite the best available therapies. The proposed translational study investigates the newly discovered role of Factor XIIa as a stimulator of overt heart failure in dilated cardiomyopathy. This project has high clinical relevance for developing new therapeutic strategies needed to reduce mortality from heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic back pain is a leading cause of disability worldwide and is frequently caused by damage to the inter- vertebral discs in the spine. The objective of this application is to determine the role of epigenetic mechanisms, which regulate tissue health without changing the genomic code, in painful disc damage. These studies may reveal new approaches for the treatment of low back pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COngenital Diarrhea and Enteropathy (CoDE) are rare monogenic disorders that are under-researched and associated with enormous management costs and adverse life-long outcomes. Our main objective is to uncover the genetic origins of congenital diarrhea in children, understand the unique characteristics of these conditions, and study the responsible genes' underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms. We will use these insights to enable tools and resources for the research community, provide information and expertise to patients and the public, and develop new strategies for treatment using patient-derived cellular systems and animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  CRISPR-transposase systems show tremendous potential to be generally useful programmable DNA- insertion tools to complement the power of CRISPR-Cas9, however the mechanisms governing DNA-insertion are mysterious and subject to unknown regulatory ‘rules’ that inhibit wide-spread adoption. We propose to characterize the mechanisms that govern programmed DNA-insertion using high-resolution cryo-EM focusing on the regulatory component, TnsC, from the shCAST system. Our structures will provide a detailed understanding of how CRISPR-transposase systems function at the molecular level; this information will enable engineering of the shCAST system to become a generally useful genome-editing tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the high mortality rate and the significant potential for a public health emergency, there are no FDA- approved vaccines or antiviral drugs for MERS-CoV. In addition, members of the Merbecovirus and Sarbecovirus subgenera within the Betacoronavirus genus pose a high risk of future spillover into humans. This project aims to develop orally available antivirals for MERS-CoV and evaluate inhibitors against merbecovirus and sarbecovirus 3C-like protease, which will have a significant impact on human coronavirus research and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggressive carcinomas of the pancreas, breast, and bladder are known to exhibit basal lineage features, which is associated with poor prognosis but for unclear reasons. Building upon progress made in the last funding cycle aimed at understanding basal identity in pancreatic cancer, the major goal of this project will be to define molecular mechanisms that define this tumor subtype. We anticipate that a detailed knowledge of lineage master regulators that drive this cellular fate may unveil novel targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Emerging research implicates gait dysfunction as a preclinical marker of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD). Building on our research, we will employ a team science approach with multi-modal neuroscience and biological methods to examine mechanisms underlying gait and cognitive decline in aging. Our overall hypothesis is that the interplay between pathological and resilience mechanisms in aging results in structural, functional, and neurophysiological brain changes that lead to the emergence of gait dysfunction as a preclinical marker of dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Hearing at birth, as well as lifelong hearing preservation, requires sensory cells in the inner ear to develop and maintain a motion-sensing compartment that detects sound-borne vibrations. This project seeks to understand how this compartment acquires its unique slanted architecture required for sensory function, and how this architecture is preserved during life despite wear and tear. Accomplishment of the proposed research will help the interpretation and design of treatments for auditory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: SUBJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in the clinical treatment procedures, advanced heart disease remains one of the leading cause of death in the United States. One main reason for the lack of optimal healthcare performance for treating these patients is the inefficiency in predicting clinical outcomes related to frailty. In the proposed research, we will develop and validate a novel objective sensor-based approach to characterize heart behavior in response to a localized rapid upper-extremity function task, among older adults with advanced heart disease to predict therapy outcomes and reversible frailty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) is complex and caused by insulin resistance, impaired beta-cell function, and many genetic and upstream exposomic factors, potentially operating differently across ancestral groups. We will deploy and evaluate data science approaches to tackle the complexity of T2D risk by deriving new ancestry- aware polygenomic and polyexposure predictors of insulin resistance and beta cell dysfunction and use machine learning approaches to identifying key `omic of the drivers of the risk across race/ancestral groups. We will disseminate new open data science resources for discovering elusive exposome factors, polygenomic predictors, and their endogenous responses in T2D risk to enhance reproducible research and add value to already precious NIH cohort data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Streptococcus pneumoniae (Spn) induced community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) leads to adverse cardiac outcomes during bacterial infection and even months and years that follow. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black men and women currently experience the highest rates of colorectal cancer of any racial and ethnic group in the US for reasons only partly understood and their risk factors have not been well-studied to date. Our new web-based decision tools will provide accurate personalized risk assessments of developing colorectal cancer for Black adults, providing clinicians and the Black community with valuable aids to identify those at highest risk for developing colorectal cancer and to inform lifestyle prevention strategies, leading to improved uptake of screening tests and earlier detection of colorectal cancer and lower mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Caused by inflammatory lung injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is associated with the loss of ventilated airspaces, low blood oxygen, and high mortality. Dysregulation and misdistribution of lung perfusion may play an important role in determining both the clinical trajectory of ARDS and its response to treatment; unfortunately, pulmonary circulation is poorly characterized in this condition. The proposed research will use imaging to reveal the contribution of abnormal pulmonary perfusion to the progression of lung injury as well as to develop strategies to attenuate ARDS severity by targeting pulmonary circulation.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying approaches for coordinating health benefits for individuals who are dually eligible for Medicare and Medicaid is challenging. Many dual-eligible beneficiaries are enrolling in private Medicare Advantage plans, which differ from Traditional Medicare in their payment incentives, provider networks, care management, and the availability of supplemental benefits. This study will investigate enrollment patterns in Medicare Advantage versus Traditional Medicare for dual eligible beneficiaries entering Medicare and compare use, spending, and health outcomes across these groups to inform federal and state policies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Medicare Advantage versus Traditional Medicare for Dual Eligible Beneficiaries

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We will determine how IL-13 contributes to COVID-19 disease through its role in induction of an inflammatory hyaluronan-containing extracellular matrix. This work has the promise of identifying novel therapies for acute and long-term COVID-19 directed at the IL-13 - hyaluronan pathway, as well as increasing our understanding of other pulmonary diseases where IL-13 and hyaluronan are known to contribute.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Congenital syphilis rates are rising in the U.S., but current diagnostic tests lack sensitivity to confirm infection among asymptomatic, syphilis-exposed newborns. Infant immune responses to congenital syphilis infection are poorly characterized but could provide new diagnostic biomarkers to inform the probability of infection among asymptomatic, syphilis-exposed infants. We will use advanced immunologic methods to expand our understanding of innate and adaptive immunopathogenesis among an established cohort of symptomatically infected infants, followed by application of these immunologic signatures to an enrolled cohort of asymptomatic, syphilis-exposed infants in order to assess their likelihood of congenital infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intestinal epithelium is a rapidly self-renewing tissue but at the same time is prone to injury. Many pathological conditions result in the depletion of the active stem cell pool in the intestinal crypts, which become repopulated by other cell types in a process of regeneration. The current proposal aims at understanding the mechanisms that coordinate the interplay between epithelial and stromal cells during epithelial regeneration after injury and will advance the understanding of the fundamental mechanisms required for optimal gut function and provide opportunities for better treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will determine the many influences on parent presence and participation in caregiving in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) and the importance of parent presence and participation for clinical and developmental outcomes of preterm infants. By studying these influences and how they change during an infant’s NICU hospitalization, specific interventions can be developed to improve infant outcomes. The study will also provide information to better understand race- and socioeconomic-based disparities in parent presence and participation to increase health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive performance is of key concern among aging populations, but little research has been conducted on cognitive performance among aging Black and Latino sexual minority men (SMM). We will use respondent- driven sampling to recruit a cohort of aging Black and Latino SMM in Northern New Jersey and assess how their social networks are constructed, and how social and physical activities promoted within these social networks and interpersonal processes (intersectional stigma and social support) may be protective for cognitive performance. Our findings will provide valuable data for health providers, public health researchers, and policymakers to more effectively intervene across the complex pathways between marginalized social position, stigma, social networks, and cognitive performance outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A multimodal, evidence-based, quantitative method is required to deliver continuous scoring for diabetic nephropathy, the most common histopathologic manifestation of diabetic kidney disease (DKD), by engaging molecular information along with digital histology, and summarizing the contributions of each pixel of a renal tissue histopathology image using quantitative morphometry and omics. The investigator team will: 1) extend digital pathology of DKD by integrating spatial molecular features to reveal hidden digital image biomarkers, 2) provide clinicians with additional useful metrics for biopsy assessment to augment the current treatment strategy of DKD, and 3) conduct a usability study to understand the feasibility of using the resulting tools in the clinic. With these deliverables, this renewal R01 application will shift the paradigm, transforming digital and computational DKD pathology to improve prognosis, diagnosis, interpretation of molecular processes, and therapy selection in DKD, and thus lead the way to translating the developed tools into the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The defining pathological hallmark of Lewy body diseases (LBDs) is the accumulation of misfolded and toxic a- synuclein (aSyn) through multiple mechanisms. This proposal will investigate the significance and mechanistic basis of a novel pathway that mediates the accumulation, transmission, and toxicity of aSyn through animal and cellular models, which is expected to shed critical new insights to new ways to treat LBDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative While the phenomenon of bone coupling, i.e., the complex spatial and temporal crosstalk that occurs between osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and osteoblast-dependent bone formation, is well appreciated, the molecular mechanisms that transduce signaling between osteoclasts and osteoblasts remain poorly defined. Herein, we describe a body of preliminary evidence wherein two osteoclast-derived proteolytic enzymes, the cysteine proteinase, cathepsin K (Ctsk), and the membrane-anchored matrix metalloproteinase, Mmp14/MT1- MMP, control the TGFβ/Smad/Tspan4-dependent deposition of migrasomes, a new form of extracellular vesicle that acts as a key "braking" mechanism to negatively regulate bone formation with the result that the osteoclast- specific knockout of both enzymes decreases migrasome formation, thereby triggering massive formation of new bone in vivo. The results of this study should not only shed new mechanistic light on a novel form of proteolytic crosstalk that controls bone coupling, but also identify new targets for therapeutic intervention in osteolytic disease states.
