IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Even after surgical correction, patients with coarctation of the aorta (CoA) continue to suffer from a diminished quality of life and a reduced lifespan, often due to hypertension. We will develop new standardized tools for a personalized medicine approach that improves objectivity and diagnosis in the treatment of CoA to limit the severity and duration of mechanical consequences and reduce the likelihood of hypertension. Results from these approaches will be used clinically to propose new criteria for the treatment of CoA patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal proposal aims to support Dr. Minmin Liu as a Research Specialist, enabling her to cultivate a stable and thriving career critical to Dr. Peter A. Jones's research program in the field of cancer epigenetics. Dr. Liu is uniquely qualified due to her strong research background, expertise in next-generation sequencing techniques, and computational data analysis for epigenetic/epigenomic studies, as well as her track record of making significant scientific contributions. Dr. Liu's proficiency will integrate cellular, biochemical, structural, and animal studies to elucidate how abnormal DNA methylation is established and interpreted in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative We have designed a series of experiments that test a new model of speech motor learning which focuses on the role of plasticity in sensory systems in both learning and retention. These studies use a combination of brain stimulation, electrophysiological and neuroimaging techniques to test the participation of sensory and motor areas in these processes and circuit level changes that predict learning and retention. Our preliminary work supports the idea that there is plasticity in each of the primary systems which participate in speech motor learning (auditory, somatosensory, motor).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Our proposal will change the paradigm of care for CFTR modulators, which are a novel class of therapeutic compounds for people with CF. The data we obtain, which will be from the largest study of people with CF on modulator therapy, will help ensure patients are able to personalize therapeutic strategies using a combination of genetics, individual modulator concentrations, and dose titration. This proposal addresses critical knowledge gaps in CF therapy identified by both Francis Collins, former NIH director and NIH’s 2022 conference on the future of CF research, to better understand metabolism enzyme pharmacogenomics, modulator pharmacokinetics, and individualization of modulator dosing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation and angiogenesis are integral parts of wound healing process, but in pathological conditions, these two processes contribute to the development of cardiovascular diseases and the progression of tumor growth and metastasis. Fibrin(ogen) plays a significant role in these processes. We have recently discovered that endothelial N-cadherin is a novel receptor for fibrin. Our preliminary data suggest that the interaction of fibrin or its fragments with this receptor inhibits leukocyte transmigration, thereby reducing inflammation, and promotes angiogenesis. The primary objectives of the proposed study are: to establish the structural basis for this interaction, to clarify its role in fibrin-dependent inflammation and angiogenesis, and to design efficient anti-inflammatory and anti-angiogenesis agents that can be developed as potent therapeutics for treatment of fibrin-dependent inflammatory disorders and angiogenesis-related tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychedelics are considered important therapeutic agents for the treatment of several neuropsychiatric disorders, including substance use disorders (SUDs) and major depression. Both SUDs and depression share common etiological elements that predispose individuals to develop these diseases, including exposure to chronic environmental stress. This project focuses on a molecular mechanism implicated in SUDs that is triggered by immune cells following chronic psychological stress, and is sensitive to psilocybin treatment, which implicates a neuroimmune interaction induced by chronic stress to the predisposition of SUDs.

PHR: Narrative This project consists of an integrated experimental-computational strategy to elucidate in depth the regulatory networks that govern angiogenesis, arteriogenesis and vascular remodeling. We will acquire quantitative experimental data on effects of specific perturbations on the signaling and gene expression pathways that govern endothelial responses to VEGF and fluid shear stress, from which w cSTAR will develop a quantitative causal model. Key model predictions will then be tested experimental in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative  Human vision critically depends on normal development of the cornea and its ability to focus light on the retina. Model organisms have been an important tool for understanding other human diseases, but a lack of knowledge has prevented them from being used to study disorders of corneal development such as myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism, keratoconus or corneal dystrophy. This proposal will investigate how the cells that produce the corneal lens of the fruit fly Drosophila differentiate and how the corneal lens itself is organized, with the goal of using this system to model human corneal diseases and test treatments for them.

PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, with more than 14 million new cases and 8 million deaths each year. New advances in sequencing technology are uncovering the genomic mechanisms that drive cancer development and progression including the complex genetic, transcriptomic, and epigenetic drivers of this disease. Expertise and comfort in these new approaches are essential to a successful cancer research program to facilitate better diagnosis and treatment options.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the NIH has highlighted the “development and testing of interventions…to address food insecurity and neighborhood-level access to healthy and affordable foods” as a priority research area, little is known about how best to intervene across the food system to improve the diets and health of adolescents. This study uses systems science approaches to prioritize food systems interventions targeting adolescents living in low-income urban settings in Nairobi, Kenya by: 1) characterizing the food and home environments that adolescents have access to; 2) quantifying the influence of those environments on adolescent food preferences, dietary patterns, and malnutrition; and 3) co-designing food systems interventions with key community stakeholders, and using project data to rank these interventions based on their feasibility and likely impact on adolescent food choices, nutrition insecurity, and malnutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Individuals with obesity are at higher risk of tendon injury than individuals without obesity, but how obesity affects tendon homeostasis and healing is not fully understood. This study investigates obesity-mediated effects of altered mechanical load and metabolic dysfunction on tendon structure, function, and gene transcription during homeostasis (Aim 1) and when healing from injury (Aim 2). This work will elucidate the effect of obesity on tendon homeostasis and healing and provide critical training opportunities for the primary investigator to leverage animal studies for translational tendon science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription factors represent one of the largest groups of oncogenes yet are traditionally considered undruggable. By employing chemical proteomic based drug discovery screens, we have identified a covalent ligand that binds to and disrupts the activity of the oncogenic transcription factor SOX10 in melanoma cells. The goal of this application is to use a suite of advanced chemical-proteomic and genomic technologies to understand the mode of action of this covalent ligand, its potential for optimization and the impact of pharmacological inhibition of SOX10 in melanoma models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative diseases, like Alzheimer's, have massive accumulation of proteins such as tau, which is linked to the failure of the cellular recycling system known as autophagy. A unique protein called BOK connects an intricate signaling network between autophagy and cellular survival. This project will elucidate the metabolic pathways regulated by BOK in order to reveal potential mechanisms by which to prevent tau-mediated death of neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Among the unique symptoms of COVID-19 are the abrupt and profound loss of smell and taste. While transient disruption of normal smell and taste is associated with many upper respiratory infections, the sudden onset and degree of severity are key distinguishing symptoms of COVID-19. Importantly, up to 4% of patients who recover from COVID-19 have persistently distorted sense of smell and/or taste 6-12 months later. Although current studies have identified disruption of the normal architecture of the olfactory neuroepithelium and of olfactory neuron signaling in patients with persistent COVID19 chemosensory dysfunction, the mechanistic determinants of persistence are still unclear. This proposal seeks to define the relevant mediators derived from uniquely dysregulated immune cells of patients with persistent COVID19 chemosensory dysfunction, the cellular targets of these mediators and how they disrupt the normal developmental and survival trajectories in the olfactory mucosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) is a group of progressive neurodegenerative disorders with an early onset, profoundly impacting patients and their families' quality of life. While it is known that the genetic makeup of an individual impacts their responses to certain phenotypes, and thereby their susceptibility to developing FTLD, the mechanism through which this happens remains elusive. The studies proposed here combine the use of patient-derived human stem cells and cellular factors linked to neurodegeneration to build a novel mouse model of FTLD with the potential to contribute to the understanding of and ability to diagnose and treat patients with FTLD and similar neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries are a leading cause of training and sports-related injuries, resulting in significant loss of activity and quality of life. ACL reconstruction, a common treatment, requires suitable tendon graft-to-bone integration to resume prior activities, as such there is an unmet clinical need to improve and expedite treatment of these debilitating injuries to get patients back to their active lifestyles and minimize health care expenditures. This proposal seeks to address this clinical need by localizing delivery of a small molecule agonist of the hedgehog pathway, a potent regulator of fibrocartilage formation during enthesis development, to improve tendon-to-bone integration following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social support has multiple beneficial effects that mitigate adverse mental health outcomes and promote well- being across all populations. Understanding how to optimize social support for transgender and nonbinary (TNB) populations, specifically those experiencing multiple forms of marginalization, could meaningfully reduce TNB mental health disparities, specifically depression, anxiety, and suicide risk. Using an intersectional framework and a community-engaged approaches, this project will identify the most crucial aspects of social support for TNB populations for reducing adverse mental health outcomes, and to develop the measurement tools necessary to support future prevention and intervention strategies that can build and leverage social support to improve TNB mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Integrating tumor function-orientated imaging technology such as near-infrared tomographic optical breast imaging (TOBI) with predominantly structure-oriented clinical diagnostic imaging modalities has demonstrated considerable potential in improving the specificity of breast cancer diagnoses. This project seeks to address the limitation of optical breast imaging in characterizing small lesions by utilizing a deep learning-based image reconstruction framework accompanied by a dual-modal integration with diagnostic x-ray mammography under spot compression (DeepTOBIDx) to achieve marked improvement in optical image resolution, as well as in quantification accuracy and speed. Once validated in the proposed reader study, this work will offer radiologists with actionable lesion functional information to effectively avoid unnecessary biopsies during the diagnostic workup.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Validation of NAD+ measurements for human clinical studies: multi-method inter-laboratory standardization There is widespread interest in the role of NAD+ in human disease and whether increasing NAD+ with supplements (e.g., nicotinamide riboside or nicotinamide mononucleotide) has therapeutic value in humans. However, our understanding of NAD+ and its metabolites in vivo is limited by technical barriers and a lack of consensus on analytical techniques. This proposal will develop standard methodology that can be used to measure NAD+ and related metabolites in human clinical trials. This includes testing whether simple blood and urine measurements by mass spectrometry or enzymatic assays can accurately predict the NAD+ content of tissue, which is currently determined by expensive and technically challenging magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In-hospital mortality prediction models (MPMs) are widely used in clinical research and practice; but existing MPMs suffer from algorithmic bias, or systematic differences in performance across groups, which is especially consequential for patients hospitalized with acute respiratory failure (ARF) or sepsis because (1) such patients face high risks of biased predictions due to diagnostic uncertainty and high mortality risk; (2) these syndromes pose increased mortality risks for racial and ethnic minorities; and (3) MPMs are frequently applied to these populations. Therefore, we seek to develop, validate, and demonstrate the impact of a novel MPM that optimizes fairness (i.e., defined by ‘groupwise optimality,’ optimizing subgroup performance without sacrificing predictive accuracy) across key subgroups defined by race, ethnicity, sex, age, primary language, insurance status, and social vulnerability. Unlike development of commonly used MPMs, we will explicitly address key causes of bias in model development: differential missing data and calibration biases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public health narrative: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) remains a major health problem, globally affecting at least 257 million carriers who are at risk of developing serious liver disease, including liver cancer. Although HBV infections can be prevented through vaccination, chronic hepatitis B can rarely be cured. Here, we aim to mechanistically dissect the steps of the HBV life-cycle that are critical for persistence and could yield new targets for novel antiviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work is basic research, designed to provide new insights into how a healthy nervous system implements decision rules that support flexible visuo-oculomotor behavior. Because the cortico-basal ganglia pathway has been implicated in multiple deficits associated with decision-making in Parkinsonism, addiction, and other disorders, our systematic examination of multiple key stations in this pathway is likely to provide health- related benefits in the long term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Survivors of adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer are likely to live several more decades, yet their previous treatment exposures can have dramatic long-term effects on their cardiovascular health. Our preliminary research suggests that there is a group of survivors of AYA cancer whose hearts are functioning at the same levels as hearts in individuals who are decades older. We have initiated the development of a diverse survivor of AYA cancer study designed to identify the characteristics of accelerated cardiac aging that can inform strategies reduce risk during treatment and develop personalized risk-informed follow-up care to reduce and prevent the development of cardiac dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) is associated with deficits in brain structure and function, but it remains unclear which of these brain abnormalities can recover when alcohol use stops. This proposal aims to fill a gap in understanding how the neural mechanisms associated with cognitive reappraisal (e.g., prefrontal cortex [PFC]) and alcohol cue reactivity (e.g., striatum) change during early abstinence, and whether changes in these mechanisms can predict the individuals most likely to return to heavy alcohol use. By identifying neural signatures associated with risk for relapse to heavy drinking, we can target specific deficits and tailor treatment plans to each individual, improving outcomes for patients with AUD.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE While electronic health records (EHRs) have had positive effects for patient safety and quality of care, they have also worsened the work experiences of primary care physicians (PCPs), and health system leaders struggle to identify interventions that contribute to improved primary care quality while also enhancing PCPs’ EHR interactions and wellbeing. To address this gap, we will use data from both community-based and academic primary care practices to evaluate the impact of three EHR-optimization interventions - 1) scribes, 2) advanced team-based inbox messaging support, and 3) artificial intelligence (AI)-assisted inbox messaging support - on PCP and patient panel outcomes and will assess the cost effectiveness of these interventions. The results of this study will guide health systems leaders towards interventions that both address EHR-based challenges negatively impacting the PCP work experience and maximize benefits of EHRs for physicians, patients, and health systems.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Assessing the Effects of EHR Optimization Interventions in Primary Care
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Information Technology Research[HITR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative To better understand the needs and barriers faced by adults with SUD in underserved, high-poverty communities in Richmond, VA, the Virginia Patient Engagement Resource Center (PERC) will create and train a patient advisory panel with people in recovery and peer recovery navigators. We will implement a consultation process co-developed with the panel to facilitate discussions with researchers regarding their grant proposals, ongoing research projects, and/or emerging research outcomes. We will conduct research on patient experiences, including a survey of individuals not yet in recovery and qualitative and participatory, arts- based research, and use the findings to inform the design and implementation of two pilot research projects strategically focused on increasing treatment initiation and retention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Type 3c diabetes mellitus (T3cD) accompanies exocrine pancreas diseases like chronic pancreatitis (CP) and has distinct clinical features and greater prevalence than previously appreciated, but the mechanisms underlying T3cD are poorly understood. From studies of islets in living subjects with CP, we have identified molecular and functional changes in islet cells that could promote prediabetes. In this proposal we aim to identify signaling and genetic mechanisms underlying islet dysfunction in pre-T3cD development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays critical roles in normal hearing, helping us hear in quiet or noisy environments throughout our lives. Understanding these roles is critical for developing approaches to help people with age-related hearing loss, difficulty understanding speech in noisy environments, learning to hear with cochlear implants or coping with hearing dysfunctions in disorders such as autism or schizophrenia. The present proposal will answer critical questions about the cellular and circuit mechanisms that allow acetylcholine to support hearing.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative One-third of patients with cirrhosis will develop a complication called hepatic encephalopathy, which is characterized by confusion, fatigue, and personality changes – all of which significantly decrease quality of life and patient survival. Current treatments are only moderately effective, but there is some data suggesting that intestinal bacteria may play an important role in causing hepatic encephalopathy. This project uses novel approaches to identify the importance of intestinal bacteria in hepatic encephalopathy, and tests if treatments that influence intestinal bacteria can treat this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections due to antibiotic-resistant bacteria known as Enterobacterales are occurring increasingly in the community in otherwise healthy persons without significant prior health care contact. Our goal is to identify community-based exposures to resistant bacteria by examining potential environmental, animal, and household sources. Our results will lead to ways to control the sources that we find and to decrease the risk of antibiotic- resistant bacterial infections in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are approximately 55,000 deaths from breast and ovarian cancer annually in the United States, with BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations found in 5-7% of breast and 6-15% of ovarian cancers cases. The goal of this project is to identify new biological factors that determine PARP inhibitor sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic osteosarcoma (OS) in people and dogs is almost uniformly fatal with little advances in treatment in the past four decades. Alpha-emitter therapy offers a targeted means to treat metastatic OS and is impervious to treatment resistance often seen with chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Using a spontaneously occurring canine OS in client-owned pets, we will investigate the efficacy and toxicity of alpha- emitter therapy in a real-world model for future translation to human OS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA methylation aberrancies are hallmarks of colorectal cancer, the third leading cause of cancer death in both men and women in the U.S. Despite the great promise for early detection and intervention, DNA methylation changes in prediagnostic blood are poorly characterized in individuals with colorectal cancer. We propose the largest prospective study to date to characterize the landscape of genome-wide DNA methylation markers associated with colorectal cancer and examine the biological relevance and modifiable potential of DNA methylation for colorectal cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will lead, enrich, and sustain a community of practice focused on accurate annotation and prediction of protein function. These goals will be achieved by organizing an innovative community challenge, by developing critical infrastructure for expanding and improving function prediction, by increasing interaction among subcommunities, by increasing training opportunities, as well as by widely disseminating scientific findings. All proposed activities will incentivize the community towards reaching the long-term goal of accurately annotating every protein with respect to their residue- and protein-level function in a fine-grained, context-dependent, and causal manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) are promising emergent cancer therapies that precisely deliver cytotoxic payloads to targeted tumor cells. Even so, the in vivo usage of ADCs has various limitations, such as on-target/off-tumor toxicity, poor brain delivery, acquired therapy resistance, and low effectiveness in target tumors with low antigen expression. We intend to overcome these issues using PMPC-polymer engineering technology developed by our team.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Drugs developed to selectively block the oncogenic kinase BRAF often exhibit a mysterious phenomenon called paradoxical activation in which they fail to inhibit and instead increase BRAF activity. This project uses new biophysical approaches to dissect the molecular mechanisms underlying paradoxical activation with the goal of guiding the design of new drugs that more effectively block BRAF activity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding why speech recognition is slower for older adults than younger adults could help address common age-related listening and memory difficulties. Our research examines how quickly information is collected and how much information is needed for speech to be understood in noise. We will study the brain systems that support recognition of words based on incomplete fragments to better understand why word recognition is slower for many older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer evades the immune system by harvesting mitochondria of immune cells via nanoscale tentacles or tunneling nanotubes. Here we address this major challenge by delivering exogenous mitochondria to the T cells and combing these supercharged T cells with novel inhibitors that block the ability of cancer cells to form tunneling nanotubes. We will test whether a combination therapy with immune checkpoint inhibitor enhances antitumor outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Immune responses to infection depend on the proper function and expansion of antigen-specific T cells, a process that can go awry when T cells recognize auto-antigens and cause autoimmunity in diseases such as multiple sclerosis. The function of T cells is dependent on the activity of channels in the cell membrane that transport charged ions in and out of cells, and we identified a subunit of the sodium/potassium ATPase as an important new regulator of T cell function. In this proposal, we will determine the molecular function of a sodium/potassium ATPase subunit in T cells and its role in autoimmune inflammation in a preclinical model of multiple sclerosis, which is essential to assess the suitability of this sodium/potassium ATPase subunit as a drug target.

PHR: NARRATIVE Loss of function mutations in the genes encoding KRIT1 (CCM1), CCM2 (OSM), or CCM3 (PDCD10) cause Cerebral Cavernous Malformations (CCM). The loss of function of each of these proteins is therefore directly associated with stroke, focal neurological defects, seizures and vascular abnormalities. The goal of this application is to understand the molecular underpinnings for normal function of these proteins as regulators of the MAP kinase kinase kinase, MEKK3.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Obesity, diabetes and closely related metabolic disorders are associated with impaired energy metabolism and damage to intracellular engines known as mitochondria. Dysfunction of these engines can contribute to elevated blood sugar levels, heart failure and diminished exercise tolerance. This project examines processes responsible for maintaining mitochondrial health and resilience in skeletal muscle and heart to promote physical fitness and defend against metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative  The provision of low-value (quality) care, defined as services that provide little clinical benefit relative to their cost, has reached epidemic proportions in the US accounting for more than $300 billion in health care expenditures annually (Kozeara 2020). Private Medicare Advantage (MA) plans have unique toolkit which can be employed to curb the use the low-value care whereas such options are not available in traditional Medicare (TM). Our comparisons of MA-HMO vs TM and MA-PPO vs TM will provide new insights as to whether specific MA plans are effective in reducing the use of low-value care for early-stage breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Syphilis affects millions of people worldwide, and its global rates are on the rise. Current diagnostic tests for syphilis are non-ideal, and having a better diagnostic test would lead to more infections being detected and a decreased incidence of disease. In the current proposal we will extend the performance testing of our promising, newly developed syphilis diagnostic platform that is highly specific for detection of infectious and congenital syphilis and can be translated to a point-of-care test format, to aid in achieving the goal of decreasing the incidence of syphilis in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a common experience for many older adults, and it powerfully affects a person’s ability to live independently and with a high quality of life. This project will investigate whether an in-home program informed by psychology and involving increasing physical activity while sitting less, bonding with a group of peers, and reducing body weight can help to improve the physical activity levels and pain symptoms of older adults living with chronic pain. Our long-range goal is to develop a scalable and accessible program that can improve pain symptoms of many older adults at home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mounting evidence links perturbations in early life host-microbiota interactions with increased susceptibility to immune-mediated diseases later in life, yet we lack a mechanistic understanding of how mutually beneficial relationships between gut bacteria and the neonatal immune system are formed. Building from our discovery that maternal antibodies, delivered via breastfeeding, are key regulators of intestinal homeostasis, this proposal seeks to define the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which maternal antibodies restrain aberrant immune responses to gut bacteria in early life. The resulting data will advance our understanding of the immunological processes that regulate nascent host-microbiota interactions, thereby aiding in our ability to manipulate mucosal immune responses in early life to promote long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop efficient quantitative model-based image reconstruction algorithms for X-ray- induced acoustic computed tomography (XACT) to facilitate dose monitoring during radiotherapy in clinics. This project addresses the algorithmic challenges (limited view artifacts, absence of quantitative dose information, and lack of the capability of correcting for acoustic heterogeneity in the reconstructed dose maps) in the path of the clinical translation of XACT and in combination with the advanced instrumentation being developed as part of the Unit Director’s R37 award, the success of the proposed will expedite the clinical translation of XACT as a next-generation modality for radiation dosimetry as well as radiography. To achieve real-time/near real-time dosimetry capability, the developed reconstruction algorithms will be parallelized using graphics processing units (GPUs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections within the brain can cause permanent damage, which makes limiting pathogen growth and spread imperative. We find that caspase-8, a protein that induces cell death, is important for controlling the growth of the parasite Toxoplasma gondii in the brain. The goal of this application is to understand how the brain and immune system limit infection through this cell-death-associated protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal takes a comprehensive approach to understanding the impact of a wide range of environmental factors including air pollution, and physical stressors (ultraviolet radiation [UV], radon), demographic factors (age, race and ethnicity), and social determinants of health (SDOH) on mammographic features in the Nurses’ Health Study 3. We expect our findings to provide valuable information on the role of modifiable exposures on mammographic features and thus, subsequent breast cancer risk. These findings will inform individual- and population-level prevention, risk assessments, and policy decisions, with the long-term goal of reducing the burden of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Misexpression of an early embryonic transcription factor, DUX4, in the skeletal muscle causes facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) through poorly understood mechanisms. This proposal aims to fill a critical gap in our knowledge of DUX4 pathobiology by investigating the mechanisms of misregulated RNA processing and quality control induced by DUX4. Our findings will pave the way to identify new therapeutic vulnerabilities for FSHD and other neuromuscular diseases caused by perturbed RNA metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Men with Castration-resistant Prostate Cancer (CRPC) do not respond to standard of care therapies or immunotherapy. To address this shortcoming, we developed a first-in-class ACK1 inhibitor, (R)-9b which not only suppressed AR/AR-V7 within the CRPCs tumors, but also activated the host immune response against tumors. The (R)-9b compound has shown good safety profiles in mouse, rat and canine models. This proposal is directed towards running the first-in-man Phase I clinical trial for (R)- 9b in CRPC patients. We will evaluate the safety, efficacy, tolerability and PSA levels in CRPC patients treated with (R)-9b. A successful Phase I trial should pave the way to Phase II/III clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will have a positive impact on developing new approaches to enhance healthspan in older adults. Specifically, this project will provide new fundamental knowledge of how the inflammatory secretome of adipose tissue influences key functional and physiological parameters in skeletal muscle, particularly the molecular response to exercise. The project is relevant to the mission of NIA because it satisfies a critical need for understanding factors that contribute to skeletal muscle dysfunction with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Fear of trauma-associated stimuli even after they have ceased to be threats is a core pathology of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) that results from being unable to learn that stimuli previously linked to trauma are no longer dangerous (deficits in extinction learning). Of relevance to the Strategic Objectives #1 and #3 of NIMH’s mission which are to “define mechanisms of complex behaviors while striving for preventions and cures”, our proposal will shed light on how molecular mechanisms in sub- thalamic neurons influence extinction learning. The proposed research is relevant to public health because our results will provide a foundation from which future studies could identify core pathways underlying extinction learning across the entire brain, eventually resulting in new pharmacotherapies to reduce the burden of maladaptive fear associated with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A first episode of psychosis is a leading cause of disability in young adults, with high risk of suicide and all cause mortality. A substantial part of the burden and cost relates to poor functional outcomes, and the inability to determine the right antipsychotic treatment during the earliest phases of psychotic illness, particularly for those who might need clozapine, a medication that is already known to work best for those who do not respond to conventional antipsychotics. In patients with a first episode of psychosis, the present study aims to determine whether the use of biomarker guided treatment decisions leads to better outcomes and equivalent side effects in people prescribed clozapine compared to conventional antipsychotics, including changes in brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in three liver transplant recipients experiences a cardiovascular event after transplant because of immunosuppression medications and a high prevalence of cardiovascular risk factors, such as high blood pressure. This study uses novel statistical methods applied to prospectively collected observational data to identify the best treatment approaches for high blood pressure in liver transplant recipients that reduce cardiovascular risk without doing harm to other organs. Improving the outcome of each liver transplant patient is of paramount importance to society due to the organ shortage and the enormous resources that are invested into transplanting each patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Pregnant, postpartum, and parenting people (parents) represent the majority of people with substance use disorders (SUD), yet their unique needs and intersectional experiences are often overlooked in research as it relates to supporting treatment engagement. The goal of the proposed study is to establish a patient engagement research center focused on parents with SUD, by leveraging a lived experience advisory panel (N = 18), special emphasis panels, and a Data Collective of 1,150 parents with SUD to serve as a national resource for other researchers seeking to facilitate treatment engagement among this population. Our approach emphasizes shared power and decision-making and a consideration of intersectional experiences of discrimination (e.g., race, ethnicity, gender, class, parenting status, rurality) to support innovative and transformative research to facilitate treatment engagement and success among parents with SUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed VCEUD (Vanderbilt Center of Excellence in Undiagnosed Diseases) will function in the broader Undiagnosed Disease Network to identify the cause of undiagnosed diseases and thus help patients and their families. We will work with local communities and organizations to increase the recruitment of underserved and minority patients into UDN. We will also work with UDN to develop more powerful AI-based tools and resources to make diagnosing undiagnosed diseases more efficient and to help doctors find people with undiagnosed conditions more easily.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strategies disrupting MYCN oncogenic programs are critically needed for neuroblastoma therapy. High-risk, MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma is characterized by high relapse and mortality rates, dysregulated tumor metabolism, and an immune-suppressive tumor microenvironment. As the development of effective immunotherapies requires new definitions of the negative regulations impairing an adequate immune response, our proposed research will provide a novel view on how oncogenic MYCN reprograms the metabolic environment of NB to drive immune evasion. Our proposed research will also aim at modulating the metabolic environment of neuroblastoma to enhance immune-based approaches for high-risk MYCN-amplified disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced age is the leading risk factor for all chronic diseases. Although many hallmarks of aging have been identified, a key physiological feature of aging is decreased blood flow and an inability to match blood flow to organ requirements. This project will elucidate the metabolic mechanisms by which aging impairs blood flow in the heart and identify interventions to improve blood flow, heart function, and exercise tolerance over the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal depression is a robust predictor of internalizing symptoms and disorders in offspring, highlighting the public health importance of studying causal risk mechanisms early in development to inform targeted prevention efforts at the earliest possible point. The current project combines behavioral and neural measures across 3 time points spanning ages 4 to 8 years to examine how developmental trajectories of reward responsiveness shape early internalizing symptoms among offspring of depressed mothers. By examining how maternal positive emotion behaviors and child early life adversity impact these pathways, findings from the current study have significant potential to inform novel prevention targets for specific populations of at-risk youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: FDA-approved PARP inhibitors have demonstrated great efficacy for BRCA-mutated (or homologous recombination repair (HRR)-deficient) cancers in preclinical and clinical studies, but limited efficacy for HRR- proficient cancers. With the aim to expand the clinical application to majority of cancer patients and address the inefficient delivery and off-target toxicity, this project will provide a safe and effective formulation for efficient and selective codelivery of DNA methylation inhibitor azacytidine and PARP inhibitors into tumor tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart valve disease affects ~13% of the US population over 75 years old, but interestingly, men have a two- fold higher risk for developing calcified valves whereas women tend to present with severely fibrotic valves. This proposal aims to investigate these sex differences, particularly the dynamic interplay between sex-specific immune cell interactions with resident valve interstitial cells, which subsequently leads to increasing valve fibrosis and calcification. Our approach includes the 3D culture of valve interstitial cells in hydrogel matrices that mimic the valve microenvironment, as well as mouse models that can mimic valve disease, and then use these models to identify small molecule drugs, specific for men and women, that could mediate fibro- calcification of their heart valves.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite tobacco use being the leading preventable cause of death in the United States, over 51 million U.S. adults continue to use tobacco products. This research proposal could substantially advance treatment development for tobacco use disorders and addictions broadly by evaluating the validity of the VR-AB biomarker for use as a predictive and/or surrogate endpoint in clinical smoking cessation trials. The validation of reliable biomarkers of addiction such as attentional bias would greatly benefit treatment development by providing earlier identification of treatment efficacy, thus shortening trial lengths and costs considerably, and by the identification of subpopulations, or biotypes, that may be more likely to respond to a given treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain is a predictive organ: its memories of the past are used to adaptively guide behavior in anticipation of events that might occur seconds, minutes, hours, or longer in the future. This project will uncover how the brain can simultaneously represent anticipatory signals at multiple timescales, how these signals are influenced by top-down goals, and how they can guide future-oriented behavior. Understanding how hierarchical anticipation signals support behavior at a range of timescales will yield important insights into how flexible, future-oriented actions are planned and implemented in a constantly changing world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Prostate cancer impacts the lives of ~190,000 men diagnosed each year in the United States and, given the high 5-year relative survival rate of >95%, approaches to minimize treatment toxicities are needed. Bladder and rectal toxicities resulting from prostate cancer radiotherapy are dose-limiting, costly to the healthcare system, and negatively impact quality of life. This study will apply our novel machine learning method to develop and validate integrated dose-volume-genetic risk models for late bladder and rectal toxicity and assess feasibility of incorporating these models into clinical workflow as a critical step towards giving Radiation Oncologists the tools they need to personalize therapy and reduce toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative A variety of experimental methods, most notably the Hi-C assay, have been developed to measure the chromatin 3D architecture that is often represented in the form of a “contact matrix.” Despite considerable progress in analyzing these contact matrices, computational tools that can perform joint analyses of Hi-C and other types of data are still lacking, hindering the progress toward deciphering the relationship between genome structure and function. Here, we propose to develop novel machine learning methods that can integrate time-course Hi-C data and RNA-seq data, co-embed genome sequences, and low-coverage contact data for resolution enhancement, and translate between Hi-C and ATAC-seq.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative. Proprioception is the ability to internally sense limb position and posture and is encoded by sensory neurons called proprioceptors, which transform changes in muscle length and force into electrical signals that are transmitted to locomotor circuits in the spinal cord. Normal proprioceptor function is essential for purposeful movement and is impaired in a variety of conditions, including spinal cord injury, aging, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; however, little is known about how electrical signals in proprioceptors are sent. This research will enhance scientific understanding of mammalian proprioception by systematically defining how voltage-gated sodium channels (NaVs) differentially shape proprioceptive signaling in the healthy nervous system, with important implications for understanding and ultimately treating conditions in which proprioception is impaired.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perinatal depression (PND) affects 10-20% of women during pregnancy and for a year following birth and increases the risk of morbidity for mothers and infants, but because the causes and risk factors for PND are largely unknown, clinicians can predict neither which women are at risk nor the most beneficial preventive interventions and precise treatments. Our initial results in a small sample of low-income women of color showed that multiple bacterial metabolic processes in the mother’s gastrointestinal tract were associated with depressive symptom severity early in pregnancy. We propose to use systems biology approaches, such as machine learning and network modeling, to predict, identify the mechanisms, and determine causal role of maternal gut microorganisms in PND to reduce the negative consequences of this debilitating disorder for the mother, the infant, and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Swallowing difficulties are extremely common and symptoms of dysphagia result in a substantial reduction in the quality of life for patients regardless of the cause. Unfortunately, our current understanding of the physiologic causes of these symptoms is limited by a lack of tools to accurately measure the mechanics of esophageal emptying. This proposal will utilize new analysis techniques to better understand the causes of esophageal dysfunction to determine methods to improve esophageal function and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in people with type 1 diabetes (T1D), and is largely preventable. CVD disproportionately affects Hispanic and non-Hispanic Black people with T1D, but little is know about the factors contributing to these disparities. Our study is uniquely positioned to advance scientific understanding of disparities in CVD risk early in the T1D disease course by leveraging the comprehensive, longitudinal data available from the racially/ethnically diverse SEARCH sample coupled with novel CVD assessments in young adulthood. With continued increase in T1D incidence, especially in Hispanic and NHB youth, the number of individuals living with this condition is projected to triple by 2050, forecasting a substantial rise in the societal burden of managing T1D and preventing its CVD comorbidities. This work has the potential to inform the design of multi-level interventions to prevent CVD in individuals at highest risk due to T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Asthma is characterized by chronic inflammation and airway thickening in the conducting airways leading to respiratory symptoms, lung function decline, and exacerbation. Aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) is an important modulator of host-environment interactions and inflammation, suggesting it may have a key role in asthma pathogenesis. We propose that activation of the AhR signaling in airway smooth muscle (ASM) will reduce inflammation-induced airway hyperresponsiveness and remodeling in asthma. Our studies using human ASM from both non-asthmatics vs. asthmatics, along with animal studies, where we knockout AhR in smooth muscle, will substantially enhance our understanding of how AhR in ASM influence the asthmatic airway structure and function. This is a clinically important step to gain basic fundamental knowledge in the development of novel therapeutic strategies to mitigate remodeling aspects of asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: N/A – Public Health Relevance remains unchanged SPECIFIC AIMS Type 1 diabetes (T1D) results from the destruction of insulin producing β-cells upon immune infiltration and inflammation of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas (insulitis). Lifelong insulin therapy is required, although patients remain at risk for both chronic diabetic complications and potentially fatal hypoglycemia. Prior to clinical onset of T1D there is an asymptomatic phase of many years during which β-cell mass and function progressively declines but glucose homeostasis remains normal. This ‘pre-symptomatic’ phase presents a window for therapeutic intervention. Indeed, immune therapies under investigation have shown some success in blunting β-cell decline, with antiCD3 recently receiving FDA approval. However, there are limited means for detecting and tracking the development of insulitis in this ‘pre-symptomatic’ T1D window to guide therapeutic interventions. Further, there is a complete lack of means to track the response to preventative treatment, prior to T1D onset. Clinical imaging modalities have been investigated to detect signatures of insulitis and β-cell decline but have either shown limited success in human subjects or are not practical for widescale deployment. Ultrasound imaging presents many advantages for clinical deployment, including widespread availability and absence of ionizing radiation. Gas-filled microbubble (MB) contrast agents are clinically approved, and are used in detection, therapy and monitoring of a wide range of diseases. We previously used contrast-enhanced ultrasound to detect signatures of insulitis in pre-clinical models based on factors such as altered pancreas perfusion or microvascular leakiness that occur during T1D. While these studies provide support for using contrast-enhanced ultrasound to guide and track therapeutic interventions in ‘pre-symptomatic’ T1D, there exists high potential for further advancements. A key limitation of pancreas imaging in T1D is that islets of Langerhans represent only a few % of the pancreas volume, diluting any disease signature by background signal and reducing sensitivity. Thus, high-resolution approaches are needed to view the specific disease signatures in T1D. Ultrasound localization microscopy (ULM) is an emerging super-resolution microvascular imaging technique that provides microvessel-level spatial resolution noninvasively in vivo, thus potentially enabling the resolution of specific T1D disease associated changes in the pancreas. Our overall goal is to apply ULM and signal processing in combination with novel ultrasound contrast agents to detect disease signatures associated with T1D, to provide image-based guidance and tracking of therapeutic interventions. We will conduct 3 specific aims:  Aim 1: Ultrasound localization microscopy of vascular impairments in the pancreas. The pancreas microvasculature and blood flow change during T1D progression. We will perform ULM with size isolated MBs (SIMBs; 1, 3 & 5 µm diameter), where SIMBs are highly echogenic and will optimize ULM efficiency. ULM will be used to noninvasively map the pancreas microvasculature and flow dynamics to identify vascular impairments associated with insulitis in T1D progression, using murine models. These measurements will be compared with histological analysis of islet microvasculature and insulitis. Aim 2: Mapping the distribution of nanodrop accumulation and microvascular leakiness across the pancreas. Increased microvascular permeability occurs in the pancreas upon chronic inflammation during T1D. Nanodrops (NDs) accumulate within the islet microenvironment during T1D and provide contrast following acoustic vaporization. We will synthesize long-circulating ‘size-isolated’ NDs (SINDs; 0.2, 0.6 & 1.0 µm diameter), that vaporize at clinical MI (<0.7) and provide improved stability. We will characterize the biodistribution of these SINDs and their specificity to accumulate within the infiltrated islet microenvironment, using both ultrasound contrast imaging with histological analysis, in murine models of T1D. We will also assess conditions where ND vaporization minimizes transient or permanent impact on the islet microenvironment.  Aim 3: Apply molecularly targeted microbubbles and nanodrops to the inflamed and infiltrated islet microenvironment. We will target best performing, optimal sized SIMBs to endothelial cell surface markers of inflammation by incorporating peptide ligands against P-, E- and L-selectin. We will use a buried-ligand surface architecture, where the ligand is protected from complement activation by a PEG overbrush, but which can bind its target marker upon application of ultrasound radiation force. Additionally, we will develop an individual bubble tracking approach to determine binding strength of adherent MBs. We will characterize the sensitivity and specificity of target binding in vitro, and perform similar measurements in vivo in models of T1D.  Impact: Assessing inflammation and immune infiltration in the islet microenvironment using contrast-enhanced ultrasound imaging represents a fundamentally new paradigm for diagnosing and tracking T1D progression during the pre-symptomatic phase of disease. The development and application of size isolated microbubbles, nanodrop agents and functionalized microbubbles, and use of super-resolution ULM techniques, represents further innovations which will have broader impact. Therefore, outcomes of this project will aid in diagnosing both the pace of T1D progression and the efficacy of any preventative treatment prior to clinical onset. There also exists viable routes to the clinic for both the contrast agents and ULM techniques for early disease monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA reductase (HMGCR) immune mediated necrotizing myopathy (IMNM) is an increasingly recognized, severe subset of autoimmune myopathy that causes significant muscle weakness, morbidity, and often permanent physical disability. High quality data, such as from randomized placebo- controlled trials (RCTs), on effective treatment for anti-HMGCR IMNM and understanding of disease immune- pathogenesis are highly limited; and these uncertainties pose a critical barrier to improving outcomes for patients. We will combine clinical and translational approaches to conduct a pilot, exploratory RCT evaluating IVIG (a promising therapy for this condition) as treatment for HMGCR myopathy and leverage this RCT to advance understanding of the potential role of HMGCR-specific CD4+ T cells in disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: REDDCAT2 Project Narrative Often unmet social needs are identified in the course of clinical care; however, there is no streamlined process to comprehensively and proactively identify and address the most important health-related social needs at the time of hospitalization. The goal of the comparative effectiveness trial is to assess the impact of REDD-CAT on medical service outcomes, diabetes outcomes, and underlying social determinants at 30-days and 90-days following discharge. In partnership with the patient, the REDDCAT2 patient navigator will prioritize reported social needs at the hospital bedside and provide post-discharge navigation support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chromosomal-breaking agents (i.e. clastogens), including ionizing radiation, remain a cornerstone of cancer therapy; nevertheless, their efficacy could be improved by inhibiting the repair of chromosomal breaks in cancer cells. Indeed, inhibitors of the DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit (DNAPKcs) are being developed for this approach; but to identify the ideal contexts for using such inhibitors, it is critical to understand the role of DNAPKcs in chromosomal break repair, which is the focus of the parent grant and the project in this supplement application. The proposed studies on this project, and training plan for the candidate Ms. Kaela Makins, will support the mission of the NIH to improve cancer treatments and patient outcomes, and advance the specific goals of in this supplement program to enhance diversity in health-related research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative Statement Opioid use disorder (OUD) has staggering public health implications, and the current best treatments (medications for opioid use disorder or MOUD) are only marginally effective. This proposal seeks to validate a tool to identify digital biomarkers of craving during MOUD using a wearable sensor, describe distinct trajectories of craving, and identify OUD disease subtypes based on physiologic and clinical data. The resultant algorithms will support real-time precision treatment strategies, predict MOUD responsiveness, and allow tailored prescribing based on dynamic assessment craving.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Methamphetamine (MA) use disorder is a widespread problem among veterans and has great public health relevance but there are no FDA-approved medications for treatment. Abnormalities in the dopamine system are hallmark characteristics of MA addiction, and studies show that dopamine function can predict the success of treatment outcomes. Medications, however, aimed at regulating dopamine have been unsuccessful. Both MA use and neuroinflammation dysregulate dopamine signaling but the mechanistic link between MA-induced neuroinflammation and dopamine brain function in humans has not been studied. This project, using multi- modal neuroimaging techniques will identify whether ibudilast, an anti-inflammatory agent reduces MA-induced neuroinflammation resulting in improved brain function, connectivity and behavior. If inflammation is associated with brain deficits and ibudilast is proven effective in restoring the integrity of neural networks, the results have the potential to advance therapeutic strategies by identifying neuroinflammation as a critical biomarker.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Joints are used for everyday movements and ligament injury compromises joint health due to the fibrous scar tissue that forms and alters native joint movement. This proposed work will use the highly regenerative zebrafish as a model to study ligament regeneration to gain insight into the molecular factors promoting ligament regeneration vs. fibrosis after injury. By understanding the mechanisms driving scar-free ligament regeneration, we can better develop future therapies for acute ligament injury that will rebuild native tissue while also preventing fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to address the important problem of currently being unable to accurately predict the course of multiple sclerosis (MS) in individual people. In ongoing efforts to improve care, we are developing a multi-faceted approach to readily predict and monitor (through state- of-the-art high-resolution brain and retinal imaging) disease severity and progression, in order to guide individualized therapeutic decision-making among people with MS. The clinical need for the predictive tools in MS being developed in this study are an utmost priority given the expanding number of increasingly more effective and potent treatments that may be associated with serious and potentially life-threatening complications.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the emerging resistance of malaria parasites to first-line artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), new antimalarial drug combinations are urgently needed. Triple ACTs (TACTs) have been identified as the most feasible and affordable alternative solution to ACTs. The combination of artemether with both lumefantrine and amodiaquine is an example of a TACT that benefits from the longer-acting partner drugs, lumefantrine and amodiaquine, having different and potentially opposing resistance mechanisms. However, children with severe acute malnutrition and adults living with HIV are two key subgroups that have been excluded from early dose optimisation studies and Phase 3 studies of this promising TACT, yet . This project will investigate artemether-lumefantrine plus amodiaquine’s disposition and safety in these two key target subgroups. they are at a high risk of malaria adverse outcomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal fear regulation is observed in psychiatric disorders, particularly PTSD, a debilitating condition afflicting 8% of civilians and about 22% of combat veterans annually. Growing evidence supports an association of autoimmune conditions and severe asthma with PTSD prevalence and risk, however contributory mechanisms are not clear. Using cell-circuit approaches and transgenic manipulations, this R01 will identify T cell-derived inflammatory mediators, cellular substrates and unique forebrain circuits involved in asthma-driven fear dysregulation relevant to PTSD.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria infection during pregnancy causes red blood cells containing the malaria parasite to attach to the placenta, the organ vital for development and growth of the baby during pregnancy. Placenta infection with malaria disrupts placental function and is linked to poor pregnancy outcomes like low birth weight, premature birth, and stillbirth. This proposal will seek to determine the biological effects through which placental malaria alters placental function and identify strategies for exploiting this knowledge for the development of placental malaria interventions as well as tools for placental malaria detection during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A first episode of psychosis is a leading cause of disability in young adults, with high risk of suicide and all cause mortality. A substantial part of the burden and cost relates to poor functional outcomes, and the inability to determine the right antipsychotic treatment during the earliest phases of psychotic illness, particularly for those who might need clozapine, a medication that is already known to work best for those who do not respond to conventional antipsychotics. In patients with a first episode of psychosis, the present study aims to determine whether the use of biomarker guided treatment decisions leads to better outcomes and equivalent side effects in people prescribed clozapine compared to conventional antipsychotics, including changes in brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Cisplatin is a very effective cancer therapy drug, but it is associated with development of chronic kidney disease (CKD) in up to 65% of the patients resulting in a significant public health burden of reduced long-term health and quality of life that remains unaddressed. Understanding how manipulating tubular O2•– dismutation in Cisplatin- induced CKD impacts mitochondrial function is expected to provide essential data needed for future clinical trial design to reduce CKD burden. This proposal is relevant to the NIH-NIDDK's mission to conduct and support medical research to improve people's health and quality of life using innovative methods, pre-clinically relevant models, and translational tools to develop approaches for repairing damaged tissues, i.e., Cisplatin-damaged kidney tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT For adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors, the impacts of treatment are significant and long-lasting, including difficult physical symptoms (e.g., pain, fatigue), emotional distress, and an increased risk of long-term health problems. Engagement in recommended follow-up care is critical; yet, the proportion of AYA survivors who engage in follow-up care rapidly declines with age and time since treatment, resulting in inadequate surveillance for late effects and missed opportunities for symptom management, psychological support, and health promotion. The proposed study examines the efficacy of an accessible digital health intervention, AYA STEPS (Symptom Management and Transitioning to Engagement with Post-Treatment Care for AYA Survivors), that is designed to enhance the ability of AYA cancer survivors to manage their high symptom burden and engage in recommended follow-up care by improving self-efficacy for symptom management and patient activation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  There are no small molecules in existence that inhibit CAPON-induced tau aggregation and neurodegeneration in the human brain. The proposed research is relevant to public health as small molecule CAPON inhibitors can lead to therapeutic agents for Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate how the body’s internal circadian clock contributes to a mysterious phenomenon in asthma called asthma remission, in which some children outgrow the disease as they physically mature. Applying the knowledge gained by this project could lead to fewer hospitalizations for patients, improved quality of life, and broad benefits to public health. The information produced by this project could ultimately help doctors increase the likelihood that asthmatic children will grow out of their asthma, shifting the goals of asthma treatment from symptom control to cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative (Relevance) Cisplatin, a widely used chemotherapy drug, elicits both acute and chronic side-effects in kidneys. This application investigates the reciprocal regulation between NF-kB and DNA methylation in persistent renal inflammation as a cause of the chronic side-effect of cisplatin in kidneys. Completion of the work will not only advance the understanding of the chronic kidney problems after cisplatin chemotherapy, but may also identify NF-kB and DNA methylation as novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Concussion, or mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI), is the most common neurological condition seen in both children and adults, and the incidence of concussions is increasing with a growing awareness of the possible consequences of repetitive concussions on brain health. We identified a protein that protects cognition and accelerates recovery after moderate TBI. The current studies will address whether therapeutics that target this protein can be used to promote recovery after a single mild TBI, paving the way for future drug development for human use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic orofacial pain conditions are unified by high levels of pain-related disability, maladaptive coping (e.g., fear avoidance and catastrophic thinking about pain) and emotional distress (e.g., depression and anxiety). The proposed study will develop, iteratively refine, and establish the feasibility, acceptability and credibility of Face-Forward-Web, the first psychosocial intervention developed through mixed-methods, designed specifically for adults with heterogeneous chronic orofacial pain, and delivered through web-platform (this population’s preferred treatment modality). Face-Forward-Web bypasses key accessibility and scalability-related limitations of existing interventions (including challenges with talk- based therapy, which is often painful and limits engagement in this population) and has the potential to dramatically improve pain, pain-related activity limitations and distress in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abasic sites in DNA arise spontaneously and as a consequence of many environmental sources including oxidizing agents, nitrosamines, and radiation. In this project we study the mechanisms that recognize and repair these lesions with a focus on a new pathway that we discovered that acts to protect abasic sites in single-stranded DNA from deleterious processing. Completing this project will provide a molecular understanding of how cells manage a common form of DNA damage that is formed in response to many environmental agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients who undergo surgery to remove liver cancers experience recurrence of their cancer within a few years. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rigorous study of factors that contribute to life-course health and aging of the immigrant population in the US cannot be examined adequately based on US data sources alone. This project will establish and analyze linked samples of households in origins and destinations using conventional as well as innovative sampling designs and unique administrative data on sensitive life-stage exposures. Data from this project will improve the understanding of the countervailing forces promoting and undermining Sub-Saharan African immigrant health over time using Ghana as a case study, from where migrant flows to the U.S. have been considerable and increasing in recent decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Thalamocortical communications underlie processes of perception, attention, memory, emotions, and the sleep- wake cycle, and are disrupted in schizophrenia, but the underlying mechanisms of pathology are unknown. The goals of the proposed research project are to test the hypotheses that focal “core” and more widespread “matrix” thalamocortical pathways are differentially affected in schizophrenia, through mechanisms that involve distinct changes in their structure, physiology, and laminar interactions with cortical inhibitory neurons in medial, orbital, and lateral prefrontal cortices. Findings will help us model typical and abnormal brain function and provide the foundation to understand heterogeneous disruption of these networks in sleep disorders, attention deficits, and cognitive and affective impairments in schizophrenia, with important implications for the design of targeted therapeutic interventions.

PHR: Hexokinase 2 (HK2), which catalyzes the first committed step in glucose metabolism, is not expressed in most normal adult tissues but is induced in cancer cells. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to increase the number of Latinas meeting and adhering to physical activity guidelines by integrating stress reduction strategies into their daily life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Müller glial cells within the retina of non-mammalian species can regenerate retinal neurons and reverse blindness, while mammalian retinae cannot. We have recently determined that the Hippo signaling pathway functions as a molecular block to Müller glial cell-mediated retinal regeneration in mice, but the precise molecular inputs regulating this response are unknown. By uncovering the mechanism of Hippo pathway regulation specifically in Müller glia, we will establish new therapeutic targets to manipulate this pathway to promote mammalian retinal regeneration to treat blindness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project—the Future of Families and Child Wellbeing (FF) Third Generation Children’s Study—will collect data on the third generation of the FF study. We will collect information on family/caregiving context, parenting and grandparenting behaviors, and child development for all children born to female members of the original birth cohort as these children reach age 5. The data will facilitate novel and important analyses of intergenerational transmission of parenting behaviors, relationships within families, child development, and gene*environment influences on social and economic wellbeing, including health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our lab uses the immune system to treat cancer by reprogramming patients’ immune cells (T cells) to target and kill tumor cells. We developed T cells to treat glioblastoma (GBM), a deadly brain tumor, by directly killing tumor cells and releasing a molecule to help other T cells kill tumor cells. Based on their effectiveness in mouse models of GBM, we are initiating a clinical trial to treat GBM patients and will perform extensive studies to understand how this new therapy works in humans. This therapy will potentially improve GBM patient outcomes and provide valuable data on how to use these cells to treat other tumor types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even though cognitive deficits in schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders have an enormous impact on human health and disability, many patients do not show any cognitive improvement with current antipsychotic medications. Thus, there exists an urgent need to develop insight into the neural substrates and neuroplasticity mechanisms underlying cognition and the discovery of novel antipsychotic medications with the potential to lead to cognitive improvement. This proposal uses innovative, patient-derived iPSC and cerebral organoid techniques to ask mechanistic questions concerning the role of Arc-dependent neuroplasticity in psychotic disorders using high-resolution imaging and functional genomic methods in concert with parallel analysis of clinical outcomes of first-episode psychosis patients treated with lurasidone; it is likely to be of high impact because it focuses on human disease neurobiology in relation to the early stage of psychosis and cognitive deficits in schizophrenia, thereby helping lay a foundation for advancing precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to increase the clinical acceptance of the novel vaccine platform PARVAX by understanding the mechanisms behind its potency and durability, by improving the platform and by testing the efficacy of novel vaccine candidates for other pathogens. The proposed work is highly relevant for pandemic preparedness, since it will derisk the PARVAX platform enabling the rapid design of new candidates for existing and future pathogens. Moreover, the proposed studies will provide insight on the means to improve the durability, breadth and mucosal immunity of other platforms.

PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is the most common neurodegenerative disease and the leading cause of dementia. No cures or disease-modifying treatments are available. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Group A Streptococcus is a top-10 cause of infectious mortality that through several toxins induces distinct cell death programs in different cells of it’s host. Cell death, and the resulting inflammation, contribute to poor patient outcomes during most diseases, including those caused by Streptococci. Understanding the specific molecular mechanisms of death gives therapeutic targets to improve the treatment of necrotizing fasciitis and other severe infections caused by Streptococcus, and tools to more broadly manipulate cell death during infections, aging, cancer, and autoimmune disease.
