IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to evaluate changes in emergency room department utilization, hospitalizations, and uncompensated care among Latinx older adults in Illinois. Using hospital billing and Medicare cost data we leverage a novel natural experiment that expanded health insurance to immigrants previously excluded from health insurance. Our overarching goals is to understand structural inequalities that contribute to health disparities among aging Latinx adults and evaluate potential policy and practice interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Protein kinases and lipid kinases have ATP pockets that are druggable and inhibitors of these two families of enzymes have been approved for treating cancers that have activating mutations in genes encoding these protein or lipid kinases. Yet, mass spec phosphoproteomics reveal that many cancers without obvious genetic aberrations in lipid or protein kinases have enhanced phosphorylation and activation of enzymes that drive anabolic processes. The focus of the proposed research is to utilize the software developed during the previous funding period (described above) to determine what protein kinases are likely to be driving growth of cancers based on changes in phosphorylation in the cancer compared to normal tissue and use this information to identify the appropriate protein kinase inhibitor to treat the cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the study of regional variation and inequities in the U.S. health care system, too little attention has been paid to the measurement of health care and health “regions,” accounting for heterogeneity across regions, the lack of representation of the full population, and other forms of bias that could affect conclusions drawn from analyses based on Medicare data. Shortfalls include outdated measures based on data 30 years old (e.g., changes in hospital location and numbers), the failure of regions to capture rapidly changing health care markets (e.g., increasingly interwoven health care delivery in the U.S. due to health system mergers and the rise of specialist hospitals), and the inability to generalize to various sub-populations (especially historically and economically marginalized groups). This project seeks to address these concerns by utilizing the latest innovations in network and geospatial analyses to define new analysis areas for health care markets in the U.S. (and a user-friendly tool for forming them), allowing for heterogeneity across population strata and the construction of regional health disparity indices, and the development of statistical methods to account for sources of bias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: In patients affected by periodontitis, after controlling the disease, periodontists and general dentists need to perform regenerative procedures to re-establish the normal anatomy and function of the periodontium. However current regenerative therapies are ineffective as they are unable to fully regenerate the missing periodontal tissues. With the final goal of developing more effective periodontal regenerative therapies, this research proposal aims at characterizing the periodontal stem cells and at identifying strategies to harness them to endogenously sustain periodontal regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Over 90% of Americans are exposed to the flame-retardant chemical tris(1,3-dichloro-2- propyl) phosphate (TDCPP). TDCPP exposure is positively associated with metabolic syndrome in men, but women are protected from its harmful effects. The proposed studies interrogate the role of nuclear receptors and sex hormones in conferring sex-specific metabolic disruption associated with TDCPP exposure, which will drive our knowledge toward interventions and screening strategies for less harmful flame retardants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Tuberculosis (TB) is the leading cause of death from an infectious pathogen, and more advanced strategies are needed to curb the global epidemic. We aim to develop an innovative, low cost, efficacious protein and adjuvant vaccine candidate for therapeutic protection given in conjunction with drug treatment against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. We expect our findings will lead to understanding key protective immune correlates in the context of therapy, which will also positively impact TB patients and those striving to cure TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Patients and healthcare providers are increasingly using the patients' portal messaging system for communication. In this study, we propose to extract different types of electronic patient-provider communication (EPPC) in the portal such as information seeking/giving and shared decision making using an innovative natural language processing and machine learning based tool called EPPCminer. We will characterize the distribution of EPPC types in messages and assess the impact of EPPC types on patients' outcomes including adherence, emergency visits and hospitalizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE In this proposal, our overall goal is to examine how two biological processes involved in aging and age-related conditions, cellular senescence and epigenetic alterations, influence adaptations to exercise training in older adults. We will conduct a randomized controlled clinical trial comparing the effects of 6-months of strength training to a health education program on measures of physical function and whole-body metabolism in persons 65 years of age and older. Using risk modeling approaches, we examine how the biological processes, clinical variables (e.g., sex, chronic conditions, medications), and behaviors (e.g., nutrition and sleep), and their interactions, influence changes in these clinically important outcomes in study participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: EZH2 is a well-known histone lysine methyltransferase and an oncogene upregulated in many types of cancer, including prostate cancer. In this project, we will investigate how EZH2 methylates its novel substrate PARP1, and how EZH2-mediated PARP1 methylation in prostate cancer. In addition, we will study how EZH2 plays its role in PARP inhibition-resistant prostate cancer. Successful completion of this project will provide novel mechanistic insights EZH2’s novel functions in DNA damage repair and transcription regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health, because there is an unmet need for more effective treatment of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), and our proposed research is focused on evaluating a new agent, a recombinant human protein known as PEPDG278D, for its therapeutic activity in preclinical models of NSCLC by potentially targeting the key vulnerability of therapy-resistant NSCLC cells. Given that PEPDG278D has not shown toxicity in previous animal studies, promising results from the proposed research may lay the groundwork for potential clinical development of this agent for treating NSCLC. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NCI’s mission that pertains to accelerating scientific discovery to reduce the burden of cancer and suffering of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research proposal focuses on the development and refinement of innovative image processing and analytical methods that will substantially improve detection of glaucoma and the identification and prediction of its progression in order to prevent blindness. We will develop technology to improve optical coherence tomography (OCT) signal and image quality and harmonize OCTs such that it is possible to be agnostic as to device manufacturer or model. Finally, we will use recently developed analytical techniques including multidimensional information compression analysis (MICA) and enhanced machine learning and deep learning models incorporating clinical features in addition to OCT and visual fields to significantly improve glaucoma detection and the identification of progression and prediction of future disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Lymphedema affects approximately 200 million patients globally and is associated with regional accumulation of lymph fluid due to obstructions to the lymphatic vessels, accompanied by compromise of local immune function and, ultimately, irreversible structural changes of the affected tissues. To bridge the region of lymphatic obstruction, we propose the implantation of nanofibrillar collagen conduits for driving capillary flow and promoting lymphatic regeneration. These proposed studies aim to develop a novel biomaterials-based therapeutic strategy and then to test its therapeutic efficacy in rodent models of lymphedema.

PHR: Narrative Pancreas cancer is the third leading cause of cancer death in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite strong associative evidence of a gut-joint axis driving inflammatory arthritis such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and spondyloarthritis (SpA), the specific mechanisms by which microbes or their products trigger intestinal immune dysregulation in the context of inflammatory arthritis have not been elucidated. The goal of this project is to define one pathway – tryptophan catabolism to indole – by which bacterial dysbiosis of RA and SpA contribute to pathogenic T and B cell responses relevant to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Our team has created a plant virus nanotechnology that, when injected into tumors, alters the tumor environment to boost immune responses against the tumor - this method has shown effectiveness in mouse tumor models and canine cancer patients. However, challenges like large tumors needing multiple injections and high fluid pressure in tumors can limit its success. This grant aims to design slow-release polymer blends as injectables, to simplify the procedure and reduce repeat doses. Effectiveness will be evaluated in mice and dogs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Mobile computed tomography (CT) is widely used in the neuro intensive care units (ICU) to reduce the risk during the transportation of critically ill patients to a fixed CT scanner. However, it suffers from deteriorated image quality compared to a fixed scanner and is insufficient for the diagnosis of small lesions. In this project, we propose to leverage the benefits from a photon-counting mobile CT, as well as deep learning-based image reconstruction algorithms, to improve the image quality of mobile CT to or beyond the level of a fixed CT scanner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Several studies have found a positive effect of increasing brain activity levels on rehabilitation outcomes in stroke, but the large heterogeneity among individual patients limits the efficiency of existing stimulation treatments. This application will identify cellular- and system-level mechanisms of post-stroke rehabilitation in rats and link them to motor recovery. Results will introduce the basis for a new paradigm to tailor the treatment protocol to the animal condition, where monitoring brain activity near the injured brain region will provide essential information to tune the treatment parameters and to promote recovery of lost motor skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors dramatically improve prognosis for many cancer patients but come at the cost of a new class of immune-related adverse events that reduce overall quality-of-life and the net benefit of treatment. This proposal seeks to automatically detect immune-related adverse event phenotypes from the electronic health record to support timely, data-driven cancer care that enhances survivorship. To achieve this goal, we will develop and clinically validate advanced informatics and artificial intelligence technologies, such as deep learning language models, to automate immune-related adverse event monitoring and data collection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human genome is stored in the nucleus, a compartment segregated by a double membrane which is spanned by large proteinaceous assemblies acting as its exclusive and selective gateways, the so-called nuclear pore complexes (NPCs). As such, defects in the NPC are associated with a broad set of human diseases, including aggressive forms of cancer and neurodegenerative disorders, and its components are commonly targeted by many viruses to dampen the host’s antiviral response. Our research focuses on obtaining atomic-level snapshots of the NPC to understand how it mediates the relay of information encoded by the genome, and how its dysfunction relates to human health and disease.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative At first glance, lymphatic filariasis (LF) may appear as an obscure tropical disease, overlooked by many and as such there exist no standard protocol in managing LF manifestation and related complications, thus makes this very worrying. LF-associated manifestations, especially lymphedema (LE) involves crisis of recurrent wounds and infections that impacts chronic pain, disfigurement, disability, and economic devastation that disproportionately impacts marginalized communities, trapping them in a cycle of poverty and despair (Asiedu et al., 2022). Understanding the critical importance of this problem is paramount hence, through this comprehensive career development program, we seek to characterise microbial communities that colonise the debilitating chronic filarial wounds associated to help establish LF-specific genomic library that guide evidence-based interventions that empower communities and restore their health and dignity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep-wake disturbances are a major factor associated with reduced quality of life of individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD), a progressive neurological disorder affecting millions of people in the U.S and worldwide. The brain mechanisms underlying these sleep disorders, and the effects of therapeutic interventions such as deep brain stimulation on sleep-related neuronal activity and sleep behavior, are not well understood. Results from this preclinical study will provide a better understanding of the brain circuitry involved in disordered sleep in parkinsonism and inform the development of targeted therapeutic interventions to treat sleep disorders in people with neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: CENTRE FOR ADDICTION AND MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A first episode of psychosis is a leading cause of disability in young adults, with high risk of suicide and all-cause mortality. A substantial part of the burden and cost relates to poor functional outcomes, and the inability to determine the right antipsychotic treatment during the earliest phases of psychotic illness, particularly for those who might need clozapine, a medication that is already known to work best for those who do not respond to conventional antipsychotics. In patients with a first episode of psychosis, the present study aims to determine whether the use of biomarker-guided treatment decisions leads to better outcomes and equivalent side effects in people prescribed clozapine compared to conventional antipsychotics, including changes in brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is one of the leading causes of mortality, but we have not yet discovered treatments that significantly reverse the lung damage of COPD. In this project, we will study an important cell type for COPD, human airway epithelial cells (HAECs), and we will understand how genetic differences between individuals can increase risk for COPD by their effects on alternative splicing in HAECs. We will use advanced long read sequencing and proteomic technologies, as well as deep learning models of alternative splicing to identify how COPD-causing genetic differences that affect splicing have broader effects on the biological processes and cellular functions of HAECs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cognitive fluctuations – called “the Lewy Roller Coaster” by families – are a debilitating symptom of Lewy body disorders, including Parkinson’s Disease (PD) and Lewy Body Dementias (LBD). This proposal seeks to model cognitive fluctuations using alpha-synuclein in the ascending arousal network with the hope of understanding underlying mechanisms and uncovering targets for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Natural transformation is a multi-step process used by bacteria to take up DNA from the environment, thereby acquiring new traits. These include genes that contribute to antibiotic resistance, virulence, and immune evasion. This proposal will elucidate the three major steps of bacterial transformation: the uptake of DNA from the environment across the cell wall, the transport of DNA across the membrane into the cytoplasm, and the recombination of DNA into the recipient cell chromosome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because the study aims to adapt and finalize our web app based on acceptance and commitment therapy for family caregivers of people with dementia and to test its feasibility, acceptability, and usability. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Cholera was introduced into Haiti in 2010, with over 820,000 reported cases and close to 10,000 deaths. After the initial epidemic peak, case numbers declined, with no clinical cases officially reported after February 2018 until September 2022, when cholera recurred in epidemic form. The current proposal explores causes for the 2022 recurrence of cholera in Haiti.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac fibrosis contributes to the progression of heart failure, but there is no FDA-approved drug specifically targeting cardiac fibrosis due to the lack of understanding of the underlying mechanism and a reliable drug discovery platform. This proposal will leverage state-of-the-art iPSC biology, tissue engineering, animal models, and single-cell multiome analyses to elucidate the underlying mechanisms for cardiac fibrosis. We expect to identify new treatments for patients with cardiac fibrosis and heart failure which is an unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorders are characterized by the development of tolerance, escalation of use, and withdrawal upon abstinence, leading to compulsive use in some individuals. In this proposal, we explore the role of habenula- interpeduncular circuit activity at the molecular and cellular levels in behavioral expression of tolerance and withdrawal to oxycodone and probe whether NOS1 is critical for these drug adaptations. We hope that our findings may open new avenues of research for development of therapies to treat addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: (Did not change) Dietary intake of the essential nutrient choline is typically below requirements; although supplemental choline improves cognitive outcomes in those who experience heavy prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE), how it confers this benefit is unclear. This proposal tests the hypothesis that polymorphisms in genes known to alter choline needs also alter vulnerability to the behavioral deficits that typify those with PAE; these variants may identify those who benefit most from choline intervention. Findings inform the mechanisms underlying choline’s protective action and facilitate optimization of choline interventions for alcohol-exposed pregnancies and those who experienced PAE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multipurpose prevention technologies (MPTs) coupling a broad-spectrum antiviral agent against HSV, and other sexually transmitted infections, with a contraceptive offer user-controlled convenience with the potential to drive product use. We will use state-of-the-art biology, chemistry, biomedicine, and pharmacology to develop novel nonhormonal contraceptives and formulate them with a lead antiviral peptide into an innovative intravaginal ring for extended delivery. The proposed research is relevant to public health, in the U.S. and globally, because a convenient, user-administered MPT will slow the spread of sexually transmitted infections and decrease unintended pregnancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section   Childhood obesity continues to rise at an alarming rate “making it one of the most common pediatric chronic diseases in the US”. In children, excess fat on the thorax exerts an unfavorable burden on the respiratory system, particularly during exercise, reducing lung function, exercise tolerance, and provoking exertional breathlessness. However, it is unknown if an increase in obesity with aging worsens respiratory function, exercise tolerance, or dyspnea on exertion (DOE). To answer this question, we will re-examine body composition, lung function, exercise tolerance, and DOE in children with and without obesity who were originally studied as 8–12-year-olds; these results will have broad mechanistic relevance to our understanding of the effects of worsening obesity as children age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Infant brain development is associated with precisely timed epochs of high regional ‘plasticity’, time windows in which interventions can have substantial and life-long impact on the developing brain. The goal of this study is to characterize mechanisms of human neonatal plasticity and measure how interventions influence highly plastic brain regions. The results of this study will be useful in targeting specific interventions to specific brain regions when they are most plastic, thereby reducing psychiatric risk by optimizing brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Copper, because of its function as a redox cofactor and its prevalence in enzymes that catalyze reactions with oxygen (O2) or oxygenated substrates, is an essential micronutrient for most aerobic organisms, and hence for human health. Organisms sense nutritional Cu deficiency and respond by turning on a suite of genes, which in Chlamydomonas is dependent on a transcription factor, CRR1, to facilitate copper economy and copper- dependent metabolism. CRR1 is degraded and economy measures are turned off in copper-replete cells. In this project, the investigators will dissect the signaling pathway that responds to copper supply, leading potentially to the discovery of a copper sensor and a mechanistic understanding of the connection between copper-deficiency and hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Suicide is the second leading cause of death among US youth and more research is needed on factors that contribute to risk and resilience to suicide attempts in adolescence. Environmental stress exposures increase risk of suicidal behavior, yet measuring environmental risk is a major challenge for research due to the complex dynamic structure of environment. In this proposal we will use multimodal longitudinal data on thousands of adolescents (i) to develop reproducible methods that quantify environmental risk in multiple cohorts globally; (ii) to better understand disparities in environmental risk and factors that confer resilience in high-risk youth; and (iii) to study biological processes through which environmental stress increases risk of suicide attempts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Measuring proteins in blood samples or tissue biopsies collected from patients participating in cancer clinical trials is essential to understand the effect of promising new treatments on the patient’s body and tumor. These measurements are critical for helping us to determine the best dose and treatment schedule for new cancer drugs, which are important for maximizing treatment success and minimizing side effects or toxicity. Unfortunately, current technological limitations hamper our ability to measure many proteins important to cancer treatment, and our team is working to solve this problem by translating novel technologies to overcome these limitations and thereby facilitate more efficient development of new therapies and improved abilities to select patients for personalized oncology approaches.

PHR: The proposed research will determine how the genomic RNA of MRV becomes detectable by host cells. We will determine how virus entry events influence exposure of RNA, define how accumulation of newly synthesized RNA is controlled by the µ1 outer capsid protein and define a previously unidentified role for RNautophagy in controlling viral RNA turnover.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The University of Alabama at Birmingham UAB Undiagnosed Diseases Program (UAB UDP) provides diagnostic assessments for children and adults with chronic undiagnosed conditions. It is currently a Diagnostic Center of Excellence in the Undiagnosed Diseases Network (UDN). This proposal describes numerous innovations to the UAB UDP, including increased use of telemedicine and a “genome-first” diagnostic approach, the inclusion of basic scientists in a set of diagnostic teams, collaboration with a federally qualified health center to increase diversity of patients seen, and incorporation of a set of bioinformatic and AI-powered tools, all aimed to increase patient access and diversity, as well as to improve diagnostic success rates and turnaround times.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal healing of blood vessels leads to narrowing and failure in half of all procedures for vascular blockages. Currently, balloons coated with medications to prevent this problem are delivered from inside the vessel, yet significant drug is washed off by the bloodstream and delivery to the vessel target remains poor. This project will investigate a chambered retrievable stent to reduce drug loss in the bloodstream, allow use of higher dose medications, improve exposure time to the drug, and may improve the treatment of recurrent vascular narrowing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a devastating rare lung disease of older adults marked by progressive respiratory failure for which there remains a significant unmet need for effective medical therapies. Lung epithelial cell dysfunction associated with disrupted cell quality control including an exuberant unfolded protein response (UPR)(i.e. endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress) and/or mitochondrial dysfunction has emerged as an important causal contributor to lung fibrosis. This proposal will leverage novel mouse models expressing mutations in the Surfactant Protein C (SFTPC) gene that are associated with human lung fibrosis and will use them characterize the molecular and cellular mechanisms which contribute to epithelial cell dysfunction, emergence of pathological cell states, and the ensuing fibrotic response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Peritoneal metastases have been considered a terminal condition for the majority of patients, but emerging evidence of immune advantages associated with intraperitoneal administration presents opportunities to advance novel therapeutics for these cancers. Intraperitoneal delivery of immunogenic mesoporous silica nanoparticles leads to rapid internalization by free and spheroid-associated myeloid cells with subsequent trafficking to tumor implants. Completion of this project will facilitate clinical translation of nanotechnology platforms for immune therapy of patients with ovarian cancer with broader application to other tumors associated with peritoneal metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project uses linked survey and administrative data to understand the impact of multidimensional and longitudinal measures of integration into U.S. society on older immigrants’ physical and cognitive health. It also leverages a cross-national comparison to uncover the role of federal institutional designs in shaping the integration-health link. The outcomes of this project will help uncover why immigrants experience accelerated health declines over the life course, as well as identify specific areas for policy intervention to reduce racial/ethnic health disparities among immigrants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a leading cause of mortality due to antimicrobial resistance and the transmission of MDR-TB threatens the effective control of TB, especially in countries of the former Soviet Union. There is a gap in our understanding of how specific lineages of M. tuberculosis acquire resistance and maintain high reproductive fitness, allowing them to transmit and cause disease among susceptible hosts. We propose to study of the evolution, transmission, and control of competing lineages of MDR-TB in the Republic of Moldova by applying innovative phylogenetic, statistical, and transmission dynamic modeling approaches to M. tuberculosis isolates and epidemiological data collected since 2010.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to create information that is necessary for the development of means to correct intestinal barrier defects, i.e., reverse “leaky gut,” in inflammatory bowel disease. Such barrier-restoring agents have the potential to be a significant advance in treatment of inflammatory bowel disease and other intestinal and systemic disorders associated with gut barrier loss. Thus, the proposed studies are highly-relevant to the NIDDK mission of supporting research that will improve health and quality of life for those with digestive diseases as well as the NIH mission of seeking and applying fundamental knowledge that will enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in DNA repair genes called BRCA1 and 2 increase pre-disposition to multiple cancers. Currently BRCA mutant cancer cells are treated with inhibitors of Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) enzymes; however, this treatment strategy has multiple limitations. In this proposal, we will develop a framework to overcome the clinical limitations of PARP inhibitors and hence provide an effective strategy for the treatment of BRCA mutant cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Metastases form in a wide range of target organs that vary not only in their chemical composition but also in their mechanical rigidity. We have found that patrolling immune cells preferentially engage and destroy stiffer cancer cells. Our proposed studies will investigate if and how the rigidity of the metastatic microenvironment influences the stiffness dependent killing of cancer cells and, by extension, whether the interplay between tissue mechanics and immune function effectively dictates where metastases grow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroblastoma is a common pediatric cancer that is difficult to effectively treat, especially as it frequently is detected after already metastasizing from a primary site. The norepinephrine transporter (NET) and somatostatin receptor subtype 2 (SSTR2) are well-known biomarkers for neuroblastoma care, to which radiotherapies have been applied with mixed results. In this application we develop a new class of high linear energy transfer therapies that exploit the high expression of these biomarkers for a novel and definitive combination therapy. We evaluate the efficacy, localized tumor control and cellular-genomic effects of this treatment in cultured cell lines and in advanced patient derived models of disease, and compare with conventional treatments. This information will be used to advance these potent agents to improve neuroblastoma patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colon cancer is the second most common cause of cancer death primarily due to the undruggable mutations to KRAS and subsequent lung metastasis with expected survival of only a few months. This proposal develops approaches for inactivating mutant KRAS via RNA-ligand displaying exosomes loaded with dCas9-HDAC1- gRNA ribonucleoprotein, siRNAs, and chemical drugs individually or in combination. The mechanisms of silencing mutant KRAS genes will be investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, we uncover the neural mechanisms of gait and mobility disturbances in preclinical dementia and identify trackable individualized digital biomarkers (from videos). We evaluate the specificity and sensitivity of these gait-based biomarkers and relate those to neural mechanisms and clinical phenotypes. By leveraging these identified markers, we can monitor the disease's progression, potentially minimizing or even replacing the demand for expensive neuropsychological or neuroimaging evaluations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Myeloid cells (microglia and macrophages) can contribute to both tissue injury and repair in retinal diseases. Efferocytosis, a reparative aspect of myeloid cells by which they “eat” and thereby clean up dead cells, is well- studied in some disease conditions, but whether efferocytosis alleviates retinopathy and how this occurs is poorly understood. This proposal is designed to identify new mechanisms involved in efferocytosis with a potential to develop new therapeutic strategies for retinopathies associated with ischemia and trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Heart failure remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality due to both pump failure and lethal arrhythmia. A major barrier to progress in treating these mechanical and electrical problems is the incomplete understanding of cellular mechanisms leading to the disease. In this Project, we will create mathematical models of heart cells and tissues from mice displaying a specific type of heart failure (called heart failure with preserved ejection fraction) to study disease-specific mechanisms, identify druggable targets, and predict implications for treatment of human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PAX3-FOXO1 and related fusions remain elusive targets for drug therapy despite their clear oncogenic role and adverse prognostic impact in rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS), the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. Our recent genetic and biochemical discoveries offer hope that bi-steric mTORC1 inhibitors capable of suppressing cap-dependent translation can directly target PAX3-FOXO1, but molecular insights into the mechanisms for response to such inhibitors are essential to guide us beyond ongoing phase 1 testing. Here, we will test our hypothesis that bi-steric mTORC1 inhibition prevents translation of PAX3-FOXO1 mRNA and thus ablates its oncogenic program and target mechanisms of resistance that limit efficacy in preclinical models, with the long term goal of enabling biologically grounded combination treatments to cure children affected by this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project narrative Lupus is an autoimmune disease with a genetic basis. We have identified a transcription factor, Pbx1, with an altered expression in the immune cells of both mice and people with lupus. The goal of this project is to use a multipronged approach to characterize how Pbx1 regulates the function of healthy and lupus immune cells. The long term of the project is a better understanding of the alterations of the immune system caused by a gene that predispose to lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over-prescription of opioids for surgical pain has contributed at large to the opioid epidemic, so it is important to reduce opioid prescriptions for patients who will receive good pain relief with non-addictive pain relievers, like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Numerous clinical trials of pain management after wisdom tooth extraction surgery have demonstrated that most patients experience good pain relief with NSAIDs alone, but some patients require opioids in addition to NSAIDs. The goal of this project is to identify the factors that contribute to the need for opioid after wisdom tooth extraction to help limit unnecessary opioid prescriptions in patients who will have good pain relief with NSAIDs alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy complications are common in organ transplant recipients, but little is understood about the mechanisms of pathogenesis. Uterine natural killer cells have important roles in pregnancy well-being and are altered by immunosuppression medications taken by transplant recipients. We use a unique model of human uterus transplantation to better understand how immunosuppression agents impact the normal function of uterine natural killer cells and lead to complex pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Statement Preventing or delaying adolescent substance use (SU) is a critical goal because the risk of developing lifelong substance use problems is elevated in individuals who began using as adolescents. The proposed R21 will develop a new analytic model that will improve our ability to make causal inferences between potential intervention targets and SU, and freely provide the code and information on power to maximize its utility for scientists who use large-scale longitudinal data. Our results using this model will also advance understanding of the transactional development of different aspects (i.e., parent- and child-driven) of parental monitoring and adolescent SU, which will be of immediate use to individuals designing and testing adolescent SU prevention and interventions by zeroing in on the specific behaviors most likely to be causally linked to SU and the level at which (individual, family) they influence SU outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 3.5 million US residents have active epilepsy, including >600,000 with temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE), and up to 80% of patients with drug-resistant TLE have impaired memory abilities that have no predictive biomarkers or effective therapies. Our proposed studies aim to understand alterations of gene and protein expression in the temporal lobe that may contribute to memory dysfunction in TLE and to identify biomarkers to stratify patients at high risk for memory impairment. These are crucial first steps in the effort to identify mechanisms of memory impairment in adults with TLE with the future goal of developing evidence-based clinical trials to treat or prevent memory impairment in TLE to improve patient functioning and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The innate immunity is our first-responder system that senses and responds rapidly to virus infection to protect us on a daily basis against infection. Many aspects of how this sensing is propagated, how it protects us from infection, and how it can lead to potentially pathogenic sequelae remain poorly understood. This work will define these processes by studying the neurotropic pathogen West Nile virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A first episode of psychosis is a leading cause of disability in young adults, with high risk of suicide and all cause mortality. A substantial part of the burden and cost relates to poor functional outcomes, and the inability to determine the right antipsychotic treatment during the earliest phases of psychotic illness, particularly for those who might need clozapine, a medication that is already known to work best for those who do not respond to conventional antipsychotics. In patients with a first episode of psychosis, the present study aims to determine whether the use of biomarker guided treatment decisions leads to better outcomes and equivalent side effects in people prescribed clozapine compared to conventional antipsychotics, including changes in brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perceptual awareness is essential to normal human function and is impaired in many cognitive disorders. Complementary imaging, electrical and behavioral approaches will allow us to pinpoint the shared common deep brain regions involved in perception, regardless of whether the stimulus is seen, heard, or felt by touch. Understanding the mechanisms of perception independent of which sensory modality is involved may lead to better, targeted therapies aimed at improving a broad range of disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Normal responses to environmental stimuli are disrupted in many neuropsychiatric disorders, leading to damaging behavioral outcomes. This study will determine the role of the amygdalostriatal transition zone (ASt) - an almost completely unstudied structure - in mediating learned behavioral responses to stimuli that predict rewards or punishments. The proposed research project will increase our knowledge of the fundamental neural mechanisms underlying associative learning and motivated behaviors, and could identify ASt circuits as novel targets of interest for psychological disorders such as anxiety, depression, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Mexico-US immigration is increasingly common and Mexican Americans are one of the fastest growing and aging populations in the United States, yet methodological challenges rooted in migrant selection and the Latino paradox hamper understanding of the effects of their migration experience on ADRD risk. A pooled binational life course dataset with harmonized cognitive outcomes and built-in longitudinal propensity scores of healthy in- migration and unhealthy out-migration provides a unique opportunity to rigorously examine these relationships. In this study, we leverage our previously created pooled binational life course dataset to estimate the association of migration and ADRD risk using the newly improved HCAP data, assess how the socio-political context influences this relationship, and examine underlying biosocial pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Early detection of Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias is vital, with gait speed as a potent predictor, particularly in its early stage of Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). The proposed work investigates cognitive contributions of gait control, focusing on locomotor learning and attentional need for walking, in MCI vs. healthy aging and its relation to basal ganglia networks. This is done aiming to unveil neural mechanisms underlying the relation between mobility and cognitive decline and enhance early ADRD risk prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Poor sleep health (e.g., insufficient sleep duration, fragmented sleep, untreated sleep disorders) is highly prevalent among older adults and associated with increased risk of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). We propose to conduct User Centered Design research that will culturally adapt our existing Sleep Health and Wellness (SHAW) program to the needs of cognitively unimpaired older adults residing in low-income housing in Boston aimed at improving sleep, quality of life, and cognitive function. The SHAW program will be comprised of sleep, mindfulness, and sleep disorders modules, and we propose to disseminate the adapted SHAW modules in a novel social network intervention that identifies, trains, and motivates socially well-connected older adults in each facility to diffuse the SHAW materials through interpersonal communication and small group sessions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lipoproteins are dynamic complexes of lipid and protein in the circulation that are correlated with cardiovascular events. This project will examine a novel functional interaction between the antiinflammatory plasma protein alpha-1-antitrypsin and lipoproteins. These studies will test the hypothesis that lipoproteins influence the function of alpha-1-antitrypsin and this contributes to protection against atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease by reducing vascular inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Approximately 40% of the more than 500,000 women diagnosed globally with locally advanced cervical cancer (LACC) will relapse and die of disease despite receiving curative treatment. We identified a critical bacteria, Lactobacillus iners (L. iners), in the cervical tumor microbiome, which rewires tumor metabolism to utilize lactate and is associated with treatment resistance and poor survival across several cancer types. Our objective is to understand how L. iners influences cervical cancer cells and immune cells (Aim 1) and design novel therapeutics by targeting either tumor resident bacteria (Aim 2) or metabolic effects of tumor resident bacteria (Aim 3) in the tumor and tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE The past two decades have witnessed several air-borne viruses (SARS-CoV1, MERS, SARS-CoV2) that led to significant mortality. Here, we propose to engineer a novel intranasal-delivered nanoparticle that exerts a universal antiviral effect by activating a unique evolution-encoded innate immune state in nasal epithelial cells. This study can shift the paradigm for early interventions in emerging viruses/future pandemics and generate fundamental insights into innate immune sensing of viral nucleic acids.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Streptococcus agalactiae is a Gram positive bacterium that can cause invasive infections during pregnancy which lead to severe disease outcomes including premature rupture of gestational membranes, preterm birth, neonatal sepsis and death. This translational research project seeks to determine if application of human breast milk sugars can prevent S. agalactiae pathogenesis, the host immune response and disease progression. The results from the proposed experiments could lead to new approaches for the prevention of GBS-associated diseases and cost-effective treatment strategies to mitigate the risk of infections during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research focuses on endotypes of Sjögren's disease (SjD), a common systemic autoimmune disease characterized by oral and ocular dryness and marked morbidity, with no available disease modifying treatments. Defining the maladaptive response of endogenous salivary gland mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) by endotype will impact human health by providing foundational insights into SjD pathogenesis and serve as the first step toward two new potential and innovative therapies in SjD, 1) salivary gland MSC-targeted therapy, and 2) JAK inhibition for SjD treatment. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission pertaining to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Responses to looming danger, ranging from threat assessment to active avoidance, are critical for survival and well-being. This project leverages pattern recognition techniques to develop models of cortical and subcortical brain pathways involving the superior colliculus to understand their roles in defensive behavior and emotional experience, and how they mature during adolescence. The knowledge generated by this research can inform mechanistic models of emotion processing and may ultimately lead to the development of improved targets for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Every year, 400,000 million skilled nursing facility (SNF) patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) transfer from SNFs to home and other destinations. Following these transitions, (1) patients with ADRD experience high rates of preventable dementia symptoms and re-hospitalization, with rates highest for Black patients and (2) caregivers of people with ADRD experience high levels of strain and psychological harm. To improve these outcomes and promote health equity, we propose a cluster randomized trial of Connect-Home ADRD, a transitional care intervention for persons with ADRD and their caregivers during care transitions from SNFs to home, assisted living, and long term care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Recently we found that a unique age-associate B cell population (ABC) population includes a naive IgD B cell population that after influenza infection generates a unique extrafollicular effector B cell response, and that makes the predominant Ab response to influenza in the aged. The naïve IgD ABC contains both T-bet-expressing (about 1/4th) and non-T-bet expressing cells ABC, and during response we find a similar distribution, suggesting two sub-lineages of ABC. We will define the requirements for inducing these subsets of ABC to become effectors and memory and will determine ways to augment vaccines to provide each signal needed to provide protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While it is well known that idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis has a devastating disease course, approximately 30% of individuals with non-idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis interstitial lung disease will develop progressive pulmonary fibrosis, with an overall poor survival worse than many cancers. At the current time, there is no ability to distinguish what patients are at highest risk of progressive pulmonary fibrosis, a pressing and unmet medical need. The purpose of this study is to use advanced imaging techniques to predict which individuals will develop progressive pulmonary fibrosis with the goal of enabling treatment plans to be tailored accordingly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Principal Investigator: Facundo M. Fernández – Deep Ovarian Cancer Metabolomics  High-grade serous ovarian cancer is the most common and deadliest type of ovarian cancer; it is diagnosed mostly at an advanced stage at which the cancer has already spread beyond the ovary or the fallopian tube, to the abdominal cavity; advanced-stage diagnosis inevitably causes high mortality. In this project, we propose to study molecular changes in metabolites and lipids associated with early disease in mouse models that closely mimic human disease in at-risk patients, look for cancer biomarkers in “mock” Pap samples and develop new tools to annotate metabolites that track with ovarian cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A central function of fat cells is to store energy when food is abundant and release energy during fasting. When this cycle is disrupted fat tissue dysfunction and metabolic disease ensues, including diabetes mellitus. This project will study a new molecular pathway responsible for the control of fat storage and release in adipocytes and whether it is critical in states of metabolic stress, including fasting, obesity, and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: A thorough understanding of the underlying biology of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (iCCA) is critical for the development of effective therapies for this highly lethal form of hepatobiliary cancer. Our preliminary studies have identified a novel B7-H4-regulated signaling axis that profoundly alters the desmoplastic reaction, a prominent feature of this cancer type, and contributes to tumor growth. We propose to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underpinning this entirely novel tumor-stromal cross-talk and advance our understanding of how to treat patients afflicted by iCCA and possibly other B7-H4-driven malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In this grant, we will overcome the high cost and inefficacies of colonoscopy for cancer screening by developing and validating new in vivo microscopic imaging technologies for detecting and treating cancer precursors called colorectal adenomas. Successful completion of this research will significantly improve colorectal cancer screening by enabling higher adenoma detection rates, and by providing a less invasive screening tool that can automatically detect and treat adenomas at the point of care without requiring sedation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-traumatic joint contracture (PTJC), a common clinical problem following injury that leads to permanent stiffness and debilitating impairment, is especially challenging in the elbow because of high susceptibility and a lack of adequate treatment options. This study will use a preclinical animal model and machine learning-based computational tools to optimize physical therapy strategies and anti-inflammatory drug treatments for elbow PTJC. The long-term result of this work will be to elucidate key concepts and fundamental principles that optimize rehabilitation/treatment following injury and lead to decreased occurrence/impact of elbow PTJC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although proteasome inhibitors are currently used in the clinic against Multiple myeloma, this approach alone is insufficient for sustaining long-term remission in patients. DDI2 protease plays a major role in cancer cell survival during proteasome inhibition therapy. This proposal aims to characterize inhibition of DDI2 protease, a strategy that can be used to increase the efficacy of proteasome inhibitors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed here is directed towards understanding the protein machinery responsible for the biogenesis of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, a structure that is essential for their survival. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed research will study the role of neuroactive steroids in modulation of voltage-gated calcium channels and the role of these channels in acute and chronic pain conditions, as well as excitability and synaptic transmission of dorsal horn neurons of spinal cord. We anticipate that this approach will ultimately lead to better treatments for acute and chronic pain conditions after surgical incision of skin and deep soft tissues with minimal potentials for serious side effects and drug abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Type I interferons are a group of proteins known to interfere with viral replication but can also shape the host immune response. Studying a virus known as Chikungunya virus, which is a human pathogen that causes febrile arthritis, we have found that interferons play both beneficial and harmful roles by acting on skin and muscle cells. Understanding how interferons signal on these different stromal cell populations throughout the course of infection will improve our understanding of tissue-specific immune responses that are mounted during vector-mediated infectious diseases and in response to vaccines.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative In this study, we will prospectively enroll 6,000 women who delivered via cesarean in Rwanda, Ghana, and Mexico and collect visible and thermal wound images and clinician SSI diagnoses on postoperative day (POD) 10 to: a) evaluate the generalizability of infection prediction algorithms developed from data on visible image and thermal images collected in Rwanda, and b) retrain the algorithms to predict SSIs across diverse skin tones. We will follow 1,200 women to POD20 and POD30 to explore the importance of following women past POD10 and evaluate for the likelihood of POD10 images predicting later diagnosed SSIs. This research will inform strategies to accurately predict SSIs after cesarean delivery among women of varying skin tones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is a serious problem that affects 1 in 3 Americans and one of its less understood symptoms is spontaneous pain. Our research has shown, after nerve injury, spontaneously active “cluster firing” sensory neurons and neuropathic spontaneous pain can be triggered by local mechanical movement of the blood vessels in the sensory ganglia. Understanding the causal mechanism behind vascular movement-evoked spontaneous pain could help lead to a new understanding about spontaneous pain and possibly to novel treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Immune tolerance to allergens in desirable to prevent allergic diseases such as asthma. We have established a model of immune tolerance in early life which is dependent on dendritic cells (DCs) and requires mitochondrial H2O2 although the molecular mechanisms that promote tolerogenic DCs are not known. We propose a novel mechanism of inducing airway immune tolerance to allergens in which expression of the molecule Marcksl1 in DCs plays an important role in both mice and humans. The results of our proposed work will identify Marcksl1 as a marker of protection from allergic asthma whose maintenance in DCs from early life would protect from disease development in later life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knee osteoarthritis is a common and debilitating disease that causes joint pain and eventually leads to joint replacement surgery but has an unknown cause and no available treatments. Exercising lower-limb muscles is one of the only recommended options to manage joint pain, but the relationship between the changes in muscle and the changes in osteoarthritis pain and disease progression are unknown. Thus, we will develop new magnetic resonance imaging acquisition and analysis techniques of both lower limbs to better understand the changes that occur in the muscles and the knee during exercise training, with a view towards better future interventions to manage and treat osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Learning is an elemental function of all brains that enables animals to adapt to an ever-changing environment. The focus of this proposal is to understand the fundamental mechanisms of neuronal connectivity that allow brains to learn efficiently. This project has the potential to uncover a fundamental design principle that fine-tunes the ability of the brain to form certain associations more readily than others, thus potentially accounting for well- known cognitive biases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Astrocytes are the most abundant cell type in the adult human brain, mediating vital functions including myelination, axonal guidance, synaptogenesis, and maintenance of the blood-brain barrier. While defects in their function are implicated in a wide range of diseases, including cancers as well as aging, how the diversity of astrocytes is generated in the brain during development remains unknown. The proposal will lead to a fundamental mechanistic insight into the development of human astrocytes and lay the foundation for uncovering the causes and devising new treatment strategies for astrocyte-related human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple myeloma is an incurable malignancy of plasma cells and, patients who have a relapse after BCMA- directed therapies have limited treatment options. Our studies will provide useful information addressing the role of targeting novel antigens such as SEMA4A in patients with relapse after BCMA therapy and the role of combinatorial therapies to target low-antigen-density reservoirs of relapse and induce deeper and longer durations of response. Quantitative antigen density profiling in malignant and normal cells will inform optimal dual targeting designs, thus broadening the therapeutic landscape and potential efficacy of cellular therapies for multiple myeloma.

PHR: Project Narrative It is not understood how the yeast Candida albicans colonizes the digestive tract of most humans without causing symptoms or why it sometimes transforms into a life-threatening, invasive pathogen. By studying which fungal genes are turned on during colonization of a mouse digestive tract, we We propose to uncover the molecular activities of these and other effector proteins to learn how to maintain the fungus in a quiet state and thereby prevent dangerous infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: This project will complete the development of a novel Personal Electrostatic Bioaerosol Sampler (PEBS) to estimate personal exposures to biological aerosols, especially to their low concentrations. First, the developed sampler will be tested in the laboratory and in the field against other personal samplers, and then it will be used to determine personal exposures to bioaerosols in occupational environments. PEBS will be a novel standalone personal sampler capable of operating in various occupational environments to determine workers’ personal exposures to bioaerosols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Diverse factors contribute to neurodegenerative disease, but many of these converge on SARM1, an enzyme that regulates the maintenance of axons, the nerve cell appendages used to communicate to other cells. The regulation of SARM1 activity is complex and can be affected by DNA damage, which is associated with many neurological disorders as well as chemotherapy. Here we investigate SARM1 regulation and the development of a neurolytic non-opioid treatment for pain based on targeted SARM1 activation.

PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular (CV) toxicity associated with cancer drug treatments leads to many CV events, including hypertension, thrombosis, and cardiomyopathy. This proposal aims to explore the role and mechanisms by which endothelial cell transcription factor EB (TFEB) inhibits endothelial cell damage and cardiac dysfunction induced by cancer treatments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Injury to transplanted organs around the time of the surgical transplant procedure increases the risk that the recipient's immune system will attempt to reject the graft and this increases the rate at which grafts fail over many years. We hypothesize that if we treat the graft before transplantation surgery with drugs delivered directly to the lining of the graft blood vessels—particularly drugs that reduce specific changes induced by injury that increase the host immune response—we can break the link between early injury and rejection/graft loss. Specifically, we propose to do this by means of nanoparticle drug carriers that have been modified to bind to the cells that line the blood vessels and are introduced while a human kidney or heart (experimentally using organs declined for transplantation) is attached to a pump that circulates washed red blood cells, a therapy already being tested in clinical transplantation, and load these nanoparticles to deliver forms of RNA therapeutics that temporarily or permanently reduce the level of certain injury-induced proteins that have been shown to boost immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Correcting age-related reductions in brain docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) levels represents a plausible strategy to mitigate progressive neurodegenerative processes associated with dementia. Although recent evidence indicates that DHA in the form of lysophosphatidylcholine-DHA (LPC-DHA) is significantly more effective for increasing brain DHA levels than is the commonly used triglyceride-DHA (TAG-DHA), the effects of LPC-DHA supplementation on human CNS DHA delivery have not been investigated. We propose to conduct the first proof-of-concept randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to compare the effects of LPC-DHA and TAG-DHA supplementation on cerebrospinal fluid DHA levels and neurodegeneration biomarkers in aging adults at risk for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Consumption of a diet high in fat and fructose is associated with a range of metabolic consequences that can lead to obesity, glucose intolerance, and diabetes, a public health crisis characterized by disability, loss of life, and great financial expense. The research described in this application seeks to understand the fundamental ways that such a diet changes the regulation of glucose metabolism, as well as the efficacy of potential treatment strategies. Our canine model is ideally positioned to act as a bridge between in vitro / small animal research and the human, allowing us to facilitate the translation of promising discoveries as well as the ability to test control mechanisms using strategies that are not possible in other species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overarching goal is to develop optical redox imaging (ORI)-based medical instruments to guide surgical and therapeutic approaches. This project will (1) develop a stress test to diagnose cartilage disease based on changes in ORI metrics and material behavior; (2) develop an ex vivo system to test emergent therapeutic strategies following impact injury; and (3) develop and validate a medical instrument that captures ORI for staging in vivo cartilage disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Youth-onset type 2 diabetes is rapidly increasing in incidence, carries a high risk of severe complications in early adulthood, and disproportionately impacts marginalized communities. Adolescents and young adults with type 2 diabetes often face barriers to healthy lifestyle change and diabetes self-management, including limited or delayed feedback on how such health behavior changes affect blood sugar. Our study, REFLECT2D, will evaluate use a novel smartphone app pairing real-time health behavior and glycemic data, laying the foundation for future interventions that use the right type of data at the right time to support health behavior change, ultimately improving outcomes for adolescents and young adults with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC) is becoming a major risk factor for chronic diseases, with older adults and those with underlying health conditions at risk of developing persistent mobility limitations and disabilities. Although exercise intervention is a common strategy to restore functional capacity, it may not be feasible or enticing to many people with PASC. This clinical trial seeks to establish the tolerability and efficacy of at home lower-body heat therapy for improving functional capacity along with metabolic and vascular health in late-middle aged and older adults with PASC, also known as “long COVID”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Major depression and anxiety are very important causes of morbidity and mortality on the population level. Methods in genetics such as genomewide association studies (GWAS) that have been used to untangle and understand the biology of other complex genetic traits have only recently been brought to bear on these traits. Using the most extensive and informative databases available worldwide, we will use large-scale GWAS to increase understanding of the genetics and biology of these important mental illnesses, in European, African, and Latinx populations, work that will facilitate bringing novel therapeutics and personalized medicine approaches to the treatment of these illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inherited retinal degenerations (IRDs) are a genetically heterogeneous group of disorders that are important causes of vision loss. The goals of the proposed research are to improve our ability to identify the genetic cause of IRDs by investigating variants that potentially lead to aberrant pre-mRNA splicing and structural genomic rearrangements that can lead to disease. Results of the proposed studies will lead to new genetic diagnoses, which will enhance patients’ clinical care and will provide them with opportunities to participate in clinical trials and receive approved genetic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 4-hydroxy fatty acids comprise a lipid class of emerging importance to mammalian physiology, yet their metabolism is poorly understood. Our work aims to establish the primary enzymes responsible for initiating the breakdown of these lipids and the metabolic ramifications that result from the disruption of these enzymes in cells, worms, mice, and humans. Completion of these goals will add a fundamental new aspect to our understanding of lipid metabolism, link 4-hydroxy fatty acids to specific physiological dysfunctions, and identify potential new therapeutic targets for the treatment of certain disorders related to fatty acid breakdown.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative: This project aims to fundamentally change how we view the role of tau in the peripheral nervous system. It will first solidify the role of tau phosphorylation in diabetic peripheral neuropathy, and then determine the dependence of tau phosphorylation on insulin signaling and GSK3β within peripheral nerves. Thus, through these innovative experiments, we will deepen our understanding of the peripheral nervous system and provide new therapeutic targets for peripheral neuropathy in diabetic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging-related functional declines are thought to be caused by hallmark biological processes that ultimately manifest in physical, mental, and metabolic impairments that compromise healthspan and quality of life. Exercise is a multipotent treatment with promise to mitigate most aging hallmarks, but there is substantial variability in exercise responsiveness. Combining endurance and resistance training in alignment with public health guidelines will be used to better understand variable exercise responsiveness in older adults with the ultimate goal of improving each older adult’s capacity to attain the many health benefits of exercise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Novel PET Imaging to Guide Therapy in Hepatocellular Carcinoma In patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), locoregional therapies (LRTs) such as transcatheter arterial radioembolization (TARE) with Yttrium-90 (Y90) are often used as bridge therapies to prevent tumor growth and progression while awaiting a donor liver for orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT), to downstage lesions to meet eligibility for OLT, or as palliative care. Clinical decisions regarding treatment response remain largely guided by conventional imaging modalities but are ambiguous at early time points following therapy. This application proposes to explore a non-invasive PET imaging method to predict response to Y90 TARE therapy early in the course of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An antigen known as DLL3 is expressed on the cell surface of two rapidly lethal types of cancer (small cell lung cancer and neuroendocrine prostate cancer) and can be targeted with a radiolabeled antibody that delivers radiation to the site of disease. This antibody, SC16.56, can be used for both diagnosis (with PET imaging) and therapy, using a theranostic approach akin to a military tank equipped with radar and an intelligence report to survey a territory, as well as a missile to launch a targeted attack. We will evaluate this antibody’s safety and treatment efficacy in patients with these two aggressive cancer types and assess tumor response using imaging and molecular genomic tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: The Undiagnosed Disease Network (UDN) is committed to ending the diagnostic odyssey for patients and families affected by undiagnosed disease. The proposed YDCoE brings together extensive clinical expertise, novel machine-learning clinical review tools, undiagnosed and rare disease discovery, next-gen sequencing and new approaches in bioinformatics and functional genomics to deliver clinical capacity for the UDN at unprecedented scale. Our strong community partnerships will ensure expanded access to individuals and groups who historically have not benefited from modern diagnostic investigations due to race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status or other systemic barriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Mosquitoes infected with the natural bacterium Wolbachia are increasingly released worldwide to curb the transmission of pathogenic Zika and dengue viruses to humans. Wolbachia rapidly spread through host populations by manipulating insect sexual reproduction including the development of sperm, eggs, and embryos. This research will characterize, for the first time, the initial epigenetic modifications during gametogenesis and embryogenesis that enable Wolbachia to spread, self-sustain at high frequencies, and protect local communities from mosquito-borne diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative The blood-brain barrier (BBB) serves as a protective barrier for the central nervous system (CNS) by preventing the entry of harmful substances such as plasma proteins and inorganic solutes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will determine how much high levels of insulin in the blood resulting from injecting insulin under skin causes three problems for the health of the heart and blood vessels. These three problems are stiffening of the blood vessels, more frequent blood clots, and using insulin less effectively. This study will see how much changing insulin levels in the blood affects these three risks in people with type 1 diabetes, people without diabetes, and people with a rarer form of diabetes called GCK-MODY.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project narrative Our proposed research seeks to elucidate the intricate dynamics of social networks and their impact on health- related behaviors and the early detection of cognitive impairment, specifically Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). By employing advanced methodologies in data science and social network analysis, the study aims to uncover the mechanisms through which social ties influence behavior change and care-seeking efforts. The ultimate goal is to inform the development of more precise and targeted interventions and campaigns that can enhance health promotion and ADRD detection strategies within at-risk communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Undiagnosed rare disease negatively impacts patient quality of life, causes disproportionate health care utilization, and creates a tremendous economic burden for the patient and the health care system. Genomic medicine carries the promise of improving diagnosis, care, and therapeutics for individuals with rare disease but limited access to genomic medicine carries a risk of health inequity. This project proposes to improve the identification, care and diagnostic modalities for patients with rare disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative Brain circuits that compute sound source location using relative timing and intensity are critical for speech comprehension in noisy environments and are altered in children with central auditory processing disorder (CAPD). The lateral superior olive (LSO) is a key component of this system traditionally thought to resolve intensity differences, however, evolutionary drive for the calyx of Held and recent evidence suggest the major function of the LSO is encoding time differences particularly for broadband transients. To address this conundrum, we will clarify cellular diversity in the LSO that is not well understood which we propose allow it to perform both functions and may be dysregulated by hearing loss or CAPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a relatively common birth defect of the lungs associated with high mortality and morbidity. There remains a critical need to better understand CDH disease pathogenesis and to identify novel treatment options to improve the lives of affected children. The data generated from this proposal using rodent lung explants, human organoids, micro- mechanical technologies, and large animal models will enhance our understanding of the impact of a major mechanosensory pathway during the canalicular stage of fetal lung development.
