IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A substantial proportion of breast cancer survivors report fear of cancer recurrence following cancer treatment, yet few interventions utilizing scalable eHealth methods and targeting fear of recurrence have been empirically evaluated. The purpose of this large, multisite phase III randomized clinical trial is to evaluate whether an eHealth intervention (“FoRtitude”) that teaches cognitive behavior therapy- based coping strategies and healthy behaviors tailored to manage fear of recurrence, can reduce fear of recurrence, depression, and anxiety; improve quality of life; and reduce fear of recurrence-related health care utilization and physiologic dysregulation (allostatic load).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This research will develop a unique multi-functional 3D printed dental implant that will effectively minimize peri- implantitis, i.e., dental implant-related infection incidences for patients needing artificial tooth/teeth. This unique infection-resistant and bioactive dental implant can also be tailored according to patient defects. They will relieve patients from the baleful aftermaths of infections, such as surgical pain, repeated clinic visits for treatment, prolonged recovery time, reliability on antibiotics, and added therapy costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Back pain has become the most common cause of disability globally and is the primary contributor to healthcare spending in the USA. The intervertebral disc and the facet joints act in concert to permit mechanical function of the healthy spine, however, both structures are prone to degeneration which can contribute to back pain. This proposal will bring a new perspective to the study of spinal degeneration by investigating the crosstalk between the disc and facets during both degeneration and repair, enhancing our understanding of the pathophysiology of spinal degeneration and contributing to the future development of more effective treatments for patients with back pain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis is a devastating lung disease that causes progressive scarring in the lungs resulting in respiratory failure and death. The research described in this grant proposal aims to understand how lung scarring can be reversed in Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis. The proposed research is relevant to public health because a better understanding of the biology underpinning scar reversal has the potential to identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of this disease and other diseases of progressive scarring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative / Public Health Relevance Candida frequently forms biofilms on the surface of medical devices. Both drug resistance and dissemination due to fungal cell dispersion contribute to the high mortality linked to biofilm infections; there are no effective drug therapies for these commonly lethal fungal infections. The proposed studies will uncover the biofilm driven regulatory pathway and effectors that govern the extracellular vesicle delivery and assembly of the protective matrix that permits Candida to persist and disseminate from implanted devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study will generate population-based data on the impact of false-positive findings from lung cancer screening with low dose computed tomography for the 14.5 million U.S. adults eligible for screening. These results have the potential to inform patient and clinician shared decision-making conversations and future US Preventive Services Task Force evidence reviews. As the number of patients screened for lung cancer increases due to expanded eligibility criteria, this research is timely and responsive to the National Cancer Institute’s goal to support research in cancer control that will help inform guideline development and policy decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic mutations in the transcription factor networks that govern eye development are a leading cause of congenital ocular malformations. The proposed studies in this project seek to elucidate novel insights into the mechanisms through which key regulatory circuits active in retinal progenitor cells contribute to the proper production of retinal neurons. This information is critical for a better understanding of the etiology of retinal developmental disorders and for potentially improving diagnosis and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The p53 tumor suppressor and phosphoinositide (PI) 3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt pathway are key regulators of cell growth and apoptosis and frequently mutated in cancer. We have discovered a nuclear PI3K/Akt pathway independent of the canonical pathway whereby PIs are linked to p53 in response to stress to activate nuclear Akt and inhibit cell death. PIs are also linked to MDM2, a key regulator of p53 stability, allowing for fine tuning of the p53-MDM2 pathway. The molecular characterization of this nuclear PI3K/Akt pathway and PI-regulated p53- MDM2 pathway could lead to new strategies to treat cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Nonalcoholic Steatohepatitis Clinical Research Network (NASH CRN) is a consortium of clinical centers and a Data Coordinating Center studying the cause and treatment of MASH, formerly termed NASH, in order to prevent known outcomes of cirrhosis, liver transplant and liver cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative Gut microbiota is now recognized as a critical, previously ignored factor contributing to the development of hypertension. However, the mechanisms by which gut microbiota regulates hypertension is a significant knowledge gap. In this proposal, building on our recently published data, we address this knowledge gap on conjugated bile acids, which are products of collaborative biochemical processing by gut microbiota and the host. The proposal uses cutting-edge animal models as tools to understand the mechanism by which gut microbiota- mediated conjugated bile acids operate as antihypertensive metabolites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The many biological and environmental factors influencing recovery from pediatric traumatic brain injury (TBI) are poorly understood, resulting in inaccurate prediction of outcomes and few effective treatments. This project will investigate DNA methylation/the “methylome”, a major epigenetic regulator of gene expression, as an untapped source of biologic complexity underlying recovery from pediatric TBI. The overall impact of this work will be to improve our understanding of the biologic complexity underlying pediatric TBI recovery, reveal biologic signatures of risk for poor recovery, and identify potential methylomic biomarkers that could revolutionize TBI management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overuse of total thyroidectomy exposes patients with thyroid cancer to unnecessary risks without improving length or quality of life. This study will address this problem by testing an intervention for surgeons and practice leaders comprised of existing evidenced-based interventions tailored for thyroid cancer treatment. Because thyroid cancer is the most common malignancy in young adults, the proposed intervention could reduce rates of unnecessary total thyroidectomy and improve long-term outcomes of survivors including quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Personality traits have been linked to the cognitive healthspan, compression of cognitive morbidity, Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias, and tolerance of Alzheimer’s brain pathology. It is essential to understand more precisely the pathways through which personality traits and ADRD are related; the current application therefore focuses on the role of potential mediators (i.e., inflammatory biomarkers, cardiometabolic biomarkers), as well as socioeconomic risk factors as potential moderators. The use of multiple large longitudinal datasets of aging and dementia will enhance replicability of results, and will be guided by theoretical frameworks of differentiated preservation, preserved differentiation, cognitive reserve, as well as compression of morbidity in late life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cystic fibrosis (CF) results from mutations in the CFTR Cl- channel resulting in diminished transepithelial Cl- secretion. The most common CFTR mutation, F508del, results in a channel that fails to correctly fold/traffic. FDA- approved compounds that improve the folding/trafficking of misfolded CFTR have been identified as part of a highly effective modulator therapy (HEMT) - referred to as correctors. These correctors are highly efficacious in improving lung function. Unfortunately, adverse events (AE) have been reported in a subset of CF patients taking these correctors, including headache, hypertension and mental health issues. We demonstrate CFTR correctors inhibit small (KCa2.x) and intermediate (KCa3.1) conductance, Ca2+-activated K+ channels (KCa) while also potentiating the large (BKCa; KCa1.1) conductance KCa. Our studies will define the mechanisms by which CFTR correctors modulate KCa channel function and how this affects ion transport across human bronchial epithelial cells (HBEs), vascular reactivity and neuronal action potential firing. As this HEMT represents the standard of care for CF patients it is critical to understand the mechanisms underlying the AE reported, both in the short- term, so they may be mitigated, and in the long-term such that next-generation HEMT may be developed – improving the lives of CF patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although it has been long hypothesized that -cell heterogeneity is highly relevant to the risk of diabetes, the nature and mechanism of such heterogeneity is largely unknown. Our previous study suggested that HNF1A, a key transcription factor that causes early onset diabetes in young people, may also contribute to common type II diabetes via governing -cell heterogeneity. In this project we will comprehensively investigate the function and mechanism of HNF1A-driven -cell heterogeneity in multiple -cell models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  This research project seeks to uncover the critical role of hepatocyte-specific necroptosis in liver inflammation, liver pathology, and cognitive decline in the context of aging. By investigating the impact of necroptosis on liver inflammation, cellular senescence, and neuroinflammation, the study aims to shed light on the intricate interplay between the liver and the brain in aging. The findings have the potential to uncover new insights into the mechanisms promoting age-related cognitive impairment and could lead to innovative interventions targeting hepatocyte-specific necroptosis to mitigate cognitive deficits associated with age-related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Altered hepatic lipid synthesis and catabolism can adversely affect local and systemic lipid homeostasis. While the critical role of insulin in promoting hepatic lipid and lipoprotein synthesis is widely studied, major knowledge gaps exist regarding hormones that suppress hepatic lipogenesis and promote fat oxidation. Our discovery that CTRP1 is a novel endocrine (from adipose) and/or paracrine (from liver) regulator of hepatic lipid synthesis and catabolism may provide a novel therapeutic target to treat non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and non- alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The societal and patient-centered impacts of osteoarthritis (OA) are profound – total costs for OA treatment in the US exceed $486 billion annually. OA management is limited to pain management and the disease often progresses to end-stage at which time only joint replacement surgery is an option. Elucidating gaps in our understanding of the role of genetic variation to OA susceptibility, heterogeneity, and progression will enable the design personalized approaches for diagnosis and care management to improve quality of level for OA patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will contribute to public health efforts to improve treatment outcomes for adolescent girls and young women living with HIV in resource-limited settings by evaluating the impact of a novel long-acting HIV treatment. Findings from this study will have important implications for HIV care and treatment approaches and guidelines globally. This research has the potential to make important contributions towards addressing some of the key public health problems in sub-Saharan Africa, including attainment of the UNAIDS 90-90-90 targets; prevention of mother to child transmission of HIV; and maternal morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A first episode of psychosis is a leading cause of disability in young adults, with high risk of suicide and all cause mortality. A substantial part of the burden and cost relates to poor functional outcomes, and the inability to determine the right antipsychotic treatment during the earliest phases of psychotic illness, particularly for those who might need clozapine, a medication that is already known to work best for those who do not respond to conventional antipsychotics. In patients with a first episode of psychosis, the present study aims to determine whether the use of biomarker guided treatment decisions leads to better outcomes and equivalent side effects in people prescribed clozapine compared to conventional antipsychotics, including changes in brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Effective speech communication plays an important role in shaping positive health outcomes and improving overall well-being, particularly for older adults with hearing loss. This project investigates the social networks of adults with hearing loss who obtain cochlear implants, and how and why social networks support effective speech communication in this population. Because social networks represent important and potentially malleable factors, knowledge gained from this project could lead to the development of novel interventions aimed at enhancing communication ability in adults with hearing loss and cochlear implants.

PHR: Disabling falls are a common feature of advancing Parkinson disease (PD). There are no markedly effective treatments to reduce fall risk in mid-stage PD. Prior studies indicate that brain deficits of the chemical messenger acetylcholine underlie increased fall risk. We will evaluate a commonly used drug, varenicline, that partially mimics acetylcholine, to determine if varenicline treatment improves multitasking and reduces fall risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chlamydia trachomatis (Ct) is a common treatable sexually transmitted infection that can result in important morbidity and, despite decades of clinic-based screening, cases continue to increase - disproportionately affecting Black youth. Check It is a community-based, bundled, seek-test-and-treat Ct intervention originally designed for men who have vaginal sex and was impactful in reducing Ct rates among women. To expand its potential impact, we will adapt it to examine the inclusion of women, impact of the change in treatment guidelines, impact of home specimen collection, effect of incentivized peer referral, utility of HIV/syphilis testing, and feasibility of extra-genital self-collected swabs, as well as program efficacy and cost- effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension and heart failure are characterized by increased cardiac sympathetic transmission, and sympathetic hyperactivity can trigger lethal arrhythmias. The goal of our research is to elucidate the mechanisms that underlie enhanced peripheral sympathetic transmission to the heart in cardiovascular disease. This will lay the groundwork for new therapeutic options that target the nervous system to decrease arrhythmia risk and prevent sudden cardiac death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement The proposed research is meant to provide physicians with an entirely new nano-based imaging technology that has the potential to determine the immune profile of an individual patient’s tissue in a single image. Clinicians will be able to utilize the new imaging strategy to interrogate a multitude of immune biomarkers on the same tissue sections prepared for histology. Incorporating it into the pathology workflow could enable physicians to better understand the patient’s molecular profile and stratify patients to receive the most effective therapeutic regimen possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this research project is to understand why group B Streptococcus (GBS), a type of bacteria that causes severe pregnancy complications such as stillbirth and preterm labor, can be harmless in the gut and vagina of healthy adults yet catastrophically dangerous in the amniotic fluid surrounding a fetus. We hypothesize that when GBS moves into the amniotic fluid, it experiences a lack of essential nutrients that are typically present in the digestive and vaginal tracts, and that this nutrient deprivation activates bacterial stress responses. These stress responses may include increased expression of harmful molecules that trigger the maternal and fetal immune system, ultimately causing tissue damage and threatening the pregnancy. These studies may help us better understand and prevent GBS-related pregnancy complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is an increasingly prevalent problem for pediatric, adolescent, and young adult (AYA) cancer patients, which can be partially attributed to off-target effects of chemotherapy treatments that damage the vascular endothelium and create a pro-inflammatory environment. PET/CT imaging with the radionuclide 18F-FDG is standard of care for monitoring treatment responses in many cancers, but could provide additional insight into chemotherapy-induced venous toxicity and risk for VTE events by allowing for quantitative assessment of serial changes in venous inflammation. In this project, we will validate 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging as a non-invasive approach for evaluating chemotherapy-induced venous toxicity and risk for VTE events, thereby laying the foundation for the use of image-derived measures of venous inflammation to enhance personalized plans for thromboprophylaxis and promote improved quality of life for pediatric and AYA cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variants in myosin heavy chain 7 (MYH7) are common causes of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), a potentially life-threatening heart disease. Most of the MYH7 variants are classified as variants of unknown significance, which affects the ability to accurately identify patients at risk for HCM. This proposal will determine the disease-causing potential of thousands of MYH7 variants to better interpret genetic test results for patients and will identify shared mechanisms by which MYH7 variants cause HCM, which may inform potential future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s dementia (AD) and age-related cognitive decline have a large impact on the health of Americans. Age is the primary risk factor for AD and cognitive decline. Aging can be chronologic aging (time since birth) or biological aging that may differ substantially from chronological age for some individuals. Exercise is a promising intervention to mitigate cognitive decline in older adults. Understanding the impact of exercise on biological aging and cognitive function could assist in improving interventions to impede the development of AD and age-related cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to evaluate an innovative, newly developed measurement for bioavailable copper in the circulation known as “accurately determined non-ceruloplasmin bound copper (ANCC)”, as a biomarker for treatment and outcome of Wilson Disease, an inherited disorder of copper metabolism where excess copper causes progressive injury to the liver, brain, and other organs. These studies will benefit treatment monitoring of current and investigational therapies for Wilson disease and have a wider impact on human health by enhancing our ability to assess copper status in health and in disease, which is important for conditions associated with low copper levels due to altered intestinal absorption or tissue distribution, and for new blood vessel formation and cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The inferior olivary nucleus plays a vital role in cerebellar function and motor control, and olivary degeneration is central to the pathophysiology of tremor and ataxia. We will examine a shared mechanism for degeneration in the olive that results from intrinsic molecular pathology as well as from extrinsic denervation of cerebellar input. This proposal has profound implications for development of treatment directed towards improving inferior olivary neuron survival and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation is responsible for frequent hospitalizations, a decreased quality of life, and increased risks of stroke and death. Recent evidence shows that abstinence from alcohol reduces the burden of atrial fibrillation, and our recent work suggests that alcohol may immediately heighten the risk of a near-term atrial fibrillation event. This research seeks to develop and study a novel tool using commonly used smartphones and smart watches to promote abstinence specifically among individuals with atrial fibrillation and to provide the first definitive evidence that consuming alcohol causes a discrete atrial fibrillation episode.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension (high blood pressure) affects 1 in 3 of the over 90 million people currently enrolled in Medicaid, and lower anti-hypertensive (AH) medication adherence rates are found among Medicaid enrollees compared to other insured populations, which poses a major barrier to controlled blood pressure. Using short-term incentives to support action planning is an evidence- and theory-based approach to forming healthy pill-taking habits and establishing long-term AH medication adherence. This study proposes to adapt the widely-used Wellth smartphone app to remotely deliver the combination of incentives and action planning that if found effective is readily scalable for improving the self-management of hypertension and other chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The role of the two FOXP3 isoforms (FOXP3 FL and FOXP3 ΔE2) in health and disease has not clearly defined. In this application, we propose to use unique mouse strains developed in our lab (strains expressing only one isoform, and the other co-expressing both isoforms through alternative splicing as in humans) to define the molecular and cellular mechanisms for the FOXP3 isoforms regulating immunopathology of allergic airway inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Polymeric bioresorbable vascular scaffolds (BVSs) have emerged as a potential solution to problems with traditional metal stents by providing initial support to prevent recoil and slowly degrading to restore vasomotion and eliminate residual foreign materials that may contribute to restenosis. However, currently approved BVS have higher incidences of major cardiovascular events and clotting in small arteries due to their strut size and slow, pro-inflammatory degrading polymer. We will develop and test in vivo 3D-printed, low profile, drug-eluting, biocompatible and mechanically functional BVS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction is implicated in a wide range of rare and common human diseases, yet the underlying features of this dysfunction are often poorly defined and extremely difficult to rectify. This proposal aims to elucidate the role of reversible phosphorylation in regulating select mitochondrial functions and to connect this phosphorylation to specific mitochondrial phosphatases. Completion of these goals will advance our basic understanding of mitochondrial metabolic regulation and define specific phosphatases as potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A hallmark of substance use disorders is the continued pursuit of drug despite high costs. To understand this pattern of behavior, we will develop and validate a computational and neurological model of costly drug consumption. Determining the mechanisms underlying drug pursuit is timely and highly significant given the ongoing substance use crisis in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the common complications of pulmonary hypertension is right-sided heart failure associated with poor prognosis in patients. We have developed preliminary data showing that right-sided heart failure, in part, is mediated by excessive activation of cardiac fibroblasts induced by the specific enzyme named c-Src. This research will allow us to design a novel strategy for the management of right-sided heart failure during pulmonary hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By 2065 the U.S. foreign-born population is expected to reach 78 million persons. This project will overcome many of the previous challenges in studying death rates among the foreign born by leveraging unique linked data from the U.S. Census Bureau and the Social Security Administration. The study will examine how social and economic factors over the life course, including earnings trajectories, are associated with death risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to test the efficacy of an innovative text-based intervention, ASPIRE, designed not just to address cognitive and behavioral elements but also to modify crucial environmental factors such as peers that influence drinking behaviors. Preliminary results from a pilot trial are promising, and our upcoming research aims to further test ASPIRE's effectiveness, understand the mechanisms driving behavior change, and identify which subgroups stand to benefit most, aligning with NIH's emphasis on non-colligate young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health by providing new data on rates and timing of hypoxia, impact of early exposure to anesthesia, and the earliest markers of brain growth/function among infants with and without oral cleft. This knowledge will be essential in guiding treatment decisions related to sleep studies, use of pre-surgical orthopedics, and timing of surgery that will ultimately improve outcomes for infants with oral cleft. The goals of this project advance the NIH mission to use obtained knowledge about living systems to enhance health and reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because elucidation of the cellular, molecular, and electrophysiological changes underlying epilepsy after head trauma (posttraumatic epilepsy, PTE) will increase understanding of the pathogenesis of PTE. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission, as the research pursues fundamental knowledge of disease mechanisms in the brain, which may provide a foundation for the development of novel and more effective strategies to treat the major clinical problem of PTE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Revision anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction results in inferior outcomes compared with primary reconstructions, thus limiting individuals from returning to their previous activities. This multicenter, multi-surgeon prospective study will allow determination of the long-term clinical predictors of outcomes following revision ACL reconstruction. Identifying risk predictors will guide revision surgical decisions and post-surgical activity and lifestyle guidance, as strategies to predict, modify and decrease this risk will change patient’s lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Botulinum neurotoxins (BoNTs) are extremely potent bacterial toxins causing the paralytic botulism syndrome. We propose to develop a platform for intra-neuronal delivery of nanobodies in order to neutralize the toxin inside the intoxicated neurons and accelerate recovery of botulism. The accomplishment of our goals will result in novel antidotes to treat post-exposure botulism, as well as a versatile platform for delivery of protein therapeutics to act on other intra-neuronal targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  APOE ε2 and ε4 genotypes are associated with risk of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and peripheral lipid traits and inflammatory markers. The strength of these associations varies with ancestry, and we have previously shown that ancestry-specific APOE haplotypes influence AD risk beyond the effects of ancestry genome-wide. Our proposed analyses of variation among admixed participants will allow us to recognize the genetic modifiers of AD risk that vary between ancestry-specific APOE haplotypes, and whether these variants have pleiotropic effects on peripheral lipid traits or inflammatory markers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: H. PROJECT NARRATIVE Young adulthood is a critical period for alcohol initiation and changes in alcohol use patterns, including increased risk for alcohol misuse and alcohol use disorders (AUD), that are strongly influenced by social factors. Previous research shows that acute alcohol responses in the lab are greater when with another person compared to when drinking alone (i.e., social facilitation of alcohol effects), and the investigative team’s preliminary evidence shows sensitivity to social facilitation of alcohol effects may be a novel risk factor for future alcohol misuse. This proposal will use a multi-method laboratory/Ecological Momentary Assessment/longitudinal follow-up approach to examine the role of social facilitation of alcohol effects on prospective alcohol misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will return research blood biomarkers for Alzheimer Disease (AD) to healthy older adults and evaluate whether the results can be sent directly to participants in a safe and understandable way. The project will benefit current Alzheimer research and future clinical needs by developing a process for returning biomarker results that is safe and effective, which will be necessary for widespread AD diagnostic testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose the creation of the Climate and Health Allied Network for Geospatial and Environmental Science (CHANGES) Exploratory Research Center at the University of New Mexico (UNM). The overall vision of our center is to synergize expertise in geographic information science, climate science, electronic health data, epidemiology, and biomedical research to identify – and ultimately predict – gaps in health care and inform policies and actionable strategies to optimally protect our vulnerable communities in New Mexico. Our center is dedicated to leveraging transdisciplinary sciences to develop innovative strategies, solutions, and policies that empower and protect vulnerable communities, not only in New Mexico but worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Many developmental and adult cases of neural injury and degeneration such as Alexander disease, multiple sclerosis and Alzheimer’s disease are associated with alterations in the development of glia (gliogenesis). However, studying gliogenesis using classical techniques is labor-intensive and tedious, as gliogenesis displays large variances in its spatial and temporal outputs. To address this challenge, we will develop a technological platform that enables rapid and unbiased analysis of histological tissues with multiple labeled elements to reveal effects of genetic manipulation on gliogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guided by a decade of experience the Center for Undiagnosed Diseases at Stanford, a member site of the Undiagnosed Diseases Network, will continue to develop and implement innovative, effective, and sustainable strategies to diagnose the undiagnosed of all backgrounds. Our Center will continue to bring Stanford’s expertise in technology development, genomic and multi-omic data analysis, stem cell biology, and translational research to the team-based diagnosis and care of diverse individuals with undiagnosed diseases. We will build and carefully study deep collaborations with community partners to promote the participation of the underserved and integrate advanced evaluation of the undiagnosed with routine clinical practice while advancing the scientific mission of the Undiagnosed Diseases Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  In all vertebrate embryos, the neural crest gives rise to the sensory, autonomic and enteric nervous system, craniofacial skeleton and melanocytes of the skin. Not only does the neural crest have the capacity to form an amazing number of embryonic cell types, but also neural crest stem cells persist in adult tissue. Because neural crest cells are involved in a variety of birth defects such as Hirschsprung’s disease, cleft palate and various types of cancers, like melanoma and neuroblastoma, the results of this proposal regarding evolution of neural crest cell differentiative ability will provide important understanding of the normal development of these cells that can later lead to disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The CLIMAte-Related Exposures, Adaptation, and Health Equity (CLIMA) Center based at the University of Southern California aims to build transdisciplinary science capacity to advance community-engaged, solution- oriented climate change, adaptation, and health research and to inform climate action policies for health equity. CLIMA will develop novel methods to characterize climate-related exposures such as urban heat islands, wildfire smoke and compound climate events, their impact on cardiovascular health and resilience across the life course, and the role of adaptation strategies (air conditioning, greening interventions for shade), and system and human vulnerability (power outages, social vulnerability). California's diverse communities and array of climate action and health equity policies provide an optimal setting to learn early lessons on real-life effectiveness, co-benefits, and gaps in adaptation strategies that communities and policy makers can use to protect the most vulnerable and strengthen climate change resiliency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Pulmonary complications are the main cause of hospitalizations in children and adults with Down Syndrome, often presenting with upper airway diseases such as tracheobronchial malacia and airway obstruction with wheezing, particularly in babies and children. Therefore, understanding early, perinatal factors leading to lung disease in neonates and children with DS becomes clinically relevant, innovative and transformative, with potential for substantial lifelong impact in a highly vulnerable population with major unmet medical needs. DS is known as a progeric syndrome, exhibiting increased cellular senescence mainly described in brain cells, which may also impact lung disease in early infancy, the focus of our proposed studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary artery disease (CAD) continues to be a leading cause of death in the United States despite lifesaving drugs and procedures like angioplasty and bypass surgery. We propose to study the genetics of human coronary artery structural variation to discover the biological mechanisms behind coronary artery formation and the development of naturally occurring bypass arteries termed `collaterals'. Ultimately, our goal is to use this information to develop new pharmacological or gene therapies that promote arterial growth to improve and lengthen the life of those afflicted with CAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Invasive fungal infection caused by Aspergillus fumigatus is a leading cause of death for patients with lowered immune systems. Despite this high mortality, the fundamental mechanism of how A. fumigatus grows and invades the host tissue is not understood and this knowledge is critical to improving therapeutic treatment. Hyphal growth is crucial for A. fumigatus invasive disease and the proposed research will define the mechanism of how a critical calcineurin signaling pathway interacts with other proteins to regulate fungal growth, antifungal response, and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The proposed research will significantly advance our understanding of the cellular and molecular pathways, and cell-specific transcriptomic profiles contributing to the neurobiological basis of major depressive disorder. Through a better understanding of the mechanisms of depressive illness, we may be one step closer to developing novel treatment strategies and personalize interventions. The proposed project will be representative of both Caucasians and African American individuals and will be sufficiently powered to identify molecular processes that are sex specific.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative Medicaid is an important source of health insurance for people with substance use disorder (SUD), but many Medicaid enrollees with SUD do not receive optimal health care. Most states now contract with Managed Care Organizations (MCO) to deliver care for their SUD Medicaid population. The proposed research will provide im- portant information on how states can further improve their Medicaid program by starting, renewing or to ending contracts with MCOs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure is a global pandemic and is increasing in prevalence worldwide, and abnormalities in cardiac metabolism have been implicated in the genesis of cardiomyopathies and heart failure – no surprise given the massive energy demands of the heart. This project proposes development of a metabolic imaging method, hyperpolarized carbon-13 MRI, to measure key processes in glucose metabolism that are altered in heart disease, which cannot be measured by any existing technique. We will develop techniques for hyperpolarized carbon-13 MRI scanning and image analysis, and apply these to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) patient studies where we expect to observe regional and global changes in glucose metabolism that correlate with clinical phenotype and are modulated by cutting-edge treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: || NARRATIVE The proposed work focusses on the release of the pro-hormone renin into the blood. This hormone is released almost exclusively by juxtaglomerular cells in the kidney. We present evidence that two new proteins may be involved: pannexin 1 and PIEZO1. We will study how they coordinate renin release in cells and animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Typhoidal Salmonella serovars cause an estimated 22 million cases of enteric fever each year worldwide, which remains a significant cause of infectious disease morbidity and mortality in lower-income countries. Our understanding of enteric fever pathogenesis is incomplete due to the absence of convenient animal models. In this application, we will elucidate molecular mechanisms of typhoidal Salmonella serovars survival and replication in infection-relevant conditions, including human macrophages in vitro and in humanized mice, which will provide new insights into the pathogenesis of enteric fever caused by nontyphoidal Salmonella.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is to understand the mechanisms underlying brain aging and neurodegeneration in males and females. This proposal is focused on a region of the brain known as the hypothalamus, which is critical for controlling sleep, food intake, the stress response, cognition, and neuroendocrine functions. This work will provide insights into how these functions are affected in healthy aging and diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a devastating genetic disease which causes progressive muscle weakness, cardiac and breathing difficulties. There is no cure for DMD, and many patients eventually die from respiratory failure. Furthermore, approximately 1/3 of patients have neurological pathology. In this proposal, we will examine the impact of DMD on the breathing muscles, nerves, and central nervous system in mouse models of DMD that have the human genetic mutation. Next, we will examine the impact of a novel adeno-associated viral (AAV) gene therapy to treat both the breathing deficits and the global pathology of DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical inactivity is a global public health problem that is associated with numerous chronic conditions in both urban and rural populations. Older adults with cardiovascular disease who complete cardiac rehabilitation are an especially high-risk group who have a major drop off in physical activity, making them vulnerable to poor health outcomes. Our clinical trial will determine whether a virtual coaching and social support intervention promotes maintenance of physical activity after cardiac rehabilitation as well as psychosocial (e.g., depression, loneliness), social cognitive (e.g., self-efficacy), and clinical (e.g., high blood pressure/cholesterol) outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research addresses social connectedness and, consequently, the overall health and quality of life outcomes of people with neuromotor disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: LEGACY EMANUEL HOSPITAL AND HEALTH CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian rhythms powerfully regulate our daily physiological and mental functions, but these rhythms can be disrupted in shift work, during jet lag, during ageing, and in individuals with a wide variety of neurological disorders. Individuals with these conditions experience cognitive impairment. Our studies focus on neural mechanisms in the prefrontal cortex that we believe contribute to this impairment during disruption of daily rhythms. These studies have translational potential in humans because impaired cognition can be debilitating for those with altered sleep/activity rhythms and for those with disorders linked to dysregulation of biological timing mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain ventricle is lined by specialized cells known as ependyma, which bears dozens of motile cilia. Ciliary beating contributes to the flow of cerebrospinal fluid. In the proposed study, we will determine whether occurrence of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) disrupts the development of ependyma and motile cilia and if so, how this can reversed to restore CSF flow and prevent hydrocephalus in the premature newborns with IVH. This research is relevant to public health because discovery of mechanisms by which IVH contributes to hydrocephalus will lead to interventions to prevent this disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Both mitochondrial and blood brain barrier (BBB) dysfunction have been independently associated with neuropsychiatric illness. Based on our recent publications and compelling preliminary data, we propose that in a relatively common genetic cause of neuropsychiatric illness, mitochondrial dysfunction contributes to BBB dysfunction and presents a novel therapeutic target. If our hypothesis is correct, this finding can shift paradigms for inflammatory influences on brain development and function based on the synergistic influences of relatively subtle structural and energetic weaknesses in the BBB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Decompensated HF is the leading cause of hospitalization. HF leads to water accumulation in the tissues (lungs and legs) resulting in shortness of breath and leg swelling. This project will advance the development of an accurate, inexpensive, easy to use device (“NIVAHF”) for volume measurements in patients with HF. Use of these devices will ultimately help health care providers and patients prevent water overload. The long-term goal is to prevent costly hospital readmissions, improve quality of life, and reduce mortality in patients with HF.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Alcohol dependence and alcohol use disorder (AUD), as well as stress-related disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) constitute a significant health concern for our Veterans. Given that the prevalence of AUD and PTSD comorbidity is especially high in Veterans, the need to better understand how stress interacts with alcohol is critical for developing more effective treatments for this significant health problem. This research project utilizes a model in which stress further enhances escalated alcohol drinking associated with dependence. The main objective of the project is to examine brain mechanisms underlying the ability of exercise to attenuate stress-enhanced drinking in dependent subjects. The ultimate goal is to provide new insights about mechanisms underlying a promising therapeutic intervention that will aid in treatment for individuals suffering from alcohol dependence and the exacerbating effects of stress that lead to harmful drinking - an especially important and clinically relevant problem for our Veteran patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease and metabolic syndromes are the rising health risk factor to our returning Gulf War and Afghanistan Veterans. Exercise-mediated hemodynamic forces impart both metabolic and mechanical effects to initiate atherosclerosis. While elucidating vascular metabolomic profiles in reponse to pulstile vs. disturbed flow uncovers metabolic biomarkers and therapeutic targets, developing 3-D electrochemical impedance sensors provides new insights into detecting arterial metabolic changes in response to hemodynamic forces.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Pre-deployment hazardous binge drinking is highly prevalent in active-duty US military personnel and can increase the likelihood of developing an alcohol use disorder. This is particularly relevant to combat veterans who increasingly treat symptoms of depression and anxiety by ‘self-medicating’ with alcohol. This research furthers the VA mission by identifying novel non-neuronal mechanisms that are involved in the dysregulation of neuronal activity and subsequent neuronal remodeling that occurs after binge ethanol exposure. Understanding these mechanisms in the context of synaptic dysfunction and the emergence of alcohol use disorder could lead to the development of novel pharmacotherapies designed to break the cycle of chronic substance abuse in this at-risk population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Photoreceptor dysfunction is one of the hallmark pathologies associated with retinal degenerative (RD) diseases that manifests in patients as a progressive loss of vision. This encompasses heterogenous diseases such as retinitis pigmentosa, which affects 1 in 3500 people worldwide and age-related macular degeneration, which is projected to affect 288 million people by 2040. We have shown modest exercise provides retinal neuroprotection in a mouse model of RD, through increased brain derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) signaling. The cellular modifications provoking neural protection and repair from exercise are not understood. Our proposal reveals novel data supporting retinal astrocyte and vasculature involvement in exercise-induced BDNF signaling. Our studies will illuminate the roles of retinal astrocytes and vasculature in this known neuroprotective therapy, ultimately optimizing exercise-based therapeutics and creating new pharmacological strategies targeting the underlying mechanisms of exercise-induced neuroprotection.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Obesity affects more veterans than the general population and even more so among veterans using VA health care services. Moreover, the number of obese older veterans has markedly increased because of both the increase in the aging of the veteran population and the percentage of older veterans who are obese. In older veterans, obesity aggravates the age-related decline in physical function resulting in frailty that leads to loss of independence in activities of daily living. However, lifestyle therapy resulting in weight loss in obese older adults remains controversial because of concerns about harmful effects of weight loss on muscle and bone mass in this population. Metformin, a drug widely used to treat diabetes, could slow the aging process and improve health span, the part of a person’s life during which they are in good health. It is possible that the addition of metformin to lifestyle therapy will reverse frailty and preserve muscle and bone mass in obese older veterans, thereby prevent their loss of independence and decrease need for admission to a VA nursing home care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Existing thermal ablation probes will be optimized to improve cure rates of a handheld device commonly used in low- and middle-income countries (LMIC). This thermal ablation device will be combined with a digital colposcope to provide triage and treatment in one instrument. In addition, a machine learning algorithm will be integrated into the new device to triage women at highest risk for cervical precancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Macrophage polarization enables macrophages adapt to different microenvironmental cues and acquire a spectrum of functional phenotypes, mainly including the classically activated (Pro-inflammatory, M1) and the alternatively (pro-healing, M2) activated phenotypes, of which the balance of M1/M2 is critical to the progression and severity of inflammatory responses and tissue damages. Thus, identification of the intracellular immune regulators that control macrophage polarization in periodontitis is key to redirect the dysregulated macrophage phenotypes and develop the novel host-directed therapeutics for this disease. We have identified the alternative macrophage polarization mediated by an oral model organism, porphyromonas gingivalis (Pg), that flows via SGK1-YAP1 signaling, a novel and potent regulatory module in periodontal inflammation, which will not only advance our understanding of the host immune response to Pg but also inform studies to identify novel targets to restore the balance of different macrophages subsets and thus ameliorate or prevent Pg-induced tissue destruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The mechanisms by which global regulatory proteins operate on their RNA targets are complex and are still largely not understood; understanding these mechanisms is crucial for preventing or alleviating bacterial infections and antibiotic resistance. The overarching goal of the proposed work is to characterize in vivo the molecular features that underlie novel CsrA-target interactions that we have recently uncovered as well as to decipher the biological relevance of these interactions; the CsrA protein is part of the Csr (carbon storage regulator) system, a global regulatory network known to impact virulence factors, secretion systems, and other important genes for rapid host adaptation in a number of pathogens. We expect these studies to further expand our knowledge of the diversity of post-transcriptional regulation approaches that global regulators can exert in bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The obligate intracellular parasites from the genus Plasmodium grow within human red blood cells, causing a lethal disease called malaria. The proposed research aims to understand the parasite-specific glycosylation pathways required for transporting proteins to specific sub-cellular locations within the infected red blood cell. The proposed study will help us identify targets for novel targets for antimalarial therapies, which are sorely needed because Plasmodium has developed resistance to all currently available antimalarial drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spiny mice naturally regenerate complex musculoskeletal tissues whereas other mammals use scar tissue to repair identical injuries. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to public health because discovering the cell types and molecules that permit and direct this unique example of mammalian regeneration is expected to generate novel clinical interventions to reduce fibrosis and enhance healing in humans. Stimulating tissue regeneration greatly improves the functionality of injured tissue and will help reduce the burden human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Modern genomic sequencing technologies have allowed the field to identify many risk genes associated with neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Here we propose to further investigate the effects of CHD8, a prominent ASD risk gene that we showed affects a major neuronal population of the brain, cortical GABAergic interneurons. We will use newly-developed “brain organoid” systems, cell culture models of human brain development derived from pluripotent stem cells, to understand the effect of this ASD risk gene on interneuron development and circuit function in the human cerebral cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Mechanisms that amplify the generation of intermediate progenitors boosts stem cell output in producing differentiated cells without increasing the frequency of stem cell division thereby safeguarding the long-term health of stem cells. However, not all stem cells display this amplification mechanism in the physiological context, and it is unclear how this capacity can be activated to increase the production of differentiated cells on demand. Our proposal will investigate the mechanisms that control the amplification of intermediate progenitors and how stem cell-specific functions can be properly regulated in general to ensure normal brain development and to prevent brain tumor formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our studies over the past several years have characterized the cholinergic anti-inflammatory reflex pathway (CAP), the neuroimmune axis that contributes to an anti-inflammatory response and prevention of acute kidney injury (AKI). We have found that either electrical vagus nerve stimulation or pulsed ultrasound (US) targeted to the spleen equally protects kidneys from AKI by activating the cholinergic anti-inflammatory reflex pathway (CAP), a neuroimmune circuit that controls systemic inflammation. Based upon these preclinical studies, we propose a pilot and feasibility study to demonstrate that pulsed US stimulation using a clinical ultrasound machine approved for its use in humans can be used effectively and safely in human subjects to attenuate the inflammatory function of immune cells collected from healthy subjects and patients undergoing cardiac surgery post US-stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study represents an important step in understanding why offspring of mothers with depression are at increased risk for depression themselves and may help to highlight the mechanisms underlying the development of an early-emerging risk factor – attentional avoidance of facial displays of sadness. These results could help provide important information not only about where to intervene but when to intervene with offspring of depressed mothers. As such, the results could pave the way for more focused interventions for at-risk children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work seeks to improve human health by developing strategies to risk stratify and identify candidate individuals for genetic testing and treatment in early life. With therapeutic intervention becoming available at earlier time points in life for treatable inherited genetic diseases, I aim to accelerate the time to diagnosis for these conditions. Access to genomic diagnostics and therapeutics in early life is often limited; my work aims to develop strategies to equitably deliver genomic medicine and offer earlier opportunities for diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Botulism is a severe and potentially lethal neuro-paralytic disease of long duration, lasting up to several months and requiring extensive medical care, which would create a devastating scenario in an unintentional or intentional large outbreak, yet, BoNTs are also widely used as valuable human biotherapies to treat more than 200 neuromuscular disorders. Besides an equine antiserum known as BAT, which can be improve and shorten disease outcome if given within the first 2-3 days intoxication when diagnosis often is still uncertain, there is no cure for botulism. Completion of the studies in this proposal will provide a detailed understanding of the mechanism responsible for BoNT duration and potency, which is essential for developments of novel countermeasures that are effective at later stages of the disease, and for development of new classes of BoNT therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The field of veterinary medicine is experiencing a crisis in mental health and well-being; evidence-based approaches to reduce this burden are critically needed. Recent research suggests that burden transfer to veterinary healthcare workers, occurring in the context of difficult client interactions, can be reduced using a tailored Acceptance and Commitment Training (ACT) intervention, which in turn improves psychosocial functioning. The proposed study will embed an asynchronous version of this intervention, adapted for students, into veterinary technician and medicine training programs, comparing an intervention group to controls, evaluating student reaction (i.e., engagement, perception of intervention), learning (i.e., demonstration of intervention knowledge), behavior (i.e., frequency of use of skills taught in the intervention), and results (i.e., burden transfer, stress, burnout, and symptoms of depression and anxiety) over one year as trainees transition into the workforce.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Effects of embedded Acceptance and Commitment Training in DVM and RVT programs as students transition into the workforce
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE This project will generate new information about copper entry into the developing and adult mammalian brain and determine the role that the blood-cerebrospinal barrier plays in Wilson disease neuropathology. This information will facilitate understanding of Wilson disease and other disorders associated with copper misbalance, including Menkes disease, Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative DNA inter-strand cross-links (ICLs) represent a dangerous type of DNA damage that human cells repair to avoid a variety of diseases including bone marrow failure and cancer. ICLs can be repaired in a variety of ways but the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. We have developed cellular extracts that recapitulate two distinct ICL repair pathways, and we will use these extracts to study the steps that lead to ICL repair, as well as the proteins that catalyze these steps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent and young adults (AYAs) with cancer want to discuss relevant sexual and reproductive health (SRH) issues and concerns with their oncology clinicians during treatment and in survivorship, yet these conversations rarely take place. This inadequate communication puts AYAs at immediate risk for making uninformed decisions involving contraception, safe sex practices, and fertility preservation, while the sequelae of not addressing body image, sexuality, and sexual dysfunction can lead to profound long-term consequences for future romantic relationships, family building, and overall quality of life. In the proposed study, we will use stakeholder input to develop, refine, and assess a novel AYA-centered communication intervention to improve SRH conversations between AYAs and their oncology clinicians, with the ultimate goal of increasing AYA access to critical SRH care and education that they need across the cancer continuum.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma ranks among the deadliest of all human cancers, with current therapies offering only palliation. In this research project, we will study how amino acid metabolism stimulates glioblastoma cells to grow and resist current therapies, empowering the design of potential new treatments for patients afflicted with glioblastoma.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our work to determine the regulatory mechanisms in linking protection of stalled replication fork integrity with innate immune response, if successful, will reveal new aspects of the replication stress response. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Using high-speed atomic force microscopy (HS-AFM), we have recently discovered a hitherto unobserved pentameric state of TRPV3, which we hypothesize to be the structural correlate to the so-far elusive pore-dilation phenomenon, characterized functionally by an increase in conductance, permeability to large ions and loss of rectification. In this project we will study the pentameric state further in terms of structure and function and determine if it is indeed related to the pore-dilated state and to the different gain-of-function mutations observed in TRPV3-channel related diseases. Results from these studies are expected to provide answers to some long- standing questions in the TRP-channel research field, and to pave the way for new avenues of structural, functional, and therapeutic approaches of TRPV channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Alterations in brain folding are linked to neurological and psychiatric disorders such as epilepsy, autism spectrum disorder, schizophrenia, and developmental delay. The purpose of this study is to understand the mechanical mechanisms that underlie folding, particularly the role of cortical growth gradients and white matter structure in normal and aberrant brain folding. The study will utilize computational modeling to test hypothesized mechanisms of brain folding, with validation based on high quality, longitudinal magnetic resonance imaging data previously collected from preterm infants and human fetuses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Proton radiotherapy is very sensitive to daily treatment setup variations and patients’ anatomical change during the treatment course. Our proposed study aims to develop an artificial-intelligent-driven online adaptive and personalized proton therapy system, which can calculate the discrepancy between the planned radiation dose and the actual dose distribution in patient’s daily anatomy before the delivery of each treatment and, if needed, generate a new plan for treatment within a few minutes. The proposed system is expected to change current clinical practice and result in a new paradigm of proton radiotherapy, ensuring that the therapeutic dose is delivered to the tumor region as desired at each treatment while minimizing treatment toxicity to improve patients’ quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The DNA repair protein XPC is an important regulator of somatic cell reprogramming. The overall objective of this proposal is to understand how XPC regulates TDG, an essential enzyme that removes repressive DNA methylation marks from genes, thereby activating transcription and a stem cell-like state in somatic cells. The knowledge gained will elucidate epigenetic regulation of cell state transitions, and how dysregulation of TDG-dependent pathways cause disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Botulinum neurotoxins pose a significant threat to the nation as a potential bioterrorism agent but are also widely utilized for medical treatment. PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to practical methods of identifying different sources of reading difficulty, including developmental language disorder (DLD), word reading difficulty (WRD), and co-occurring DLD/WRD, among Spanish-English bilingual children. PHR: Despite considerable efforts toward vaccination, influenza remains a significant source of morbidity and mortality in the U.S. Our studies demonstrate that the synthetic food additive, tBHQ, impairs the T cell response to influenza; the purpose of this proposal is to determine how and why this occurs. This knowledge will allow us to better predict how tBHQ exposure will impact immunity to influenza and other respiratory viruses as well as the effectiveness of vaccination and may also allow us to predict other chemicals that may impair T cell function in a similar way.

PHR: Project Narrative We previously conducted a pilot randomized placebo-controlled trial that found that the cesarean rate was lower in obese, nulliparous women who received prophylactic antibiotics during labor inductions. The currently proposed study is a multicenter trial evaluating the same intervention in that population. Should we have results similar to those in the pilot trial, prophylactic antibiotics for the indication of labor induction would represent a novel intervention to decrease the cesarean delivery rate in a group at high risk for that outcome

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Narrative: Parkinson's disease is a severe neurodegenerative disease. Current treatments are symptomatic and do not prevent disease progression. Thus, there is a need to identify new therapeutic targets. Neuroplasticity in the striatum has been found to underlie motor impairments in Parkinson's disease. However, the role of synaptic organizes in these neuroplastic changes and contribution to motor and non-motor dysfunction is not known. We propose to understand the role of a type of glutamate receptor which serves as a striatal synaptic organizer in neuroplasticity and behavioral impairment associated with Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Sex hormones can alter host responses and are a potential reason to why biologic males and females experience different outcomes following influenza virus infection. The proposed research will determine how estradiol, an estrogen steroid hormone, regulates lung inflammation, virus replication and other host processes during influenza virus infection in males and females. We expect to identify host responses that are differently regulated in biological males and females, which will suggest novel approaches to improve infection outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative To assemble complex molecules rapidly, efficiently, and with predictable outcomes is among the most significant challenges in the discovery of new medicinal agents. This proposal addresses several major technological gaps in the field of organic synthesis, and its successful completion will speed the preparation of novel medicinal lead structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: A robust and efficient vertebrate nervous system requires that axons be myelinated in the central nervous system (CNS) by myelinating glia during development and maintained and refined throughout life. However, how myelinating oligodendrocytes target specific structures and avoid others, is not known. In this proposal, using zebrafish as a vertebrate model, we will investigate the mechanisms that drive CNS myelin targeting and growth by studying junction adhesion molecules 2&3 (jams 2&3) and transmembrane protein 125b (tmem125b).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The subfamily of the tandem Coronins forms a structurally unique class among the extensive family of the Coronins, however to date their actin-regulatory functions remain completely unknown. Using a combination of single molecule techniques, protein crystallography, and cell biology, we will investigate how the mammalian tandem Coronin, Coro7, structurally and mechanistically inhibits Arp2/3-mediated nucleation induced by nucleation promoting factors (N-WASP, WHAMM, and JMY), and other Arp2/3 regulators, including GMF, and SPIN90. In addition, we will elucidate how these actin-regulatory activities of Coro7 work in concert with Arp2/3 and its various interactors in intracellular membrane transport and autophagy. Altogether, this proposal will shed light on the enigmatic actin- regulatory functions of the class of the tandem Coronins in vitro, and in cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major constraint in treating patients with vestibular loss is the lack of objective assessments of otolith and semicircular canal function. This project investigates whether novel video-oculography (VOG) measures of vestibular function can be used as valid markers to track recovery from vestibular loss and predict functional outcomes. The findings will be crucial towards devising rehabilitation therapies based on discrete measures of vestibular function in individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative High blood glucose shortly after a stroke is a frequent issue and often indicates less favorable recovery. Our research focuses on unraveling the intricate interactions between high blood glucose, red blood cells, and the consequent damage to brain blood vessels. By gaining a deeper understanding of these relationships, we aim to develop innovative approaches for diagnosis and treatment, ultimately improving the care and recovery of stroke patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We have known for decades that RAS mutations drive up to a quarter of all cancers and that each tumor type is enriched for a specific set of RAS variants. Our preliminary findings suggest that specific RAS variants are enriched in melanoma because they amplify the signals required for cancer initiation in melanocytes. This proposal will use a complement of structural, biochemical, cellular, and animal studies to define the properties of RAS mutants required to initiate melanoma, and test whether interventions that target pathways that enhance these properties can prevent tumor formation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ongoing studies demonstrate that male infertility can originate from disruptions during prepubertal development as the germline prepares for continuous sperm production. However, because the factors that regulate prepubertal germline development are largely unknown, progress towards diagnosing, preventing, or even treating male infertility has been stifled. The proposed studies will generate fundamental insights into the mechanisms that govern germ cell development, including that of the germline stem cell population and fate decisions that ultimately lay the groundwork for sperm production throughout reproductive years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survival for pediatric patients with high-risk neuroblastoma remains dismal, with even worse survival for Black patients and patients who experience adverse social determinants of health like household poverty. Despite the addition of GD2 antibody immunotherapy, disparities in outcome remain, suggesting racial differences in immunity may contribute to health inequity. The goal of this proposal is to characterize tumor and host immune landscapes before and after GD2 antibody and chemotherapy combinations in newly diagnosed high risk neuroblastoma patients, and correlate results with genomic ancestry, adverse social determinants of health, and survival on a multi-institutional phase 3 clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this R01 model development proposal, we plan to develop and characterize an autologous humanized mouse model for the study of immunotherapies in glioblastoma, utilizing tumor tissue and matched immune cells from the same patient. This model will incorporate an immune system, tumor model, and cell-based therapy from the same patient, removing any bias resulting from a mismatch in the immune systems and ensure experimental outcomes are relevant to the clinic. To validate the humanized model system, we will generate chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells from the same patient the tumor and immune system originate from and treat the humanized mice, allowing comparison of outcomes to patient data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Due to the alarming rise in antibiotic resistance development, we are in urgent need of new antibacterial therapies. Some of our most powerful current antibiotics (penicillins) are effective against bacteria because they cause unbalanced activity of “autolysins”, self-produced enzymes that kill cells by degrading the cell wall. Experiments proposed here will allow us to understand autolysins better, paving the way for new strategies to exploit bacterial self-destruction through the development of novel antibiotics that target autolysins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to test whether CD200R blockade, either genetically or using novel antagonist antibodies, enhances chemokine-mediated immune cell recruitment to tumors and T cell functions in tumors. We will also test if angiogenesis inhibitors will significantly increase the efficacy of CD200R blockade therapy. The information generated from this study will not only advance our understanding of cancer pathogenesis but also pave the way for human trials of CD200R blockade-based novel combination therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Novel statistical methods will be developed for integrated analysis of studies with disparate data structures, such as individual-level data from a main study and summary-statistics data from genome-wide association studies. Applications will lead to understanding the mediation and effect modification of genetic associations by environmental factors, developing a comprehensive disease risk prediction model, and the powerful discovery of genetic associations for complex diseases combining different depths of phenotype data across different studies. User-friendly and computationally efficient software will be developed and freely distributed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sale of cannabis for recreational use is rapidly becoming legal across states in the US. Products are often marketed directly to consumers using claims that are not supported by evidence. Specifically, products are commonly labeled as “Indica”, “Sativa” and “Hybrid” and are associated with corresponding marketing claims (“Indica” products more likely to have sedative claims, e.g., relaxation, sleep; Sativa-labeled products more likely to have energizing claims, e.g., focus, productivity). The current study provides evidence to inform cannabis labeling and marketing regulations by using a large-scale content analysis of cannabis marketing and labeling, a randomized online experiment, and a placebo-controlled randomized laboratory experiment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This research will help understand the molecular basis for two rare skeletal diseases - Jansen's Metaphyseal Chondrodysplasia (JMC) and Eiken Syndrome (ES) - that are caused by PTH/PTHrP receptor (PTH1R) mutations. The proposed research will build upon our in vitro findings showing how JMC- and ES-PTH1R mutants impact cellular mechanisms. We have furthermore generated mouse JMC and ES models to explore the impacts of the disease-causing PTH1R mutations on bone growth and kidney function, and to test new peptides and other compounds as potential therapies for these and possibly related disorders of bone and kidney physiology.
