IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current supply of cholera vaccines is insufficient, and new lower-cost cholera vaccines have been developed to control the disease globally. However, because we lack accurate immunologic tests to gauge cholera vaccine effectiveness (called ‘correlates of protection’) it is unclear how to best evaluate these new vaccines. In this study, we will identify correlates of protection for cholera which are associated with effective immunity, paving the path for the development and licensure of the next generation of cholera vaccines.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surfactant Protein A (SP-A), is an immunomodulatory protein associated with lung disease of prematurity, abnormal vascular growth, and with Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP); the leading cause of acquired childhood blindness worldwide. Understanding the function of this protein in normal and pathological contexts is critical to developing novel, rational and safe therapies for preventing and curing neovascular eye diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE People incarcerated in the United States are disproportionately affected by substance use disorders as well as chronic physical and mental health conditions, yet are known to under-utilize health services during the transition from prisons to communities. Reducing health disparities in this population requires evidence-based strategies to connect recently-incarcerated people to community-based care. This project will conduct a 2-arm randomized clinical trial to test the effectiveness of a protocolized transitional nurse case management intervention initiated prior to release and continuing for 3 months after release with phone-based support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AML is the most common acute leukemia but, despite the diffuse use of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), it still has the lowest survival rate of all leukemias. Adoptive immunotherapies are currently hampered by the absence of specific targets, most of which are often shared with healthy tissues and thus lead to immunosuppression/toxicity. Here, we will develop new gene editing strategies to generate a “stealth” hematopoiesis that is resistant to immunoglobulin-based drugs/CAR-T cells. Our strategy allows targeting multiple genes essential to leukemia survival, thus poorly amenable to escape mechanisms. It could be rapidly implemented in allogeneic-HSCT protocols currently used as standard treatment for high-risk subtypes of AML, like those with FLT3 mutation/ITD. Moreover, since our selected targets (FLT3, KIT and CD123) are expressed at high levels in a spectrum of several hematologic malignancies, our strategy could provide more efficacious yet less toxic therapeutic options for several blood cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In the U.S., radon-induced lung cancer accounts for 21,000 deaths annually, yet the disease remains highly preventable by eliminating exposure to the deadly gas. RADAR 2.0 will address community concerns about high lung cancer rates by building capacity for radon mitigation in rural communities and discovering radon risk messaging intended to prompt radon risk reduction behavior. Additionally, we will support public health action by developing an automated report-back website and investigate the soil processes and characteristics to support pre-construction radon risk forecasting and radon resistant new construction policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance This trial will evaluate a web-based, system-level intervention that addresses persistent gaps in PMTCT care by facilitating guideline-adherent services to optimize HIV prevention and maternal health. The HIV Infant Tracking System (HITSystem) 2.1 will prospectively follow HIV-positive pregnant women through 6 months postpartum, employing accessible technologies to ensure complete and timely engagement in clinical care, and robust management of maternal viral loads during critical windows for preventing new HIV infections. Such improvements are essential before low resource countries can close the remaining gaps and eliminate mother- to-child transmission of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will use engage key stakeholders in designing and iteratively optimizing an online substance use intervention for high school seniors. The optimized behavioral intervention then can be readily adopted by high schools across the US to prevent and reduce substance use and related negative consequences among both college students and nonstudent young adults. In addition, project results will (1) indicate which strategies effectively change mediators, (2) test several novel intervention strategies (i.e., using normative education to change norms about other behaviors linked to substance use; targeting anticipatory socialization); and (3) identify individual and contextual factors that moderate component efficacy, paving the way for more effective, efficient, and potentially tailored interventions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ensuring appropriate utilization of deceased donor kidneys and preventing needless discards of usable kidneys requires expert pathologist interpretations of preimplantation kidney biopsies, but expert kidney pathologists are often unavailable in real time and biopsy interpretations from on-call general pathologists are unreliable and inconsistent. We will apply innovative artificial intelligence (AI) techniques to the interpretation of preimplantation kidney biopsies, and we will link biopsy data with national transplant recipient registry data to develop and validate predictive models of key post-transplant outcomes. Further, we will study attitudes of key stakeholders and catalog facilitators and barriers to implementation of AI-assisted preimplantation biopsy interpretation, to encourage rapid clinical adoption of this technology which could increase transplants, improve outcomes, and assist kidney transplant providers and patients in evaluating the 50,000 kidneys recovered for potential transplantation per year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research will reveal how Insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding proteins (IMPs) contribute to neuronal temporal fating and further elucidate their roles in stem cell behavior. Knowledge of endogenous neuronal cell fating mechanisms is needed for cell replacement therapies to treat neurological disorders. Moreover, IMPs are upregulated in cancer cells, correlating with poor prognosis; our results may help reveal new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Current medications for the treatment of neuropathic pain are only marginally effective and suffer from serious, sometimes life-threatening, side effects. Inhibiting the activity of the α9α10 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor is emerging as a promising strategy to treat neuropathic pain; however, technical challenges have limited the investigation of this receptor and prevented the discovery of drugs that target it. This project overcomes this historical hurdle in α9α10 drug discovery to identify novel α9α10 antagonists and provide strong evidence to support their future development into new treatments for neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is estimated to cause 20% of deaths worldwide, though we have a poor understanding of sepsis and no effective treatments. Our understanding of sepsis is limited by both improper collection of blood samples and ambiguous clinical phenotyping. This project addresses both of these problems by 1) improving the quality of blood collected from sepsis patients that prevents artifactual oxidation during specimen collection and storage, and 2) linking molecular data including those associated with redox immunometabolism to clinical sepsis phenotypes. These blood samples, molecular and clinical data will provide researchers with new tools to find effective treatments for sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop, test, apply, and disseminate new features for multilevel statistical models and software to estimate effects of intraindividual means, variances, slopes of time-varying variables on cancer control outcomes using intensive longitudinal data collected over much longer periods than the typical single burst design. The results will make notable methodological and substantive contributions for the analysis and application of intensive longitudinal data cancer control research. Given the enormous health burdens imposed by cancer, such information could be of significant value to efforts to improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Our studies use a human model system to investigate the lineage plasticity that frequently accompanies progression to aggressive muscle invasive bladder cancer, and thus has strong translational relevance. The proposed analyses will elucidate the alterations of chromatin landscapes at the single-cell level that occur during luminal-basal plasticity and will provide essential insights into the mechanistic basis of the epigenomic reprogramming that drives this plasticity. Furthermore, our analyses of luminal-basal plasticity will identify novel approaches for increasing response to an antibody-drug conjugate that is currently approved for treatment of locally advanced and metastatic bladder cancer, thereby leading to improvements in therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with athymia have a complete absence of T cells due to the lack of thymus and will die within the first two years of life without thymic replacement. Current therapeutic approaches are not sustainable or reliable leading to long wait times during which time patients continue to suffer from complications associated with immunodeficiency. Thymmune Therapeutics is developing a scalable stem cell-based therapy for patients with athymia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Repair of the infarcted heart requires timely recruitment and activation of immune and reparative cells. The dynamic changes in the extracellular matrix network play a central role in regulating phenotype and function of infarct cells, acting through binding to the integrins, a family of cell surface receptors that transduce signals, regulating cell behavior. Our proposal examines for the first time the role of integrins in macrophages and fibroblastss infiltrating the infarct, investigates central mechanisms involved in repair, angiogenesis and fibrosis, and dissects the molecular cascades modulated by cell-specific integrin activation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Receiving parental care is essential for appropriate physical, cognitive, and emotional development in infants across species, and failure to care for an infant predisposes an individual to neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders. Caregiving behavior is mediated by neural circuits that promote parental bonding with infants. In this grant, we propose to study the neurobiology underlying the expression of pro- and anti-parental behavior in males and females across behavioral states at the circuit, cellular, synaptic, and molecular levels.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Resting-state (RS) neural activity shows rapid changes across the first years of life (the background against which brain function and behavior emerge), with RS activity in older children and adults indexing the inhibition of task-irrelevant processes, associated with top-down cognitive control processes, central to how local networks process information, and associated with our ability to quickly process information. Our understanding of RS activity in infants and toddlers is limited by challenges that have so far hindered research in this area, with this project making progress via (1) the use of a RS task optimized for infants and toddlers, (2) using recently developed algorithms to more accurately measure RS activity, (3) obtaining measures of RS activity in brain space to test theories associating RS neural activity with brain structure, chemistry, and developmental milestones, and (4) obtaining temporally dense brain measures as understanding brain development requires assessing maturational processes. In this prospective cohort design, brain development and behavior will be examined at baseline in infants 0 to 4 months (N=70) and then longitudinally at 4-month intervals with the final visit at 12 to 16 months (4 visits in total), with finding greatly extending our understanding of infant/toddler resting-state neural activity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary embolism (PE) is the third leading cause of cardiovascular death, with post-PE complications leading to drastic reductions in quality of life and chronic functional limitations, as well as an increased risk of recurrent PE. This proposal will utilize a novel murine model of PE, single nucleus molecular profiling, and longitudinal multiplexed molecular imaging to noninvasively access the contribution of PE size and age on the resultant inflammatory and pulmonary fibrotic response while also quantifying the salutatory effects of fibrinolysis therapy. These findings aim to elucidate novel targets and molecular imaging agents to aid in better diagnosis and stratification of patients with PE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Before you can see the retina produces neural activity that guides development of the brain’s visual system. This project will explore how the cortex and the thalamus work together to actively transform this input to a form uniquely suited for early visual maturation, using a rodent model of fetal brain development. Our long- term objective is to understand the special role that fetal rhythms play in the maturation of vision, to be able to identify and treat consequences of preterm birth and perinatal brain injury such as cerebral visual impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ewing sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor with poor outcomes for patients with relapsed or metastatic disease. We have identified that PAK4 contributes to Ewing sarcoma development and metastasis, and we propose to further understand the mechanistic role of PAK4 through dissection of its direct downstream signaling networks and role as a novel regulator of alternative splicing. Finally, we will validate PAK4 as a novel therapeutic target for high-risk Ewing sarcoma in combination with chemotherapy and other targeted agents, which is relevant to public health and the NIH's mission because understanding and validating new therapeutic targets for pediatric sarcomas will improve patient survival while minimizing toxic effects of current therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The human gut microbiota is a diverse collection of microbes crucial to our health and well- being. This proposal seeks to both define whether one specific metabolite present in our gut, in combination with our diet, shapes the composition of a very important group of bacteria critical to our health and whether these bacteria in turn affect the levels of this metabolite which has profound impacts on our health. These studies will be instrumental toward efforts to develop interventions to shape the composition and function of our gut microbiome to promote health and treat a wide variety of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive condition characterized by uncontrolled pulmonary vascular cell proliferation that ultimately leads to right heart failure and death. In this proposal, we will uncover novel mechanisms that are involved in hemolysis-mediated pulmonary vascular remodeling. This work may provide important new answers to the question of why hemolytic patients have a higher susceptibility to PAH and may lead to the discovery of new, more targeted therapeutics for this incurable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although obesity develops at a similar rate for both sexes, the biology underlying excessive weight gain in men and women is thought to be substantially different. While a dysregulated hypothalamic neural network critically contributes to the development of obesity, the intraneuronal signaling mechanisms underlying sex-specific control of body weight remain vague. The proposed research seeks to identify a critical hypothalamic signaling pathway that affects metabolic homeostasis in a sex-specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with mental health conditions that affect the functioning of the front of the brain – anterior lateral prefrontal cortex – can experience difficulties with high-level abilities such as reasoning, planning, multi- tasking, judging the accuracy of their memories, and decision-making. We seek to gain mechanistic insights regarding the function and detailed anatomy of this region in humans, through a combination of tightly controlled cognitive tasks and powerful magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods. We expect that this theoretically novel and methodologically sophisticated research will advance our understanding of the function of a brain region that is critical for day-to-day life and work in our complex modern world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we will leverage the expertise of our team in Magnetic Resonance Fingerprinting (MRF), machine learning, and pulse sequence optimization to develop and optimize a rapid and robust quantitative MR technique, applicable to high-resolution volumetric brain imaging. The high-resolution 3D MRF imaging and reconstruction pipeline to be developed in this project will make quantitative MRI more accessible in clinical settings. We will also develop a cloud-based post-processing pipeline for convenient sharing and setup of our imaging technologies across imaging sites, promoting method validation and clinical translation.

PHR: Building on our success in the IGNITE research network, we are well positioned to drive the implementation of genomic medicine. Indiana University has clinical and research infrastructure spanning the state of Indiana capable of building upon its existing genomics-enabled learning health system infrastructure and disseminating implementation strategies and tools in partnership with other national sites. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac rehabilitation (CR) is an evidence-based, available, reimbursable treatment for cardiovascular disease (CVD) that reduces secondary cardiovascular risk, but adherence to cardioprotective behaviors established during CR (weight management, physical activity [PA], medication adherence) diminish with time effectively furthering health disparities in cardiovascular care; this represents a public health crisis. This study will use the Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial (SMART) design to develop an adaptive stepped-care intervention sequence for 400 under-resourced or under-represented CR patients following CR graduation intended to rescue patients from non-adherence and preserve cardioprotective behavior engagement. The technology-based interventions will be evaluated across 6 months, and the primary outcome is to determine the best intervention for adherent and non-adherent patients measured by adherence to the 3 key behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Microbial pathogens display proteins, pili, and glycopolymers that are important for their viability and pathogenicity. We will elucidate the molecular mechanisms that underpin the display of these macromolecules in gram-positive bacteria. Chemical libraries that sum to more than 200,000 small molecules will be screened using a novel cell-based assay to identify glycopolymer assembly inhibitors that could be developed into antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Currently, hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is the most devastating disease in dermatology, with tunnel formation resulting in a major impact to patients’ quality of life and significant burden and associated costs to the health care system. Our long-term goal is to develop targeted therapies that can restore function of the tissue and prevent disease progression. Better understanding of the mechanisms that control local tissue cortisol synthesis and signaling in HS tunnels, coupled with the novel 3D organoid HS model will facilitate a clear path to translating this knowledge to develop novel advanced therapeutic approaches for HS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This proposal investigates whether complete or selective hepatic insulin resistance combines T2D (type 2 diabetes) with NAFLD (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease) that progresses to life-threatening NASH (nonalcoholic steatohepatitis). We use genetic and metabolomic approaches in mice fed a western GAN diet or a related high fructose diet, which model the sugar-sweetened food and beverages associated with T2D and NAFLD/NASH in people. Our experiments investigate whether Follistatin secreted from the insulin resistant liver integrates NAFLD/NASH with glucose intolerance of type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Voice and upper airway (VUA) diseases hamper a person’s speaking and breathing functions when performing day-to-day activities. In this project, we will develop a flexible, wireless wearable device to monitor VUA symptoms via a unique, hybrid accelerometry and electromyography sensing technology. With this new wearable system, clinicians will be able to track patient VUA health conditions outside clinics, whereas patients will be empowered to be more in charge of their health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism affects the brain’s capacity to interpret and respond to social information, including human faces. In this project, we use advanced imaging methods to measure the structure and connectivity of the part of the visual cortex that responds preferentially to faces in each individual, and how these measures of brain anatomy relate to face recognition ability. By focusing on brain structure and individually defined regions, rather than brain function and group averages, we hope to fill significant gaps in our knowledge and to shed light on the developmental mechanisms by which early visual experience shapes the social brain in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Cocktails of individually efficacious phages have been proposed as a strategy to create clinically viable phage therapeutics with sufficient spectrum of activity to combat highly resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa. As such, this project will generate a highly optimized N-phage cocktail using a hybrid machine learning-pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic paradigm to strategically select N-phage components, dose, and administration schedule to maximize the killing of multi- and extensively-drug resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This project will leverage phage whole-body distribution from our murine pneumonia model to establish a human, physiologically based pharmacokinetic model, which will allow detailed assessment of expected human exposures to phage and describe key aspects of target-mediated phage distribution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Leigh Syndrome (LS) is an inherited mitochondrial disease that presents with prominent neurologic symptoms and death in childhood, with no effective therapies for this devastating disease currently available. Recent studies by our laboratory (Brestoff et al., Cell Metabolism, 2021) and other groups indicate that many cell types transfer their mitochondria to other cells in vivo, and our recent work demonstrates that administering healthy mitochondria to Ndufs4-deficient mice with LS completely restores cell-intrinsic metabolic defects (Borcherding et al., Cell Metabolism, 2022). The proposed studies will leverage our expertise in intercellular mitochondria transfer to establish two novel therapeutic strategies - postnatal mitochondria administration (Aim 1) and bone marrow transplantation (Aim 2) - to treat fatal inherited mitochondrial diseases such as LS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some pneumonia survivors, including those with post-intensive care unit syndrome, suffer from cognitive deficits, reducing their quality of life and inflicting healthcare and financial hardships. Strikingly, pneumonia-associated microorganisms (e.g., P. aeruginosa) trigger lung endothelial production and release of several cytotoxic amyloids (e.g., tau and Aβ) that are key pathological hallmarks of dementia. Whether pneumonia-elicited lung endothelial cytotoxic tau variants initiate blood-brain barrier breakdown to induce neurovascular unit dysfunction (e.g., pericyte injury, gliosis, and impaired hemodynamics), and whether APOE-ε4-induced neurovascular unit dysfunction exacerbates the negative impact of lung endothelial tau on the brain remains to be determined and are the focus of this study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Genetic differences between people and populations can impact the risk of adverse effects from environmental exposures. Improved understanding of the relationship between genetic susceptibility and the environment is critical to protecting public health. Current approaches have had limited success in identifying human health relevant interactions. We propose a fundamentally different approach to functional assess commonly variant human genes for their role in specific environmental exposures which could enable more effective human risk assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Mu opioids such morphine and fentanyl are potent in relieving pain, but they produce many side-effects such as tolerance and addiction, leading to the worldwide opioid epidemic and climbing opioid overdose death. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD), which includes ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn’s disease (CD), are diseases of the gastrointestinal tract that result from abnormal immune response to luminal antigens in genetically-susceptible individuals. IBD represents a disease of major interest, with more than 3 million American afflicted with this chronic inflammatory disorder. The proposed studies are designed to identify and harness information from novel inflammation-related metabolic pathways that promote tissue healing through interactions with metabolites derived from bacteria found in the lumen (i.e. the “microbiota”). Such studies should provide new avenues into our understanding of why inflammatory diseases develop, and in particular, how innate immune responses contribute to inflammatory resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A major clue to the nature of disease in multiple sclerosis is suggested by the increased amounts of antibody in the brain and cerebrospinal fluid of MS patients. We have developed unique strategies to produce large amounts of this cerebrospinal fluid antibody in tissue culture cells and have demonstrated that antibody binds to myelin proteolipid membrane complex and produces demyelination, oligodendrocyte cell death and tissue damage when injected into the brain of mice. The goals of this proposal are to (1) molecularly dissect the specific antigenic targets identified by complex MS myelin-specific antibodies, (2) determine the prevalence of various epitope-specific CSF and serum PLP1 Abs in MS patients and correlate their presence and titer with disease severity, and (3) delineate the role of pathogenic PLP1 Abs in MS lesion pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer genomes are shaped by mutation and chromosome rearrangement. Understanding mutational processes driving these alterations advances our understanding of how cancer develops and has potential to lead to new cancer therapies. Building on methods unique to our laboratory, we propose to elucidate the mechanisms of catastrophic mutational processes that drive very rapid evolution of cancer genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop scalable computational methods for estimating probabilistic model parameters and in- ferring genealogical information across different timescales, which will significantly facilitate the analysis and interpretation of human genome variation as well as single-cell genomics data. The user-friendly software tools stemming from this research will be broadly applicable to scale up inference under many settings, thereby en- abling the biomedical research community to better harness massive genomic data to improve human health. In particular, the methods developed in this project will be applied to study the biology of metastasis in cancer and antibody maturation in the immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Risk-taking is a hallmark characteristic of adolescence; while risk-taking is an essential component of evolutionary survival and experiential learning, maladaptive or irrational risk-taking in adolescence is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. During this critical life stage, profound brain remodeling and behavioral development may be influenced by early-life environmental exposures, affecting developmental trajectories related to risk-taking, yet such research is challenging, time-intensive, and costly to perform. We will leverage an ongoing cohort study to assess the impact of early-life metal exposures on developmental trajectories of adolescent risk-taking behaviors spanning more than 20 years, critical research needed to understand risk-taking behaviors and inform effective and timely interventions to promote optimal adolescent development.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Our proposed research focuses on the return of internalized macromolecules to the cell surface from endosomes (endocytic recycling), a basic cell biological processes that is of fundamental importance to many areas of biomedicine. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative While bone tissue dynamically adapts to mechanical stimuli to maintain its strength, disrupted signaling between bone cells is a major factor in the initiation and progression of many skeletal diseases that are difficult and costly to treat. The proposed work will use a novel model system to expand our understanding of how mechanical stimuli determine the adaptive response of bone tissue.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite decades of research into the pathophysiology of AKI and improvements in supportive care, acute kidney injury (AKI) remains a major clinical problem with high mortality rates. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Most patients with cancer succumb to their disease because cancer cells can disseminate to various organs, a complex process called metastasis, which is hard to detect early on, to prevent and to treat. This grant proposal focuses on developing a mechanistic understanding of one of the earliest steps in metastasis, the formation of the pre-metastatic niche, and on testing the hypothesis that small vesicles released by tumor cells and taken by sentinel immune cells in organs prone to metastasis trigger an inflammatory reaction that favors organ colonization by metastatic tumor cells. The long-term goal is to identify targets within the metastatic process to intervene when it is in early development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest forms of cancers. It is estimated that 8 million Americans have pancreatic cystic lesion, the only readily identifiable precursor of pancreatic cancer. The purpose of this program is to develop the in vivo optical technique that can be used during minimally invasive endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration (EUS-FNA) procedures, providing accurate diagnosis of pancreatic cystic lesions and assessment of their malignant potential, needed to improve life-saving decisions and help to deal with the large prevalence of cysts being discovered recently with MRI/CT imaging.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to define and characterize a novel cellular therapeutic strategy to treat autoimmune diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The regulation of RNA in biological systems plays an important role in gene expression programs and defects in this process can lead to human disease. A major mechanism for RNA regulation is through interactions with cellular RNA-binding proteins, and therapeutics that modulate these interactions are currently in development. This proposal seeks to develop a general method for characterizing RNA-protein and RNA-small molecule interactions with application to the development of novel RNA-targeted drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy surgery can result in seizure freedom or a marked reduction in seizures in approximately two-thirds of children with intractable seizures who have been carefully selected, with minimal adverse functional loss. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is an important non-invasive tool that allows the neurosurgeon to precisely map regions of the brain supporting critical functions that should be preserved; however, excessive head motion can lead to mis-identification of these regions, with direct implications for treatment. The proposed project, “Improved 3D EPI for pre-surgical mapping of epilepsy” promises to deliver a highly innovative imaging method capable of producing high-quality functional maps in the presence of uncontrolled head motion by tracking the position of the head and updating the acquisition in real-time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic myeloid leukemia is a devastating blood cancer currently treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors for a lifetime because most patients relapse upon treatment discontinuation. The main goals of this project are to understand how the kinase DYRK2 abrogates self-renewal and survival of leukemia stem cells and to identify drugs that can stabilize DYRK2 protein and eradicate leukemic stem cells in frontline therapies, which will allow patients to achieve the clinical milestone of cure or treatment-free remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Summary Retinal/choroidal vascular diseases including neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD), diabetic macular edema (DME), and proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) are prevalent causes of vision loss. Vascular endothelial growth factor-A (VEGF-A) is a key stimulator and intraocular injections of VEGFA antagonists provides great benefits. However, outcomes are suboptimal because other vasoactive factors contribute in some patients and because patients and physicians have difficulty maintaining the frequency of injections needed to control neovascularization (NV) and exudation. While Faricimab, which targets both VEGF-A and angiopoietin 2, may have slightly greater durability than specific VEGF-A antagonists, it does not provide better efficacy and there are many patients treated with Faricimab who have suboptimal outcomes. Treatments that target other contributing factors in addition to VEGFA and provide sustained release to reduce treatment burden are needed and this proposal addresses both of those needs. In the previous grant period, we demonstrated that AXT107, a collagen IV-derived 20-mer peptide mimetic, strongly suppresses NV and vascular leakage in models relevant to nAMD, DME, and PDR and elucidated part of its mechanism of action; it binds integrins αvβ3 and α5β1 and blocks their co-receptor functions resulting in suppression of VEGF and hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) signaling and conversion of angiopoietin 2 (Ang2) from a Tie2 antagonist to a Tie2 agonist. When injected into the vitreous of rabbits, AXT107 self-aggregated into a gel that slowly eroded providing sustained release and prolonged suppression of NV and vascular leakage. This led to clinical trials in nAMD and DME which demonstrated sustained suppression of exudation in many patients, but in some patients the gels were not compact and fragmented, resulting in dispersion of particles into the anterior chamber, occluding trabecular meshwork and increasing intraocular pressure. These studies have helped to validate αvβ3 and α5β1 as important therapeutic targets, but also demonstrated that more knowledge is needed to better understand exactly how they interact with RTKs, which interactions are important, and rationally design an antagonist that can be provided by sustained delivery. AXT107 is still a clinical candidate if a new sustained delivery approach can be developed, but in addition, it provides a tool along with newly developed analogs to further explore the mechanism by which antagonism of αvβ3 and α5β1 suppresses NV and exudation providing new knowledge that can guide development of improved next generation antagonists of αvβ3 and α5β1. Thus, this proposal will explore detailed mechanisms by which signaling through αvβ3 and α5β1 promote retinal/choroidal NV and exudation and how best to utilize that knowledge for design of therapeutic peptides, while at the same time solving issues related to delivery of AXT107 to allow additional clinical testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Policymakers lack critical evidence on the effects of promising interventions to address food and nutrition insecurity because of no available evidence on long-term population health, effects on health disparities, and cost-effectiveness. Using our NIH-funded, validated, state-of-the-art, and dynamic microsimulation model, this project will measure the longer-term health outcomes, health equity, and economic impact of four highly promising policy interventions to address food and nutrition insecurity on the US adult population and across racial/ethnic and socioeconomic groups. This proposal seeks to fill these gaps by improving our understanding of the health equity and economic effects of different food and nutrition interventions and providing important evidence to support national priorities around diet-related diseases and health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE CD4+ T cells play key roles in orchestrating immune responses to infections and cancers and have been implicated in most autoimmune diseases. Key to their participation in these settings is activation by antigen- derived peptides that are produced by an array of poorly understood intracellular pathways. We propose to identify these pathways using a variety of complementary techniques and highly customized reagents, with an eye to enhancing rational vaccine design and treatments for autoimmune diseases and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Many neurodevelopmental disorders result from mutations in proteins that regulate transcription, particularly those that control histones. Histones wrap DNA into complex structures to regulate transcription and are modified by posttranslational modifications, which help to control this process. We propose to study how disruption of these modifications affects neuronal function and leads to neurodevelopmental deficits.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Transient cerebral ischemia occurs in many clinical settings, including transient ischemic attack, cardiac arrest, hypovolemic shock, etc. Most cerebral ischemia survivors have long-term neurological sequelae due to brain ischemia reperfusion injury. This proposal will use state-of-the-art animal models and advanced imaging technologies to study the underlying mechanisms and corresponding treatment strategies for brain ischemia reperfusion injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The mammalian cell cycle is commonly conceived as a hard-wired pathway, but emerging work indicates that the cell cycle is much more plastic than is generally believed, with multiple routes to cell division under different conditions. The proposed project uses single-cell time-lapse microscopy and cell tracking to determine how cells are able to rapidly adapt to inhibition of a key cell-cycle regulator called CDK2. The proposed work will reveal how the cell cycle is wired for success even in the face of perturbations, which may identify ways to improve the therapeutic efficacy of targeted cell-cycle inhibitors to treat human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Neurodegenerative diseases, including Parkinson’s disease (PD), Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), are among the fastest growing diseases afflicting millions of people worldwide with tremendous economic and societal burdens. A highly conserved and less understood family of human Tubulin Polymerization Promoting Proteins (TPPP) is implicated in PD and related disorders. Using a model system and postmortem human brains of healthy individuals and PD patients, this proposal seeks to elucidate novel mitochondrial mechanisms underlying TPPP functions in promoting neuronal survival and gain insights into disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our scientific premise leverages minority stress theory and builds on literature that indicates that: a) sexual minority (SM) versus heterosexual young adults (YAs) display higher rates of tobacco use initiation, current use, and escalations in use along with fewer successful quit attempts; b) SMYAs experience minority stress, including mental health problems, family stress, less peer support, and discrimination; c) SMYAs residing in rural (vs. urban) areas may be especially vulnerable to experiencing minority stress due to greater community- based stigma toward SM individuals; and d) rural individuals face higher tobacco use rates and related mortality. The overall goal of this research is to address knowledge gaps in prevention and cessation efforts targeting SMYAs, by examining minority stress factors (i.e., mental health problems, family stress, less peer support, discrimination) as mediators of the associations between rural versus urban status and tobacco use outcomes (i.e., any current use, specific product use, changes in use status/level) among SMYAs over time via longitudinal survey assessments and in real time via ecological momentary assessments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative IRAK1 kinase is a core transducer of Toll-like receptor (TLR)-mediated innate immunity in vertebrates, with no reported role outside of the pathogen response. We recently identified IRAK1 as essential for cell survival in response to ionizing radiation (gIR), acting in a pathway distinct from TLR signaling. We will elucidate the spatiotemporal dynamics and molecular mechanisms of IRAK1 activation after gIR, as well as illuminate its biologic role.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The enzymes of the proline cycle are central to the metabolic shift that occurs in cancer cells to enable tumorigenesis and metastasis. This project will develop chemical probes of proline cycle enzymes and use them to discover novel cellular mechanisms of proline metabolism in cancer. The proposed research is a key initial step in establishing the tractability of the proline cycle as a therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Adolescents with migraine experience changes in their migraine symptoms during puberty, however, the mechanisms through which such changes occur remain unclear and individuals who will experience worsening, no change, or improvement of their symptoms cannot be identified. This goal of this study is to identify the baseline factors that determine migraine prognosis and characterize the changes in these factors preceding or following changes in migraine symptoms in adolescents. The results of this study will address an important knowledge gap concerning adolescent migraine and will enable the development of novel early- preventive strategies or personalized medical interventions for migraine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schizophrenia is a common and debilitating mental illness with relatively unknown etiology or pathophysiology. We are proposing to identify pathophysiology by studying neurons derived from schizophrenia patient and control induced pluripotent stem cells. Electrophysiology, cell biology, imaging, and molecular analyses will be applied to these models to discover pathophysiology associated with specific clinical and cognitive symptomatology unique to each individual patient with the goal of developing new therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human lupus nephritis is a common severe manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus that is often unresponsive to conventional therapies. We propose to identify and quantify the immune states within the kidney that predict progressive renal damage. We will then use similar and complementary techniques to identify which mouse models of lupus nephritis manifest specific human pathogenic mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement)  Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by lung inflammation that results in bronchoconstriction and thickened airway walls, ultimately causing difficulty in breathing. We propose to study the role of an enzyme known as Diacylglycerol Kinase in regulating constrictor and proliferative functions of airway smooth muscle cells and the inflammatory response of immune cells with an overarching goal of establishing these enzymes as novel therapeutic targets in managing asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative The goal of this project is to identify the neuronal ensembles of the voluntary induction and maintenance of alcohol dependence using single-cell whole-brain functional connectomics. We will identify the role of CRF and dynorphin neurons in the whole-brain networks during intoxication, withdrawal, abstinence, and stress-induced relapse. We will also identify the brain networks modulated by pharmacological treatments known to affect alcohol-related behaviors and identify the brain networks that are specific to high-intensity binging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project is to develop a novel imaging technology that combines a compact PET device with any clinical ultrasound scanner to enable real-time visualization of molecularly targeting agents in a patient. It offers interactive PET scanning capability and adds molecular contrast to ultrasound scanners while scanning a patient freehand. This enabling technology will change the status quo and bring novel molecular imaging and interventional applications to many point-of-care settings such as operating room, emergency room or patient bedside.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Currently, there is no treatment for CCHF, a potentially fatal viral hemorrhagic fever disease. The ultimate goal of this project is isolate and make antibodies against this virus by studying the antibody response from survivors of this disease. We will test the antibodies in a mouse model in the hope that these antibodies can eventually be used to treat CCHF infection in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac rehabilitation (CR) is an effective evidence-based intervention that improves event-free survival in cardiac patients through continued program participation, but fewer than 10% of all eligible patients who receive CR (<30%) in the United States attend all prescribed CR sessions, with even lower rates observed among racial and ethnic minoritized groups. A hybrid CR intervention that combines optimal features of telehealth, home-, and clinic-based CR (i.e., TeleheartCR) could increase CR participation by addressing structural barriers to access, while retaining the functional capacity benefits for which CR is known. The goal of this proposal is to conduct a randomized controlled trial comparing TeleheartCR with traditional clinic-based CR in a diverse group of cardiac patients to test differences in (1) program adherence (% of total sessions completed), and (2) pre-to-post program change in functional capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative CHD2 has been identified as a significant risk factor for neurodevelopmental disorders, including Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), epilepsy, Intellectual Disability (ID), and Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). As a chromatin remodeling protein, CHD2 regulates the expression of numerous downstream target genes, but the way in which various signaling pathways controlled by CHD2 converge and integrate functionally at the molecular and cellular levels in the nervous system remains largely unknown. We will systematically investigate how these signaling pathways interact during synaptic homeostatic plasticity and how distinct CHD2 disease risk variants impact synaptic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nuclear envelope protects the nuclear environment to maintain genome integrity. The proposed work will determine how distinct regulation of bilayer lipid composition controls the formation of the nuclear envelope to protect the genome. Defining the role of membrane lipid composition in nuclear envelope formation has the potential to significantly contribute to our understanding of how defects in nuclear envelope integrity arise in human genetic disorders and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell immunotherapy is a powerful treatment for hematologic malignancies, however clinical responses vary depending on CAR T cell function and persistence. The optimization of CAR design has gained considerable interest with a new focus on calibrating CAR intracellular signals via the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifs (ITAMs) to increase fitness of CAR T cells. In this proposal we will test the hypothesis that finetuning the combination of ITAM sequences of the CD3 zeta ITAM alters the kinetics of kinase and adaptor molecule recruitment, influencing bond lifetime and the quality of intracellular signaling resulting in long-lived tumor killing T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) remains a leading cause of cancer deaths in males and there is a tremendous unmet clinical need to uncover mechanisms of therapeutic resistance in this patient population. This study will discover and validate bacterial enzymatic pathways that are responsible for androgen production in the gut that contributes to therapeutic resistance to immunotherapy and endocrine therapy in mCRPC. We ultimately aim to identify a microbiome drug target for use in the development of targeted therapeutics to overcome treatment resistance; as such, we anticipate that the knowledge gained from the proposed studies could be translated to a therapeutic that could greatly impact the lives of individuals with advanced mCRPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall – Narrative Climate change is and will remain the most significant threat to global public health; the need for robust scientific evidence to guide maximally effective and equitable action is paramount. To address this urgent need and build capacity in climate and health research, we have designed the Climate and Health: Action and Research for Transformational Change (CHART) Center. CHART’s mission and overarching aim is to launch a transformative and integrative framework for climate health research, from molecules to populations, that drives evidence-based impactful solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop new statistical methods for estimating concentrations of analytes measured in immunoassays, considering measurement error and contamination in the samples, and modeling exposure-outcome associations with adjustment for exposure measure uncertainty. The proposed new methods will be developed based on the indoor allergen measures collected using ELISAs and multiplex assays in the New York City Neighborhood Asthma and Allergy Study and will be used to assess the associations between concentrations of indoor allergens and asthma morbidity among asthmatic children. The methods and tools developed in this proposal will have a wide range of applications and can be used to improve lab analyses, which are crucial for diagnosis, treatment, and intervention decisions in many areas of medicine and public health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATVE This proposal uses state-of-the art machine learning techniques to extract important clinical information from digital kidney biopsy images. Deep learning models will integrate digital kidney pathology with proteomics and clinical data into a larger prediction framework to provide kidney disease patients with an automated assessment of vascular pathology and cardiovascular prognosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this proposal is to develop novel Adeno associated viral (AAV) for safe and efficient retinal gene delivery. The ability to target foveal photoreceptors is especially significant because this is the area of the retina responsible for acute, daylight vision. A significant portion of our work will be performed in macaques as these hurdles are faithfully recapitulated only in the intact eyes of animals with a fully functioning immune system, and ocular characteristics similar to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Warmer water in the Gulf of Mexico due to climate change, along with nutrient pollution of coastal waterways, have contributed to frequent and repeated Florida red tide (K. brevis) blooms, which impact large segments of gulf coast communities; however, the adverse effects of the neurotoxin, brevetoxin, produced by the algae, on the brain health remain unknown. This proposal will develop clinical tools and blood tests to detect aerosolized brevetoxin exposure- related adverse brain health effects on coastal residents, particularly those with preexisting neurological conditions or genetic predisposition to the harmful effects of environmental toxins. Ultimately, this work will help public health decision-making and developing strategies aimed at protecting the brain health of residents living in coastal communities who frequently endure exposure to harmful algal bloom toxins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons undergo massive morphological differentiation as they mature, including the growth of dendrites, axons, and synapses, and membrane transport and regulation of receptor signaling are essential to regulate this expansion in size. Disturbances in membrane traffic have been associated with numerous neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders. This proposal will determine how neurons regulate membrane traffic in time and space, a fundamental cell biological question with profound implications for neuronal function and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuft cells function as microbial sensors and direct regional immune responses in many organs. The colon or large intestine harbors the largest and most diverse community of microbes in the body, yet little is known about tuft cell interactions with microbes or the immune system in this part of the gut. This proposal will study how tuft cells in the colon detect specific microbes and how these cells influence inflammation, which may provide new avenues for treating infections or inflammatory disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We have identified multiple early differentiation paths that B cells can take following their initial immune activation, with one leading directly to the generation of antibody secreting cells, and the other to cells bearing a memory signature. To be able to design future immunotherapies and vaccines to infectious diseases, an understanding of the early transcriptional and epigenetic processes that govern this cell fate decision is needed. The aims of this study will define the epigenetic architecture of early naïve and memory B cell differentiation, identify genes and mechanisms that direct immunity, and ascribe the roles of key epigenetic modulators to this important immunological defense system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional impairment and loss of neurons are characteristics of neurodegenerative diseases. Numerous genes associated with these devastating diseases act in organelle quality control pathways. Our work focuses on investigating the mechanisms of neuronal selective recycling pathways involving the lysosome machinery using quantitative cell biological and proteomics approaches.

PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because developing novel treatment approaches for cardiac fibrosis and heart failure represents an urgent unmet societal need in the United States. Thus, the proposed research is highly relevant to the NHLBI’s mission to support medical research on heart failure, which affects ~6 million people in the Unites States and is a leading cause of mortality, hospitalization, and healthcare expenditures in our country. This proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge that will help to enhance health and reduce the burden of human illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Global cerebral ischemia arises as a consequence of cardiac arrest and affects ~200,000 Americans each year, however, an effective treatment for neurodegeneration and cognitive deficits associated with global ischemia remains an unmet medical need. The proposed research will examine a role for TREM1-triggered neuroinflammation in global ischemia pathology and test novel inhibitors of TREM1 and BRD4 that may be useful to ameliorate the neurological deficits of global cerebral ischemia. It is anticipated that these translational studies will create a foundation for developing novel therapeutic strategies to ameliorate this serious medical condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In the pancreatic islets of Langerhans, the peri-islet ECM provides a critical barrier to immune infiltration that is lost in early type 1 diabetes (T1D) and may contribute to islet dysfunction and death prior to clinical diagnosis of disease. Poor knowledge regarding the molecular mechanisms contributing to loss of the peri-islet ECM in early stages of T1D is a major barrier limiting the development of therapies to preserve β-cell mass and function in patients at risk for developing T1D. The goal of this study is to determine if cytokine-stressed β-cells contribute to loss of the peri-islet ECM in early T1D and determine how loss the peri-islet ECM impacts β-cell survival and function in preclinical T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Infection with the food-borne liver fluke, Opisthorchis viverrini, a parasitic worm, which is prevalent in East Asia, frequently leads to cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer). While the prognosis for this liver cancer is dismal, especially in the resource-poor regions when the liver fluke parasite is endemic, we have discovered proteins that are essential to the parasite. Here we focus on developing an anti-infection/anti-cancer vaccine targeting these essential-to-the-parasite proteins.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 1.25 million Americans aged 65 years and older receive hospice services annually, with hospice medications paid for by both the Medicare Part D prescription drug benefit and the Medicare Part A Hospice Benefit. In 2014, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) shifted policy to increasingly place the burden of medication payment on hospice agencies’ operating budgets and away from Part D. The impact of this policy change on patient and hospice outcomes is largely unclear, and we propose to address this gap with a nationwide retrospective interrupted time series analysis using secondary data from CMS.

PROJECT_TITLE: Impact of New Hospice Drug Policies on Expenditures, Utilization, Prescribing Quality, and Access

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many of the tools used in gene therapy and biomedical research (e.g. CRISPR-Cas systems) were discovered by studying bacteria and their viruses. This work will identify new regulators for CRISPR-Cas systems and compare different strategies to reduce their undesired off-target effects. This work will also find new bacterial- viral interactions that may influence biomedical and research technologies in years to come.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is growing evidence that distinct subgroups of scleroderma patients have an increased risk of cancer, and that unique scleroderma immune responses, alone or in combination, associate with cancer protection. It remains unknown whether cancer drives the autoimmune response more broadly in scleroderma, whether diversified immune responses exert potent anti-tumor pressure, and whether cancer treatment is effective scleroderma therapy. To address these knowledge gaps, this proposal will (i) study the value of innovative cancer and immune response measurements in identifying patients with incident cancer diagnosis, and (ii) investigate the relationships between malignancy, the immune response, and scleroderma disease activity in two of the largest scleroderma cohorts in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Blood trauma, arterial remodeling, and dysfunctional vasoregulation during non-pulsatile artificial circulation contribute to patient adverse events. The BiVACOR, a first-of-its-kind, impeller-based total artificial heart with the ability to generate continuous (non-pulsatile) or pulsatile outflow, will be used to investigate in vivo effects of non-pulsatile versus pulsatile flow. Findings will inform development of artificial pulsatility algorithms that mimic physiologic pulsatility in order to reduce adverse events in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The project aims to elucidate and reconstruct the biosynthetic machinery of kratom natural products in yeast for novel non-opioid analgesic development. It will address the longstanding question in plant metabolism about the role plant enzyme complexes play in regulating complicated biosynthesis. This work will provide new methods to discover novel plant complexes and the pathways they organize and ultimately advance pharmaceutical compound biosynthesis for “biased” non-opioid analgesics as the next-generation painkillers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Patients with alcohol use disorder who develop sepsis are significantly more likely to die or have a complicated intensive care unit stay than septic patients without a history of alcohol use disorder. Animal models demonstrate that both gut permeability and the adaptive immune system are disproportionately impacted in septic mice following chronic alcohol ingestion. Understanding mechanisms underlying why mortality is higher in septic hosts with alcohol use disorder may lead to precision medicine approaches to a disease that is common, costly, and highly lethal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a common chronic illness among children requiring a high degree of self-management for good glycemic control. Adolescents are at risk for poor disease management and health outcomes due to a number of factors, including high rates of depression, anxiety, and stress-related, maladaptive eating behavior, which undermine treatment adherence and worsen glycemic control. The current study therefore aims to conduct a pragmatic clinic-based efficacy trial with an additional feasibility of implementation aim utilizing a two-site clinic screening and referral process to a randomized controlled trial of a group-based mindfulness-based intervention, BREATHE-T1D, as compared to a health education condition, HealthEd-T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal heart rhythms are a major cause of heart failure, strokes, and death in the US. Our research focuses on how the heart acquires its normal heart rhythm during development, so we can apply this knowledge to better understand why abnormal heart rhythms form in the adult heart. Using this approach, we have identified an essential factor called all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and found that ATRA can be used to reverse disease processes in the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This is a service-user informed mixed-methods study of the implementation and impacts of the Certified Community Behavioral Health Clinic (CCBHC) program in New York State. Though the model is slated for continued expansion on a national basis, there has been limited research on it and none incorporating service user experience in the research process. By examining the service user perspective alongside rigorous empirical tests of the impact of CCBHCs on utilization and quality of care, this study will provide needed evidence for future implementation of the model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Type I Spiral ganglion neurons (SGNs) process and convey all electrical signal generated in the inner ear to the brain. Of the three known subtypes of SGNs, one is particularly critical for hearing in noisy environments but vulnerable to disconnection and eventual degeneration due to sound overexposure or old age. Here we investigate how the three subtypes of SGNs are generated, focusing on genetic and activity-dependent regulation of their unique identities during development in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Immunotherapy has revolutionized cancer treatment, but therapy resistance remains a significant problem. One promising strategy to trigger an immune response within tumors and enhance immunotherapy efficacy is by inducing the accumulation of endogenous ‘virus-mimetic’ nucleic acids in cancer cells. We have uncovered a novel viral mimicry-inducing factor, DHX9, involved in the suppression of double-stranded RNAs and RNA/DNA hybrids in cancer cells and aim to study how DHX9 controls these endogenous nucleic acids, as well as targeting DHX9 to enhance antitumor immunity and boost immunotherapy in ‘cold’ tumors, such as Small Cell Lung Cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is relevant to public health as it will use state-of-the-art imaging in living cells and live animals to provide novel insights into the dynamic processes by which the bone in our skeletons is built by bone forming cells called “osteoblasts” and is resorbed/reshaped by bone destroying cells called “osteoclasts”. We will for the first time dynamically image the process by which key proteins that form the bone structure are assembled in living bone cells and in live animals and determine in real time how drugs that are used to treat osteoporosis (low bone mass) affect bone cell dynamics and bone resorption dynamics. These studies will significantly advance our mechanistic understanding of the processes of bone formation and resorption and have implications for treatment of osteoporosis, osteogenesis imperfecta and metabolic bone diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pachyonychia congenita (PC) is a rare genetic skin disorder caused by mutations in specific keratin genes. PC profoundly alters quality of life owing to, in particular, excruciatingly painful lesions in plantar/palmar skin, and there are no effective treatments available for this condition. This project aims at creating and validating transgenic mouse models that genetically and phenotypically recapitulate PC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have characterized the recurrent mutations observed in patients diagnosed with large granular lymphocytic leukemia (LGLL). In this project, we determine the functional consequences of those mutations in T- and NK cell models to identify disease-relevant molecular pathways, predictive markers of treatment response, and new targets for therapeutic intervention. The assembled multidisciplinary team is uniquely suited for the proposed work that requires integration of genomic datasets (Ratan, Zang) and genome editing in immune cells (Luckey) with expertise in LGL leukemia biology and an extensive patient registry (Loughran, Feith).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome (HLHS) is the leading indication for heart transplantation in infancy and is the most common cause of cardiovascular death in infants. With improved understanding of HLHS pathogenesis, the identification of novel therapeutic strategies will serve to decrease costs and improve outcomes for this vulnerable group. The results of this study will establish key mechanisms and modulators of heart failure progression in HLHS and will elucidate a potential therapeutic pathway to mitigate cardiometabolic impairments and progressive cardiac dysfunction in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinoblastoma is a childhood retinal cancer that is thought to develop by forming premalignant lesions in utero, followed by malignant progression and tumor emergence in infants and young children. This project aims to understand how the aberrantly proliferating retinal cells overcome initial barriers to growth, form quiescent premalignant lesions, and later emerge as retinoblastoma tumors. Understanding this process may enable approaches to suppress malignant progression and the development of retinoblastoma in genetically predisposed individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: ICAM-1 is an adhesion molecule expressed on the surface of alveolar epithelial cells, endothelial cells, immune cells, and other parenchymal cells that mediates parenchymal cell-leukocyte adhesion and outside-in intracellular signaling through binding to β2 leukocyte integrins during homeostasis and the innate immune response. Studies of ICAM-1 are stymied by the critical need for mice generated by CRISPR/Cas9 technology and for cell-specific Icam1 knockout mice. We are generating mice deficient in ICAM-1 in alveolar epithelial cells or endothelial cells and propose to study the function of both membrane-bound and soluble ICAM-1 in clearance of alveolar surfaces by alveolar macrophages, maintenance of circulating neutrophil counts, sequestration of neutrophils by intravascular inflammatory mediators, and inflammatory and innate immune responses to S. pneumoniae and P. aeruginosa, two common and clinically relevant bacteria that recruit neutrophils through different adhesion pathways, so that we can understand this interesting and critically molecule and assess its potential as a therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While current guidelines suggest that restrictive transfusion threshold of 7 to 8 g/dL is safe, this might not be true for patients with different underlying disorders that are less tolerant of anemia. This individual patient data meta-analysis (IPDMA) will establish a comprehensive database with the power and detail to fully explore the effects of transfusion thresholds across clinically important subgroups of patients. The results will inform red blood cell transfusion guidelines and influence clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The R01 renewal focuses on refining the Non-Invasive Venous waveform Analysis for Heart Failure (NIVAHF) device, a tool developed for non-invasive monitoring of volume status in heart failure patients. Through a series of detailed aims, the project intends to overcome its discovered limitations by better understanding how the device's signals are influenced by conditions such as tricuspid regurgitation, post-heart transplantation, and the presence of a left ventricular assist device. By leveraging advanced statistical analyses and machine learning, this research aims to optimize the clinical utility of the NIVAHF device for these specific patient subsets, ensuring more accurate and timely detection of complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal aims to study pathways that lead to environmentally-associated social anxiety symptoms in Black and Latinx youth living in the context of economic disadvantage, a population that is at high risk for mental health problems but has been underrepresented in neuroimaging research. We propose to investigate effects of prenatal exposure to air pollution on risk for social anxiety symptoms through studying effects of prenatal exposure to air pollution on behavioral inhibition, a marker of social anxiety, and brain function underlying cognitive control, a risk factor for social anxiety in children with behavioral inhibition. The long-term goal is to inform development of novel prevention and interventions programs for social anxiety in youth living in the context of economic disadvantage, and to promote interdisciplinary developmental team science in which the wider mental health system has the skills to work together to improve the health and development of vulnerable children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Although hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a common condition, particularly in Black patients and women, and impacts qualify of life more severely than almost any other skin disease, there is currently limited understanding of the genetic factors that contribute to disease risk and severity. Our initial genetic study of 720 HS patients combined with patient data in biobanks identified genetic variants that contribute to the risk of developing HS and that may affect the genes SOX9 and KLF5 to influence wound healing, inflammation, and the maintenance of the skin and hair follicles. In addition to studying how the recently discovered genetic variants affect HS, we will use a larger genetic study of 2,000 patients and more biobanks to identify more variants affecting HS, including any related to ancestry and disease severity, which may help predict risk of disease progression and reveal new targets for treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The rising rates of maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States demand answers. The obstetric outcomes of hemorrhage and infection, which contribute to maternal mortality, and cesarean delivery in low- risk women, which increases maternal and neonatal morbidity risk, vary widely across hospitals and are marked by stark disparities between Black and non-Black women. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to improve maternal health and reduce maternal health disparities by developing actionable evidence about the influence of changes in labor and delivery nursing unit organizational characteristics (work environment, nurse workload, percentage of registered nurses with a Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree) on these three obstetric outcomes and disparities in these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative  After loss of vestibular (inner ear balance) sensation, some patients ultimately recover enough to perform daily activities, but many fail to fully compensate and remain disabled by chronic imbalance and the inability to see clearly while moving. This research project will identify the neural mechanisms that underlie how the brain adapts to changes in vestibular input and will advance development of an implantable bionic inner ear device that can help restore quality of life to thousands of individuals disabled by unilateral and bilateral loss of vestibular sensation.
