IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  Despite intensive research, the etiology leading to neuronal cell loss in Parkinson’s diseases (PD), Alzheimer’s diseases and related dementias remains unknown. Genome wide association studies (GWAS) have identified numerous sequence variants associated with the risk to develop sporadic PD, however, there is little insight regarding which and how these risk variants mechanistically contribute to the development and progression of PD, thus impeding the clinical use and the development of novel therapeutics based on these data. This proposal aims to systematical identify and define the molecular and cellular mechanisms how GWAS-risk variants contribute to the development and progression of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis underlies the leading cause of death in industrialized societies. During atherogenesis, the accumulation of apolipoprotein B containing lipoproteins (LDL and VLDL) in the matrix beneath the endothelial layer of blood vessels leads to the recruitment of monocytes, cells of the immune system that give rise to macrophages and dendritic cells. Macrophages derived from recruited monocytes participate in a maladaptive non-resolving inflammatory response that expands the subendothelial layer due to the accumulation of cells, lipids, and matrix. This proposal aims to investigate the contribution of TMEM86 enzymes in regulating phospholipid remodeling and plasmalogen-derived active lipids mediators in macrophages. We will define how plasmalogen metabolism regulated by TMEM86a controls macrophage immunometabolic responses during the progression of atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States and across the world, and cardiac fibrosis is one of the most detrimental factors for a variety of heart disease including hypertrophy and heart failure. However, an efficient therapy for fibrosis-associated heart disease is still an unmet need. We propose to investigate novel mechanisms of cardiac fibrogenesis and to identify potential new therapeutic targets for developing better therapy for fibrosis-associated heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS OF THE PERMIAN BASIN
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the novel mechanism underlying the pathogenesis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Based on our novel findings, we hypothesize that the mitochondrial carrier protein PSAP plays a regulatory role in mitochondrial quality control, apoptosis, and autophagy pathways, thereby contributing to the pathogenesis of ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases . The elucidation of the molecular mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of ALS will facilitate the development of preventive and therapeutic strategies .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The black-legged tick, Ixodes scapularis, transmit several pathogens, including Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human anaplasmosis. Survival in the vector in different developmental stages of ticks is particularly important for intracellular microbes, such as A. phagocytophilum, that cannot be transovarially transmitted. In this study, we propose to characterize the role of tick molecules such as organic anion transporting polypeptide (OATP), Xanthurenic acid (XA), tryptophan pathway and microRNAs in A. phagocytophilum survival and transmission from these medically important vectors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is to optimize the inhibition of BACE1, known as β-site amyloid precursor protein, for reducing both amyloid plaques and subsequent tau pathology. We aim to investigate how to inhibit BACE1 together with enhancing microglial function for reducing AD pathologies. The obtained results will eventually be used to develop safe BACE1 inhibitors and modulator for microglia function for AD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ionotropic glutamate receptors (iGluRs) mediate the majority of excitatory neurotransmission in the central nervous system, while their disfunction is associated with devastating psychiatric, neurological, and neurodegenerative disorders, including schizophrenia, depression, autism, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, epilepsy, and Alzheimer’s disease. We aim to study heteromeric assembly, noncompetitive inhibition, and ion channel block of AMPA and kainate subtypes of iGluRs using a combination of biophysical and biochemical approaches. Our results will advance understanding of iGluR structure and function and guide structure-based drug design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The healing response within the myocardium after a myocardial infarction (MI) is complex and involves both temporal and regional changes including inflammation, cardiac scar formation, and tissue remodeling. Over the last decade the importance of the spleen has been highlighted as a reservoir for the majority of monocytes trafficking to the heart in response to ischemic damage. In this proposal, we will utilize advanced nanomaterials as tools to localize inhibitors to the spleen to dissect the mechanisms by which HDACs modulate the cardiac inflammatory affect after MI.
